A decent beer. Good with a light meal like a salad. Pours light. Light head. Crisp beer
As close in flavor to white bread as beer gets.  Not exceptional and overated, but passable overall.
Quite good pale lager. Widely distributed, still there is something unique and interesting. Well balanced bitterness.

First off I will say that I do really enjoy Stella Artois. The problem with it as with most mass produced beer is it loses some character. Stella is a pale lager that offers a refreshing crispness, a light dance on the tongue if you will. What Stella lacks is a full body, strong aroma, or any complexity. It pours pale straw yellow with a thick white bubbly head. There is little to no aroma as well. It does have more flavor than most US macro brew or alot of common lagers. Light taste with easy going hop character. It is bubbly and light in the mouth and is very drinkable. If you are in a bar with a limited selection, you are in the mood for larger, a Stella will not do you wrong. Keeping in mind that there are many lagers with way more complexity, however Stella is easy to find.
On tap at the devils game.  Poured a golden light yellow color with a white head.  Crisp, refreshing and drinkable but not too much to this one.

Green bottle, 330 ml, best before 30/05/11, drank in its glass, gift from my boss (merci!), savoured on January 17 2011; eye: golden, clear, good effervescence, tiny ring of off-white head, no lacing; nose: corn, slight spices, sugar; mouth: corn, acridness, sugary, finale in corn with presence of acridness, light body, rather carbonated, mildly sweet, grainy texture; overall: quite ordinary

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille verte, 330 ml, meilleure avant 30/05/11, bue dans son verre, cadeau de mon patron (merci!), savourée le 17 janvier 2011; œil : dorée, claire, pas d’effervescence, petit anneau de mousse blanc cassé; nez : maïs, très léger épices, sucre; bouche : maïs, âcreté, sucré, finale en maïs avec présence d’âcreté, corps léger, plutôt carbonatée, moyennement sucrée, texture granuleuse; en résumé : b’en ordinaire
I don’t know what was wrong with the one that I tasted, but there was a strong bitter flavor coming from it that shouldn’t have been there.

Light golden colour with a white head. Aside from the hoppy aroma, there’s always been something about the aroma I’ve never liked, can’t quite put my finger on it. Taste is malty, soft, a little fuller bodied than most macro beers with a slightly bitter finish. Decent but I’ve never been a big fan, not about to start with this tasting either.

I drink Stella quite a bit. Pours light amber with a nice white head that dissipated about half way through the beer. Aroma is malty. Flavour is sweet and bitter ay the same time. Full bodied and great ratio of Carbonation. Makes a nice light and refreshing beer.

Pours a clear golden with medium white head.  Moderate carbonation with decent lacing throughout.  A bit of flavor, nothing exciting.  Would not purchase again, but if given to me I would drink.  Not worth a premium price.  Like their tulip glass however...

Aroma: Lots of green hops, grass or floral, with hints of bready malt underneath.
Appearance: Pale, sparkling gold with frothy white head that dissipated too quickly.
Taste: Medium sweetness, medium sourness--not unpleasant, but an odd aftertaste.
Palate: Light-Medium Body, creamy texture, lively carbonation, bitter finish.
Overall: Not too impressed.  It’s drinkable, but I wouldn’t stock my fridge with it.

I am sorry, but what does this beer have that the cheap mass produced beers don’t?  It’s not much better!  It’s marketed as this la dee da beer, and I think many people have been duped.  Stella sucks.  And i’m confused by, buddy’s review below me. Why should I check the label to make sure its genuine import?  As if import makes it better...  yeesh what a sucker for the stella marketing campaign.  I’d way rather have some cheap lager made down the street from me instead of this stuff.

330ml bottle (brewed under license in Australia by Fosters - always check the label to see if you are getting the genuine imported version or not). A clear golden beer with a loose white head. Nose and taste is grainy sweet malts with subtle grassy hops. Medium bodied and easily drinkable with a low carbonation. An OK premium lager but I recall the Belgian brewed version was better.
On draft. Golden and transparent in the glass. Bready malt nose. Medium body. Touch of diacetyl on the palate. Definitely like this one more on draft.
A very good pilsener. Here in Norway, our lagers are not that great. This is a very decent lager, with a sweet malty note to it.
Ho sempre apprezzato questa pale lager, perchè nel mondo delle birre industriali ha sempre tenuto un certo livello, ma ora il livello è calato e parecchio...
330ml bottle. Pale clear golden. Head is medium high and total white. Aroma has some citrus and grass. Flavor is pure and quite fresh. Has citrus and grassy hops. Maybe little dry finish.

500ml can of UK brewed Stella. Pours a medium white head, average retention. Clear pale yellow-gold body. Wheat dominates, grassy hop, corn. Bitter. Dry lingering bitter finish. 4 2 5 2 8 Bottle. Wheat, alcohol, corn, hoppy. Bitter. Pale gold, white head. Sweet dry finish. 4 2 5 2 8 ### Clearly a premium lager. Metallic, watery, whiff of sulphur, lager malt. Not too bitter, not too sweet. Dry finish. 4 2 4 2 10

Pours clear copper yellow with a rather small fast diminishing head. Aroma is very light with a hint of sweetness. Taste is very mild, some sweetness, very little bitterness is noticed. Finish is hardly noticeable but does linger a bit in the background. Palate is light bodied, watery with low carbonation. Overall as a pale lager i would say this is a good beer, it’s refreshing and mild and very drinkable as such.

Bottle. I typically drink ales more than lager, but when I want a pale lager, I really like Stella. Grainy/malty flavor is what sets this beer apart from many other lagers in my opinion. Quite refreshing and good overall, when rating based on this style.

Pours a golden tint with white head.  Very little lacing.  Aroma of corn and bread.  Taste is the same with a crisp dry bitterness that lingers.  Alittle sweet and bubbly. On the tongue.  Good...for a pale lager.

Poured into a pint glass. Appearance is a pale, clear golden with a fluffy white head that dissipates rather quickly. Nearly no aroma. Taste is almost nothing. I get a slight carbonation on the tongue but other than that, I have difficulty realizing there is a beer in my mouth. Meh.

From a 330ml bottle on 30/12/2010 (brewed under licence in Australia). An okay premiuim lager. Has a slight grainy, grassy aroma. Very line and length flavour wise, with a reasonable hop kick at end (has a slight lemony sourness).
Bottled in Vail, Colorado.  Light golden yellow appearance. Pale malty aroma. Slightly creamy mouthfeel. Fairly sweet pale malty flavor. Malty aftertaste.
27.09.2007. 0,33l Bottle at the Metra Club in London. Pale yellow colour with white head. Weak malty aroma with ok bitterness. Short finish.

Smells like grainy nothing.  Gold, but with no head- it looks just like apple juice.  Yuk.  Flavor is acceptable, mildly grainy and grassy in a balanced way, but with hints of corn and an off-astringency I associate with the grain.  Not my favorite.  I got a pint to rate the beer, and I will probably never have this beer again.

Bottle (284ml): Not much of a smell here to be hones, just grain & some light malts. Looks pale yellow with a bubbly white head that doesn’t last long. Tastes mildly bitter with grain & hops & malts & a light bitter finish. It is light bodied with a slight fizz & generally quite smooth. An average beer overall with no real negative aspects other than the look really. Very drinkable beer & goes down well. ()
Very fizzy, light. Flavors of corn and rice, pale malt. Actually not bad, but I’d still take a Yuengling over this beer for the category.

bottle.  Pours clear gold with actually a sustaining white head.  Light aroma, mostly of nothing, but some light corn.  Taste is crisp, refreshing lager, some corn / hop notes.  Although it’s pretty uninteresting, it really is a nice pale lager, very smooth, refreshing, drinkable.

Took me a while to get this one in. Probably because I never order it. Ever. It gets you drunk. Makes you beat your wife. Everyone knows Stella. It’s rubbish. Even for rubbish it’s rubbish. It offends me. Reassuringly expensive! That takes the piss.

Little blond easy to drink ! Good for everyone  !

nothing  crasy  ,  but still good , overrated for the grand ppl.  
a bit better then the master brewer !

Pours a nice golden clear with minimal head, not much of smell, your typical macro brewer pale lager smell. Taste is malty, hay, corn, not great but i got a soft spot for this beer because i use to think this was the greatest beer ever but as you get older and experience other types of beer you quickly realize this beer isn’t that great at all. I’m giving it a bit of high score here. Not much of an aftertaste, pretty bland, drink it ice cold on a really hot day!
Very reliable beer, that when ice cold on a summer day, you can’t go wrong.
Pale, bright golden color.  Nice foamy head.  Hardly any bitterness. Crisp and clean, with a light biscuit-y flavor. Not extremely flavorful, but nice enough.
Disappointing, not sure why I expected better. Has a strange finish, almost a toxic lime. Besides for that, nothing unpleasant, but nothing interesting either.

Bottle.  Thought I rated this one before...oh well.  Pours clear, pale gold, with a medium frothy white head.  A little lacing is left on the glass as the head recedes.  Aromas of corn and skunk.  Flavor is similar; sweet corn, sweet berry, and a bit of bitter grass in the finish.  Medium carbonation and tart-ish.  Meh.

Straight out of a bottle.  Aromas/Tastes not unpleasant but subdued nearly to the point of non-existence...what’s there is mostly a light grainy maltiness.  Quite smooth.  Maybe a hint of balancing grassy hops?  Not bad, but dull.  And great for it’s style.
Pours an aggressively bubbly piss yellow with billowy white foam. Tastes very mild, but is well balanced with no mass-produced aftertaste.
excelente bière, si je devais recomender une bière qui a du charactère et du gout, ce serait celle ci
Bottle.  Pour is clear medium gold with white head. Not much nose, a little fruit, a little hop. Notes of slight fruit, malt, and hops. Clean finish. Unoffensive but boring.

Somehow I haven’t rated this yet, so here goes. From a bottle. Pours light straw yellow with a respectable white head. The aroma is a tad skunky (yay green bottle), with some strong hay and grass notes, a little bit of lime and peach fruitiness, a just a hint of sweetness. The flavor is fair enough for what it is. A light maltiness with some grass and lemon notes. There is just a touch of a chemical note in the finish. Not something I would drink by choice, but for what it is, it isn’t too shabby.
good overall beer...surprisingly somewhat cheap if you find it in the right place...once found for 12.99 for a 12 pack

Draft at Toad in the Hole. Clear gold with fluffy white head. Strong sulfur and recessive fresh bread aroma. Mostly pleasing pale malt flavor. Very clean with lingering grainy aftertaste. May be worthy of classification as a Munich helles, but barely.

Tap. Crystal clear pale gold pour with a quickly dissipating white head that clings to the glass. Aroma is grass and lemon. Watery mouthfeel. Taste has just a touch of Belgian yeast, extremely mild cherry/fruit, plenty of grass. For its style, terrific. For a beer in general, its just above a drain pour.

Bottle. Light yellow with a medium sized-short-lived white head. Aroma of light floral hops and sweet grain. Taste is lightly sweet with a touch of bitterness. Thin and a bit watery. Basic, boring but inoffensive.

Rating #440, can and gift from Ingerlis 
 


Another unbelievable pale lager beer, and this can’t even keep a head.
Aroma has only a bit of spicy hoppyness and no malts whatsoever, maybe a tiny bit caramel. Well, taste is much better than the impression. It has some caramel and honey at first which is very pleasing, then comes some spicyness from hops and a nice alcohol-touch in the finish. Bitterness is VERY mild. This is a very nice lager taste allthough the bitterness is missing, and it is really a shame that the rest of the beer does not live up to that. Palate is a bit better than average, and even somewhat creamy. All in all a nice expierience due to the taste and palate, but appearance and aroma are under average.
440ml can.  Pours pale golden with a large head.  Aroma is grassy, with a hint of some hops.  Hardly any taste, just some pale malt.  Sweet after taste.  Easy to drink.
Light straw color; Light to medium body; Aroma of malt, & cereal; Flavor of light malt, hops, and grain; Finish is slightly bitter; Overall, solid lager.
Im just now having one and its pretty good belgium beer..not bad for the price
Pours straw yellow with thick white head and foamy lacing.  Not much aroma, but faint straw and hay.  Not much taste, either.  Not sure why this stuff is so popular.

Bottle:
White head on top of a clear yellow beer.
Typical pilsner smell of malts, spices and hops.
Taste is typical for a pilsner with nothing really to add it up.
Ok,nothing special,just a nice addition to the Greek Market besides amstel and Heineken...Easy to drink as any pale lager,nice soury aroma but otherwise a bit dull...

Clear yellow pour with a soapy, one finger, bright white head. Aroma is sweet grass, cereal, dry hay and light floral notes. Flavor is grass, cereal, floral notes, bready yeast, finishes with light toast and mineral notes. Palate is light bodied with a moderate strength but fairly sharp carbonation. Decent pale lager.
Clear yellow, good white head.  Aroma is malty along with ever so slightly skunked hops.  A good malty taste along with a well balanced bitterness.
On tap at chapys in dayton, oh. Musty aroma. Golden color with light head. Not much flavor but what there is is fairly bold. Decent beer but not worth the price at a restaurant.
sweet malty,toast, yellow golden, clear, minimal head, light sweetness, lightly bitter, salty, light body, thin feel, lively,
Clear golden beer with decent head.Flavor,sweet,light bitter,citrus hops,some fruits,light sour.Good body for pale lager.

330 ml bottle @ Ullan Krouvi. Rated @ 22.7.2010.

Pours a clear yellow colour with a foamy white head. Fair amount of hops on the nose and flavour. Malty body. Not-that-bad lager.
Average pale lager.  What non-beer lovers drink.  Pretty straightforward, and identical in the bottle or from the tap.

I personally thought this was just awful, and my friends were telling me how awesome it is, obviously not beer drinkers, had this on tap, pours a light golden color with a thin white head, aroma is of corn with cardboard, has a very light mouthfeel and is overall extremely bland and boring.
I do love this beer, especially when enjoyed out of its signature glass. Nice lager with a smooth finish.

I distinctly recall not liking this beer too much and am schocked that I didn’t rate it. In any case, a poor look and to my taste, a bit too much lager funk.  In addition, as I find it similar to poor American lagers, this is therefore overpriced.
This beer is an enjoyable. Mainly because this is an import it is overpriced but anyways its a very drinkable beer

I like this beer simply because it’s the ultimate fall back beer if you’re at a bar or somewhere with a limited selection.  While it’s certainly nothing to write home about, out of all the "common, mass produced" beers this one definitely takes the cake.  While it may not be as good as microbrewery or quality imports, it sure as hell beats a Moslon or Kokanee or Bud or Coors et cetra any day.  Much more complex flavor then you’d find in a beer that is fairly common.  Mild hints of green apple in the nose and palate, and very slight citrus notes in the aftertaste, albeit you almost have to be looking for them.  Light, drinkable, different than most "mainstream" beers.  I’d even go so far as to say it’s a great introduction to more complex beers for newbies.  I’d drink it any day.

Draught at De Fiere Margriet, after a long day of 6 Westies, 7 Struise, and a few with dinner. Decent enough hop character to make me taste it, enough balance to be enjoyable. Light, clean, refreshing after a long day of drinking wonderful beers. Much better than in tastes in Japan. Hard to say something nice about it, but not bad.

Bottle at barbeque, pours a straw yellow, with very thin head. Aroma of light malt, some cereal, light hops. Taste is similar to aroma. Palate is light body, and light  watery carbonation. Finish is light malty and cereal, very little hops. Overall good served very cold on a summer day.
Bottle, 5,0%. Has a weak sweet taste and no aftertaste. Easily drinkable but often overpriced - you can probably get something better for the price. Just look around.

Bottle:  The aroma is light-moderately grassy and floral with a hint of sweetness.  It pours a transparent gold with a large white head with fairly good retention.  The flavor starts with lightly sweet cereal notes.  The finish is lightly grassy with a hint of floral notes.  Light bodied with light fizzy carbonation.  Surprisingly...better than I expected.

Bel giallo carico. Schiuma compatta ma non fine. Secca, con note di amaro. Gusto debole e poco persistente. Poco equilibrata. Sapore mediocre di malto. Niente luppolo. Bionda da bere ghiacciata. 

Beautiful golden. Foam compact but not fine. Dry with something bitter. taste is easy and not durable. Not so equilibrate. Taste is sometind of malt. Nothing of hop. Lager to drik iced. 

(maremma che traduzione)
One of the better pale lagers.  Crisp with a decent floral bouquet and some flavor to it.
I don’t really get the hate for this beer. It’s definitely on the high end of the "out of the bottle" spectrum of beers; not too bitter, crisp and floral. Easy drinkability.
Nose is moldy and faintly like wet dog, tastes a little bland and watery, hints of shoe sole.
Very skunky aroma. Light golden in color. Not bad for a macro lager. Definitely drinkable and smooth.
Draught. Cereal hop aroma and flavour whith sharp aftertaste. Better than I expected.
Pale gold, huge bubbly white head. Sweet aroma and flavor, a slight yeast flavor going on. Finish is rather lingering for this style, good for a mass produced beer.

One of my favorite (and well deserved, considering its great world wide rateing).

..Aroma.. nice hoppy ..hoppy..happy.
 fresh cut grass/alfalfa, bitter in a great way, very refreshing, perfect on a hot summer day.(mebe mowing the lawn, or enjoying time with good friends, amazing. Although not hispanic great with some lighter mexican food’s.

..Taste.. almost no malt, infact low sweetness, verry floral, tiny hint of evergreen. (In my opinion)

..Yeast/Bac.. earthy in a green way...umm..( it seems too clean...sterile in a good way, no real bac taste.

Other..bay leaf.....
Definitely one of the better pale lagers around. No skunk or chemical/metal taste and goes down smooth

Stella Artois has a thick, white head and a very clear yellow-golden appearance.  Carbonation is high and lacing is present and fairly even.  The aroma was skunky, stinging, and bad.  The taste is of barley, some other grain I think, and hops, which are relatively strong on the back end of the sip.  Mouth-feel is light, watery, and slimy.  Stella Artois finishes crisp and fairly refreshing.  I preferred this beer when I had it once on tap; the green bottle allows light to spoil the beer.  So, I would recommend only drinking this on draft or from the can.  Overall, I’d rate this as a pretty good beer.

RJT
Ressemble un peu à la Heineken, mais en mois houblonné. Idéale dans ma recette de moules belge à la bière et au cary.
Pours a light yellowish color. Smells a bit of skunk with some fruit and spice. Taste is similar.

Stella Artois. This is what Heineken should be like. It pours out a clear yellow with a white head that settles and dissipates very quickly. It has a strong, very strong skunky aroma. It’s pretty intense. It has a slightly hoppy metallic flavor to it. It settles into a sweet undertone that the body carries somewhat well. This is a macro lager but it’s definitely one of the better ones on the market. If you like this sort of beers and are at a basic market, this would be one of the better choices. Overall it’s a decent beer that is marketed really well.

I think I might’ve gotten my hands on a stale bottle but this is awful. Harsh oxidized stale taste w/ no redeeming qualities other than a nice head and look to the beer. I can’t believe people drink this. I’d take a PBR over this any day for 1/2 the price.

On tap at Tigin Irish Pub in downtown St. Louis. Pours a dark golden yellow with an attractive foamy head. Light beer with high drinkability. Very good beer, definitely memorable and I highly recommend it.
A great pale lager, good hop flavor, finishes clean with that righteous pilsner aftertaste.

This is actually not a bad euro lager.  Nice malt sweetness.  However this has to be the most overrated lager in the world.  People go crazy for It. I think It is way to average for all that.  Serving: Bottle and tap
Bottle. Clear yellow with medium size white head. Flavour is malt, sweet  and hops.

Powdered sugar in the nose and in the aftertaste.  I waited a while before rating this beer because of it’s great following and oh so wonderfully surprising coupons.  yup.  coupons.  Non-distinct hop aroma and malt aroma, a little warm-fart like...you know what I mean, not the acidic ripe smelling fart, but the sweat-pant induced silent but deadly smell. Bottle.

Pours a clear yellow body with a medium white head. Aroma of some hops and bread. Average and quite boring lager flavor, some bitterness, some malt sweetness and boiled vegetables. Not much to say about this, a standard lager.
11.2 oz bottle. Very pale with a fizzy white head. Nothing exciting, but it’s better than most American pale lagers.

head: normal 

colour: goldenblond, clear 

smell: grains , corn , malts, bit of hops 

taste: sweet for lager, yeast , hops, bitter , malts , very famous beer national and international but in my eyes like many pilsner/lager types of belgium not worth to be proud of ... altough this one is much better than jupiler, primus or maes

Not the sort of beer you want when you ask for a Belgian, but IMO, better than given credit for.
Light grain aroma. Clear yellow color with a small white head. Mildish bitter and sweet beginning. Bitterness fades in the finish,
Bottle. Clear straw with tight head. Aromas of straw, malt, and grass. Flavors of malt and straw. Thin body with moderate carbonation.

Pours a pretty uninteresting pale yellow body with a medium white head. Smell is skunky hops with hints of wet paper. Taste is pretty average lager flavor; some bitter dry hops, very light malt sweetness and a few touches of boiled vegetables. Stella Artois is, as expected, a straight forward lager beer of the mediocre kind.
Random bottle found in fridge. Clear gold pour with thick white head. Musty malt, noble hop aroma. Light crisp malt with just a hint of noble hop bite. Light and clean.

On tap at Yardhouse. Pours a clear golden with a small frothy white head that diminshes quickly to nothing. Corn malt aroma. Medium mouthfeel with a corn malt wih a bitter finish. Not much going on with this one.
En canette.  Bière jaune étincelante qui propose, au nez et à la bouche, un mélange de maïs sucré et de foin.  En résumé, lager de faible intensité.
Pours a slightly cloudy straw color in glass. It’s a better than average pale lager. Nose and taste is pale malts. Rated 3/9/2000
Bottle. Golden color, medium not lasting head. Aroma hoppy. Taste bitter. Boring beer.

(12 oz bottle).  Pours straw colored with thick white head.  Aroma of skunk which masks some candied sugar.  Sweet followed by some slight bitterness.  Too bad it was skunked; a decent lager made worse for marketing purposes.

11.2 oz bottle at restaurant 

Appearance: Clear yellow with a nice white head and lot of lacing 

Aroma: Skunky, pale malts and yeasty 

Taste: Pale malts, citrus and some bitterness 

Drinkable, a good standby when nothing else is available.
Low white head. Aroma and flavor are corny traditionel, mild grassy, mild slight sweetness, metallic. Bottle

THIS IS YET ANOTHER CLEVERLY DISGUISED MASS PRODUCED ANHEUSER BUSCH PRODUCT THAT MAY HAVE ONE DAY BEEN GOOD. TODAY NOT SO MUCH, IT HAS SKUNKY AROMA A BIG HEAD CLEAR YELLOW COLOR AND CORNY WATERY MALT FLAVOR NOT A HORRIBLE TASTE BUT NOT ENOUGH FLAVOR TO TALK ABOUT, NOT NEARLY  WORTH THE PRICE.

Aroma:  SKUNK!  Obscures everything else.  Brilliant clear light golden color with pillowy bright white head, good retention, plenty of lacing.  Taste:  Skunk extract with something slightly sweet that might have been enjoyable if my palate hadn’t been scorched by SKUNK.  Mouthfeel creamy but light, moderate carbonation.  Dry finish.  Another victim of the "Green Bottle Curse".  A beautiful-looking lager with an interesting sweet undercurrent, but I can’t keep playing green bottle roulette.  I’ve had Euro Pils and Lagers in brown glass bottles and they are just fine.  I feel like Charlie Brown running up to kick the football with Lucy Van Pelt as the Euro exporters.  Why do I keep going back to green bottles?  Like a battered wife, I suppose I keep hoping "this time will be different."

I’ve travelled to many different countries and I’ve noticed the most popular beers are usually some of the least impressive. In the USA we have Budweiser, Miller and Coors and Europe has Carlsberg and Stella Artois. Stella is definitely a distinctly European-style brew, but because it’s a mass-market beer it’s only average in quality.

POUR, COLOR AND AROMA

There is a special “chalice” glass specifically designed for Stella Artois, but I do not own one, so I had to use a regular pint glass. The beer poured extremely rough out of the bottle and formed a large, bright white, creamy head (this is impressive for a pilsner). The color was a crystal-clear, beautiful shade of light gold with a lot of carbonation apparent. 

A problem with this beer is its green bottle which does not adequately protect it from light. As soon as I popped the top I could smell a very “skunky” scent which is typical for green bottle brews. The scent was much more potent than simply a generic, grainy “beer smell” (which was also evident upon closer inspection). 

TASTE

I was pleasantly surprised upon my first swig of this beer because I was expecting a typical dry, bitter, bland, watery taste that pilsners of this type are known for. Instead I got a surprisingly creamy-tasting head with a body that was fairly standard in the pilsner style, but with just a tad more flavor.

The problem with Stella Artois is this enjoyability is only good for a short amount of time right after the beer is poured. As it flattens and warms the taste becomes blunt, dry, bitter and watery. It claims to be a premium pilsner, but there isn’t much to the palate to suggest neither any premium ingredients nor any high-end, delicious taste. This is a beer that is fine for very short bursts only, and probably even better when accompanying food. Otherwise, the taste is unremarkable.

FINISH

Light lagers and pilsners are not known for their smooth finish, but Stella Artois is a notable exception to that rule. With its creamy head and fairly watery body, it’s no wonder this beer is easy to drink without any friction at all.

BODY

I haven’t been able to get official statistics on this beer, but my sources tell me it is fairly light at 5.2% ABV and 140 calories per serving. I can at least attest from experience that Stella Artois is probably about that light as it had very little effect on me. It was actually quite refreshing in a way and would probably work much better as a summer beer than a winter one. 

FINAL THOUGHTS

A smooth finish and a light body are nice qualities for a beer to have, but I’d much rather have some real taste to my beer. Stella Artois is only delectable for a limited time and even then it does nothing to impress my palate. . It makes me wonder just how “progressive” our neighbors across the pond really are if they’re drinking this stuff en masse.

I really like Stella served VERY cold. I enjoy it with pastas, pizzas, salads and maybe fish/seafood.

Light golden. Looks like a Bud or something. Thin head, decent lacing.  Smells floral. Hoppy up front, but a sweet finish. Quite drinkable. It’s pretty light and tasty. Not entirely my style, but it’s fairly easy to find, so when there is a somewhat limited selection, this would be a pretty decent choice.
WAY too strong of an after taste.  Decent taste, color is good.  Nothing special about this beer.
Classy green bottle beer. Tastes like skunk with a hint of cooked corn and grass.
Pours a clear golden hue.  Aroma is grass and malts.  Taste is sweet, nothing spectacular and does not get a full review.

One of my favourites. It’s a nice golden colour, with a fairly frothy head. Skunky aroma reminds me of Heineken but out of the can I find it’s much more pleasant. Nothing beats a nice fresh pint on tap though. Excellent beer but not as good as many other Belgian brews.

Stella Artois is basically the superior version of Heineken.  While maintaining a similar pale lager simplicity, Stella has a sweeter more complex taste and better body. Definitely superior to the big three American pale lagers in every sense of the word, but still inferior.

golden yellow body with minimal white head
taste is of hops and malt with a kick in the aftertaste-not bad though
very carbonated
Average drinkability. #1 Belgian import lager

overall its an average beer but its not worth the high import cost that you pay for it.

Reviewed on: 03-13-2007 21:53:13

They may have sold out to the masses and maybe altered the taste over the years, who knows, but this is a solid beer that is consistant and always refreshing. It is a golden lager that has a nice light foamy head. The taste and mouthfeel are simple, no off-putting taste, just a nice sweet lager that can be enjoyed anywhere. Stella is a very drinkable brand and they do a very good job on getting the correct glass to serve it in. I’m not a fan of how they do it, but we have to give them credit for getting people to drink better beer, even in the red states, where they would usually drink BUD.

a great beer on a hot summers day. pours a dark  yellow with a white bubbly head and descent lacing. aroma and flavor are a little corn, malt, and a touch of grassy hops. a nice sessionable summer beer.

From a can poured into a Stella Artois glass I use at home. A European Macro, very quaffable, for the masses. Inoffensive Aroma, can smell the  alcohol. Appearance is good, pale straw and very clear good head till the last sip. Flavour is acceptable, nothing to write home about, but easy to put back and smooth. One of the better macro’s.

A pale lager in a fancy bottle. 
 Some skunk and corn, and something along the lines of melon rind. A little odd, but it doesn’t hurt the beer.
 I don’t see myself buying this again; at least not for myself.

Pours clear, golden yellow with a thin white head and very few bubbles moving through. The aroma is of corn-ish pils malt with light grassy hops. The flavor is sweet and like a malt liquor with Sazz hops. Decent for the style, but nothing special. Does however, make macro drinkers think they’re trying a great Belgian beer.
Clean, crisp euro lager. Aroma is subtle noble hop & light clean malt. A nice beer, pretty standard version of the same thing. Nothing between this & every other lager in Australia.

A little better than most of the American made macros, but more expensive. It pours a clear yellow color with a decent white head. The aroma is very weak with some light hints of corn and cardboard. The flavor is sweet corn with a dryer, slightly hoppy finish. Better mouthfeel than most pale lagers.

Pours golden yellow with a decent white head. Actually, it’s the clearest beer I’ve ever seen. Aroma- dry grass, skunky, yeast. Taste- skunky, grassy, a little sweet from the yeast. Light bodied, yet has a bit of depth.

On-tap.

A - Light straw color with a good sized white head.

S - Light and clean with most of the smell being the grainy and grassy slightly sweet Euro Pale Lager smell.

T - Mostly a grainy sweetness along with a bit of grassy flavor. Has a slight hint of tea like bitterness.

M - Light body with decent carbonation. Fairly smooth.

D - Light and easy to drink, like most of the style. Taste isn’t great, but compared to other beers like it not bad.

Notes: It is like other Euro Pale Lagers, made for mass consumption so easy to drink and pretty inoffensive flavor. Compared to other beers like this one, it probably has a slight edge.

Light and heavy carbonated. Skunky and malty. Very malty flavor with a very sour finish. Typical pale lager. Refreshing and delicious. I could drink litres of this stuff. Beer doesn’t have to be complicated to be good.

On draft at Daanens- Pours pale golden with a decent head, aroma is nothing better than your average pale lager. The flavor tastes like an amped up pale lager, very disappointing. This is from Belgium?

0.5 l bottle.

At wolfgang pucks on draft in downtown disney. A bit on the flat side and no head.

Drank it to try and get over my trouble woes.. Trouble is it does not do the trick very well. Makes me feel worse and more angry.. really the taste is strange but the aftertaste on the tounge is very abysmal indeed I must say i cannon stomach another 1 of these.. i guess any beer that makes u feel tripe after 2 cans is no good at all the beer of binge drinkers in uk..
Has a bit of a sweet/bitter taste... not too much though. When I first started drinking beer, it was the first one that I actually liked. Its still good now, but not as great as I remember.

Stella Artois is a very clear, pale golden lager with a foamy white head that has decent retention and lacing.  It has a skunky aroma with notes of grass and lemon.  Yeah, it has the green bottle whiff.  It’s light bodied, pretty watery, prickly and not very smooth.  It leaves the palate a little gritty.  It has a skunky, green bottle flavor.  The best part of the flavor is my burps, which taste a little like noble hops-- maybe Saaz?  Now I remember why I don’t buy this.
on tap. funky and dough and pepper. tastes of pepper and yeast and general funk
Good every-day beer.  Some personality to it!  Better than what Molson and Labatt usually offer in Quebec :)
On tap; OK, an average safe beer. I do like it better on tap as I would rate it lower in bottle. I used to like this when I started drinking beer but now do not enjoy it.
One of the beers that I won’t buy again. It’s barely drinkeable. When I’m realy thirsty, and there is nothing else around... maybe I’ll put it in my mouth again.
draft, pours light gold, thin white head.  Skunky aroma with some hay.  Thin adjunct and grassy flavors ending with a metalic taste.  Eh.
For a pale lager, Stella Artois is average. It will beat out the terrible American macrobrews, but there just isn’t much here to judge.

12 ounce bottle from Whole Foods Market in Charlottesville, VA. Pours a light golden color with a thin head. Poor head retention and lacing. Aroma of grassy hops with an acrid almost meaty note. Taste is acrid grainy malts and grassy hops. Watery and thin. Poor beer.
Stella and I are friends.  Not the hreatest ever, but it will beat out any of the macrobrews anyday.

Nice golden yellow color. Bright white head. Aroma of citrus light hop sweet and a hint of dirty socks. Light bodied with a sweet grain taste. Bitter finish. A crisp beer. Just because it comes from Belgium doesn’t mean it has to be good, and this is a perfect example. Although the flavor varies, it is about average for a mass produced beer.

For being Belgian I was disappointed.  Usually I like anything from Belgium. But this beer didn’t smell or taste good to me. I’d drink it again if it were to be handed to me but I wouldn’t go out of my way to drink it. Not a whole lot to say about this one.

On tap at the Ten O’ One Club.  Clear pale yellow color with foamy white head.  Aroma is of light malt and grass with light notes of fruit.  Taste much the same with a pinch of Belgian hop spiciness.  Not sure why all the hate on this one, pretty drinkable and not a bad choice.

We have this on tap and in the bottles a lot. Nose is slightly skunky as you would expect from this style. Yeast flavor is most prominant with a fresh cheese aroma. Overall a good beer for meals when you don’t want to taste only the beer.

I have had this on draft and refrigerated bottle.  Aroma is skunky from bottle and pretty good on draft.  This beer is smooth and refreshing.  Pours a clear pale golden color with a little white head.  Taste is simple balanced barley and hops.
It holds true to the fact that it has a variety of flavor and refreshing taste, but it doesn’t really leave much to the palate. Smooth and refreshing.

From bottle pours a clear golden color, almost no aroma, has a thin white head. Mild aroma of malt. Taste of malt and has a light bitterness. Thin mouthfeel. Good for a pale lager. Very easy to drink. This is what Budweiser wishes it could be
Bottle. Golden colour with a small white head. Malty aroma with a hint of hops. The flavour is malty with some fruits, slightly bitter and sweet. Mouthfeel is very smooth. Good pale lager.

Pours a pale golden color with a white head and lots of carbonation.The aroma is a light malt and hops.The flavor is a light malt and a refreshing taste.The mouthfeel is almost creamy.The finnsh is a little metallic.Overall it’s better than most pale lagers.

A decent drink.  330 ml. bottle to lager glass.  Pours golden with thin, light white head that is quickly gone.  Initial impression is fruit and bread.  Very smooth in the mouth, but just a bit thin.  A nice balanced bitter sweet taste.  Finish is dry.  Good for mass production.

[1/10] Gold, white head out of central casting. Sweet malt and mild noble hops. Bland malt sweetness and decent balancing bitterness. Perfectly acceptable but without any particular charm. [2.7]

[7/11]Don’t think I’m harder on this sort of thing than I used to be, but just seems slightly worse every time. Malts seem increasingly cheap. Still has a lovely head. [2.5]

[4/18] Can. UK version from Aldi, bb 9/18. Smells like carpet cleaner. Tastes like they didn't even spring for the expensive cardboard. Bitterness and appearance still OK.

330ml green bottle

Pours a gold color, with about a one inch foam head.
I find this beer to be very smooth, it goes down very easy. I’ve had this beer a few times, and have always enjoyed it. I was a bit hesitant with this one because of the green bottle, but it came in a set with a pretty cool glass.
I find this to be a great beer on a hot summer day.

330ml bottle. Poured a pale light amber colour with a modest thin white head. Clear, clean and thin looking with an aroma of malt and hops that is quite bland and basic. Tastes a little better than it looks and smells, not much though. Sudsy taste that leaves a bitter aftertaste . Not as premium as it is advertised to be.

Slight aroma. Pours a clear golden colour. Thin white head when served in a lager glass that does not last long. Moderately carbonated. Has a bitter taste. Not a bad beer for one so readily available.

Like Corona and Heineken, the palate is dominated by bitterness and not much else. The funny thing is that I can tolerate this beer on some occasions, but if my palate has gotten some exercise (for example with wine or good beer) Stella comes of quite bitter and unenjoyable.
Served from a 22 oz bottle while on travel in Port Hueneme. Pours a nice clear medium gold. The aromas and flavors are crisp pilsner malts, and grape flavors. A decent beer.

I bought this because I like green bottles.  It’s good for pale lager, and I enjoy the clean crisp taste that has a bit of hops.  High carbonation.  A guy I know that’s more of an expert refered to it as the "Keystone Light" of Belgiun beers.  I don’t think it’s that bad.  I could drink a case of these.

11.2 oz bottle. Strong skunk odor, hay. Pours golden with minimal head, nice lacing, small bubbles. Taste is kind of sweet. Medium-bodied. Finishes with a slight bitterness. I used to think Belgium could do no wrong in the brewing world. Then I came across this beer.

On draught at a local eatery. Pours a yellow/gold color with a thin white head. Aroma is white bread, grass and/or grains. Thin bodied palate with just enough carbonation to tickle the tongue. Flavor is ever so slightly sweet with hints of malt mixed in with grain and corn. Slight bitterness to the finish. Better than Bud.
Yellow with a fragmented head. Aroma of corn, hay and caramel. Sweet hay-like flavours, a bit of grass and a metallic hoppy ending.

In NY from a bottle.  A bit of citrus and then grass, hay and toast.  Light golden color with frothy head.  Light and a bit bitter.  Short and thin finish.  Easy to drink.  Not exciting but better than average (and reliable) daily beer.
Bottle. Clear orange with nice creamy head. Aromas whilst rather subdued are slightly floral. Flavours are very thin. Finish is slightly dry and bitter. OK beer.

This is a beer that i drink and dont hate...but there is nothing special in the body, taste, palte or mouthfeel. Its not horrible it just doesnt bring anything exciting to the table. Did drink a lot of it in Greece :).

330ml bottle. Straw pale gold hue, nice but quickly diminishing white frothy head, minimal lacing. Faint aromas of biscuit, cereal, grain, grass, hay.  Short light sweetness, quickly followed by dry bitterness, slightly sour. Very dry after-taste, fizzy carbonation, thin watery texture. I used to really like this beer but that was when all I had to compare to was NZ mass produced beers, still this is one of the better "regular beers" that is on offer, though that isn’t saying much.
Thick creamy head. Clean finish with floral almost citrusy hint. Very consistent and drinkable. Nice overall. Buy it on sale.

(draught at Tommy’s in Middletown CT)



^light-body and taste, §hop-bitterness, watery, 

drink only as a water substitute

This is what I used as my bar to compare other beers (better than Stella was a decent/good beer. Worse than Stella was a disappointing beer). By all means a standard euro-lager. Good carbonation, thin body, and a touch of sulfur. Prominent steel flavour. Overall it’s refreshing and adequate when there’s nothing else on offer... even if it doesn’t live up to its ’Belgian’ reputation (at least when consumed outside of Belgium). I’ve tried more entertaining lagers since, though.
Bottle. Poured pale yellow with a thick white head. Aroma had notes of sweet malts and some grain and cereal. Flavor was sweet with a somewhat unpleasant metallic taste.

This is the beer you drink when there is only macro brewed American swill lagers.  In the same mold as Pilsener Urquell, just not as tasty.  Bready and yeasty in flavor, this rare Belgium lager is soft and mild.  I could drink these all day long, but then again, why the hell would I?  I guess even in Belgium, there are "men" who are afraid of flavor.  Not a bad beer, but not a top notch one either.

Poured from a can into a tulip. Dense and durable white head. Smells really delicate, floral, over a malty base. Easy to drink, very refreshing. A good pale lager, but not different from so many others.

Poured a clear, pale yellow with a small white head. Mild aroma and taste: watered down malt & hops with a faint bitterness. Overall... it’s a pale lager - not a style I enjoy anymore.  
Re-rate: Had this again not too long ago.... not a good beer. This is better than Coors, Bud etc... but so what?
Yellow with white head. Mild aroma of floral/grassy hops. Decent malt balanced by some bitterness. Solid pale lager. Nothing exciting, but quite drinkable.
Tap. Not bad for a pale lager. Aroma is citrusy, with floral notes. Flavour is bitter, and it has good length. Thin body, and oily in the palate. Yellow colour, with a fizzy head that disappears.

33cL can in France somewhere.
Standard sort of pale Euro lager. Quite clean, bit drier on the finish than most, possibly a bit more body too, but unremarkable on the whole.
Unremarkable beer.  Doesn’t taste like anything.  Not bad tasting at all but not memorable either.  A day later, I can’t remember any flavors that stuck out.

(draught 0,5l) (1.11.2009)

Hops aroma. Clear golden color. Large white head. Medium sweet, light sour. Oily texture. Bitter finish. (4.4.5.3..11=2.7)


(bottle 0,5l) (6.12.2017)

Aroma: Grainy, corny.

Appearance: Clear golden color. Minimal, white head.

Taste: Light sweet, corny, grainy. 

Palate: Light-medium body. 

Overall: Meh. (4.3.4.3..9=2.3)
Funny story: Front label 2x mention Belgium. Neck label 1x Belgium. Back label: packed in Staropramen CZ, brewed in Hungary :)

Bottle at The Tin Can in Nashville, and everywhere else, but that’s the last place I had it.  Meant to rate this one earlier, but by the time I remembered it (today), I didn’t want to waste my 400th rating on it.  Anyway, pours a clear pale yellow gold with a large, even white head.  Aroma of grain, yeast, light hops, malt.  Flavor follows suit.  LIght bodied.  Not much here, except that it’s a little better than most other Euro macros and their American counterparts, so I have it rated a bit higher than most other pale lagers.  Woo-hoo.

Poured from tap into tall glass.

Very pale yellow with thin head and slight lacing.

Mostly sweet grain aroma, almost like corn (even though there is no corn). Some notes of apple and slight hops as well.

Sweet and grainy malts in the forefront. Nice noble hops provide counterbalance and provide a spicy, somewhat bitter finish. Too bad the malts are so weak.

Moderately high carbonation, light body, semi-dry finish.

Easy drinking, which is complemented by the nice hops. However, those sweet grainy (almost corn-like) malts really are a detriment.

Definitely sells more because of its status instead of its taste - the new Heineken. While a decent beer, it amazes me that people think drinking this beer proves they have discerning taste. Typical lager for snobs.
Bottle served with glass at Peppes, Stavanger. Pale yellow body. Thick white head. Typical lager-bitterness with an extra punch in the aftertaste.

Bottle. Clear straw with white head.  Aroma is dry lager yeast and some grain.  Flavor is similar to the aroma with a little more chalk and some breadiness.   Light, well carboNated body.  Overall a pretty standard European lager that I find to be a little bit more refreshing than some.
Great pale lager - rich taste, very similiar to some Czech lagers. A favorite one.
Another of the old favorites, that are not up to date. In the begining this lager was brewed in Sweden i.e not imported

Pours a pale gold with a pure white head that dissipates quickly. Nose is hops and alcohol. Creamy on the palate. Taste is clean, crisp, lightly hopped, not overly flavorful. Stella pairs well with ham and cheese or nuts/pretzels.

Nostalgia definately makes some beers taste better.  Bottle pours gold with a soapy white head.  Aroma smells of bread and grass.  Flavor is basically the same and finishes dry.  Good to have in the refrigerator to keep people from "experimenting" on my better brews.
Golden with white head, leaves lacing to the bottom of the glass - tastes of malt and some bitterness - overall an ok beer
Clear, lively, light body. Good lager. A good beer to have around the house.
Typical pale lager, slightly bitter, with a decent bite for aftertaste. Extremely overrated, barely drinkable.
Probably the best lager around indeed. No chemicals added to much surprise. Great unique taste.
Decent beer. I’m not one much for lagers, but when I do reach for a mass-produced lager, it’s Stella.

Weak tasting, barely pops on the tongue. Tastes overly fizzy with little heartiness. The color is runny yellow, and is pretty indicitive of the flavor. Stella goes down crisply, but strikes me as entirely average.
Decent Macro, but nothing special. Nice balance and refreshing. Interbrew has put this beer everywhere.
Can. Another pilsner beer, not sweet luckily, slightly hoppier than a lot of other pilners. Good thirstquenching pilsner.
Skunky smell, bold taste with a very bitter aftertaste.  Used to be a favourite before I got introduced that there were more beers than macros.

Re-rate: 4.5 to 5 after another glorious
Draught at  Yankee Stadium 
Stella, I love you
One of my favorites!, very hoppy spicy smell, spicy kick to the flavor as well, golden colored with a thin head. Smells a bit like greenery/grass when first opened.

Above average lager. Grassy/straw aroma, more flavour than one would usually expect to find in a lager, though not by much. mainly cereal flavours with a hint of hops. gets your attention at first, but loses it’s appeal very quickly. i always find the mouthfeel slightly oily or syrupy.
Overall it’s acceptable, and when i have to choose a macro-lager, this is usually it.
Nice golden yellow color. Much different taste but one that tastes great on draft. Nice refreshment after a long day. Worth the price.

Bottle pour, thin white head, very clear, light golden yellow color. Slightly skunky, a bitterness that is not strong, but hangs around. Aromas and flavors are a little sweet, with some light malt and bitter hops accents. A slight aftertaste, that is strangely refreshing. 
I have always liked this brew....something a little different than Heineken when I’m out at the bar....I really like it on draft.
pretty dull in taste and aroma. Not much there to be honest, You only get a small hint of hop.

Yellow colour with small, disappearing white head. Not much aroma and even less taste. When I say that it had no taste I really mean it. Most tasteless beers (such as the big American names) have a little taste, which is usually offensive. This has less taste but it is not so offensive. A small hint of hops in the mouth and nose is all you get here. So it doesn’t actually taste bad it just doesn’t taste of much at all. I won’t recommend it but it is cheap and better than most international pale lagers.
Nothing truly special -- in the same league as Coors light & Budweiser.
I think everyone finally realized that Stella is just a Belgian silver bullet.  It has all the same qualities of an American Light.
Bottle. Pale coluor, skunky aroma. Grassy hops in taste. Standard euro lager

Pretty bad, cheap-tasting lager.  In my opinion, Stella Artois is about on par with most American macro lagers.  There’s very little to recommend it.  The color is a pale, drab yellow.  The small white head dissipates very quickly.  There’s little aroma, except for a muted cheap malt note, overly sweet and more reminiscent of corn than barley, although I don’t believe that adjuncts are used.  The flavor is similarly dominated by a cheap, overly sweet malt flavor.  There are some hops in there, I guess.  The beer is not entirely without crispness when cold.  Still, the feel is rather thin, even for a lager probably based on a pilsner style.  Overall, I’m not a fan of Stella.  The flavor is unclean, which is a pretty big problem for me in a light lager.

Sour metallic vinegar veneer quickly gives way to boisterously cloying  finish which remains acidic but with an off-putting syrupy sweetness reminiscent of over-fermented apples. Strong sour chemical sensation throughout, including morning after. The headiness of the alcohol is apparent from the first taste which isn’t a good sign. Actually it tastes even more alcoholic than it is. Not a very enjoyable  drink- Aggressively marketed;  Expensive, and not reassuringly so.

Stella. Drink all the time if it’s on tap. In the last few years has become an american staple. My fallback beer. Sweet, grassy, malty and better then other macro alternatives. If I am at a bar I will take this over a yuengling unless of course they have specialties or seasonal’s.
Poured pale yellow, slight skunk, clean, smooth, grassy, little malty, little grainy.
Bottle. Boring but not disturbingly bad pale lager. KInd of like the smell of it, it´s a bit more hoppy than your standard pale lager.

11.2 oz bottle.  Pours a pale yellow color with a small white quickly vanishing head.  It has a crisp hop aroma along with a skunky smell.  It has a roasted taste and also tastes of hay, cereal and grass. This is a OK beer in my opinion.
it is straw yellow with no head. smell is skunky grain, very light. taste is skunky, a tiny bit smoky.
Light golden color, has a decent big belgian brewer lager flavor.  Drinkable, goes down smooth with some euro flavor.

Drinkabily and refreshing.
The bitterness level is so palatable, and it’s not too so fizzy.
Vague taste of malt.
A nice, clean Belgian lager.  I’m not a huge light lager fan, but this is eminently drinkable.

Not sure how I missed rating this one earlier, but here goes.  Went to a club for my friend’s going away party and asked what beers they had.  Bud, Miller, Coors, Stella, and Heineken.  Awesome, way to cover a broad range of styles!  So Stella on tap ended up being my drink of choice for the night, as crazy as that may sound, and I downed 5-6 of them out of clear plastic cups that look like they were made for beirut/beer pong &#40club didn’t have a table unfortunately&#41.  I love how some people who don’t know anything about beer will see BMC and say something like, "I don’t drink that terrible piss water!  I like the good stuff, like Stella!" not realizing their knowledge of "beer" is limited to pale lagers and maybe Guinness.  Some people will never learn.  Oh well, anyway, this beer is golden-yellow with a white head.  Looks a little better than an American adjunk lager.  Aroma is pale malt, grain, corn, and some mild noble hops.  Flavor is pretty bland and similar to the aroma.  Has a cleaner and stronger taste than BMC &#40although that’s not saying much&#41 with slightly more hops to it.  Palate is light with medium-high carbonation.  Not terribly offensive, but still one of the worst true Belgian beers I’ve ever had.

Out of the bottle the aroma is skunk, and so is the flavor mixed with light grains and corn.  On tap the skunk is gone &#40thankfully!&#41 and you taste more of the clean grain with a touch of hops on the finish. &#40my rating is based moreso on the tap version&#41

Obviously I didn’t buy this. Seriously guys, someone gave it to me. I didn’t spend money on it. A bit skunked, surprise surprise. Probably improved it a bit for me in reality. Overcarbonated even for the style. Rather crisp. Cleaner than most, still not that clean.
&#40bottle&#41. Clear gold color. Small white head. Light grain aroma and flavor. Avg duration. Thin texture. Moderate carbonation. Fair lacing.
Smells watery, tastes watery, no distinctiveness, no flavor, no sophistication. Awful.
Not bad overall, good for summer drinking, reminiscent of Heinie and some German mass-lagers so at least there isn’t adjuncty nonsense.  Compare to Warsteiner, which I think I rated the same as this.
Bottle, Honolulu. A little skunky, but it still goes down smooth, kind of. It is a good after work beer or with some light food

IT has this reputation of being a bad beer but this is in fact quite a classy beer. do not be decieved this is good stuff and wont necessarily make u angry.. it really has that rep coz its called stella more than anything else.. tastes unique with good drinkability.

Honestly, this isn’t that bad. Has a faint spicy hop aroma, with some malty cereal aroma to id. Flavor is crisp, malty and light with just a touch of spicy saaz hop bitterness. Clean palate. Good beer if you’re looking for a lager
Horrifying in a bottle due to the green but actually quite good on tap. What Budweiser could be with some effort. Premium generally not worth paying unless its the best thing on tap.

In a word: crisp. Highly carbonated, this beer pours a pale gold with a foamy bubbly head. Has a slightly bitter taste, even a little metallic - but in a good way. Feels very active in your mouth. Has a lingering aftertaste. Not too bad and almost always available.

Unfortunately I will sometimes suffer from “lager prejudice” - the prejudicial fear of lackluster lagers which I then presume applies to all lagers. This is not always the case, of course, but it can be easy to forget when one has been scarred so many times by lager mediocrity. Stella Artois from InBev is a double dose of “lager prejudice” because she is what I would classify as a macro import lager and, better yet, owned and distributed by the largest corporate conglomerate in the world of beer ownership and distribution. I would be speaking of InBev, of course, those feisty Belgians who most recently bought Anheiser Bush for a few gazillion dollars. In the international world of corporate beer, InBev is loathed even more than Anheiser Bush.




She poured a lovely crystal clear golden yellow with a rocky white head which resembled the white caps splashing my face during my virgin Stella Artois voyage a few years ago. A delicate scattering of lace clings to the sides of my glass. Bright and playful, lemon and lime tease while soft white breads, rolls, and orange blossoms perfume the air. Sweet lemon drops transport me further back in time, and I remember why I enjoyed this lager so much. My first quaff has a soft yet bright mouthfeel and a short finish that refuses to linger long; apparently, she has better things to do then to hang out with me. Lemon cream with a spritz of key lime tickles from start to finish while soft white breads and rolls, home-made and not the store-bought wonder bread kind, and green grass gleams under a layer of morning dew. Great balance and extreme quaffability along with no bitter aftertaste and an honorable Belgian lager palate makes Stella Artois a winner in my book, and thousands of others, too.




You can lament and deride InBev as much as you want and more often than not for good reason, but before InBev bought the rights to Stella Artois, she was already a winner in her home country of Belgium. I can’t say if her palate or recipe has changed any, though I would imagine it has. To be able to meet the sheer quantity her mass production requires for domestic and export consumption, there will always be some change. Stella Artois gets a bright passing grade from me.

This beer has a lot of carbonation and is semi-hazy in color with a moderate sized head. The taste to me was actually sour and was not enjoyable to say the least. I found it disgusting and will likely never try it again. Not recommended.
Bottle. Golden pour with a thin, frothy, white head. Brown sugary sweet malts on the nose. This bottle’s pretty skunky. I’m going to finish it, though.

Overrated pilsener; it’s a bit better than Budweiser, Coors, and other popular lagers, quite a bit more expensive, and still very boring.  It has more aroma to it than its competitors - a blessing or a curse depending on your tastes.  This is pretty much all that distinguishes it.
Really dull/faint aroma with a minimal-to-no head.  Golden pour with light carbonation.  Nose is fairly clear with a hint of hops on the edges of the tongue in the aftertaste.
Well I am set to say that i pretty much hate this beer. Looks generic and has no aroma to speak of. Taste was plain except for a terrible after taste like burnt rubber. May you burn in hell InBev
For a beer that is served everywhere in america, i was a little let down by the taste.  Very pale, light flavor stifled by the intense carbonation.  Unimpressed by overall experience.
On tap at the Crown and Tower. Clear yellow pour with a rich, white foam. Aroma is faint hops and malt. Finish is bland, but drinkable. Fairly refreshing summer lager.

As a fan of Lagers I think this one is overrated...Not much better than the macro pee....now I must admit if I could find it for $8.50 a case like superdude1979 below I would buy it and push it on "friends"
Pours pale gold with a medium sized white head.  Nose is a little skunky.  Taste is mild hop biiterness.  This is basically not that much different from most macrobrew pale lagers.

Not much special here. I got a case on sale for $10, and then I was able to use a coupon for an additional $1.50 off. This beer is always so expensive and I don’t really know why. Pours a nice golden color, easy on the palate, no aftertaste or any sort of flavour. Not as watered down as American Macro swill, but no real flavor. Not worth what they charge.
0.5L can. Pours straw yellow. Faint grass aroma. Slight malt flavour. Not good, but definitely drinkable. One of the better of the ubiquitous macro lagers.

This is awful and I don’t know what they put into it and how much longer they can continue to sell this tripe but simply a rubbish lager which taskes a bit like Kronenbourg 1664. If you have any sense you shall not be drinking ’Wife Beater’ as this gets you off your head and will make you regret stuff you’ve done and the hangover is not much better.

Overall Impression: I’ve always thought of this beer as being a little overrated, but not on here, it seems the rest of the RateBeerians agree that it is pretty mediocre.  It’s not bad for what it is, and it’s better then most of its competition, like Heineken, so it has that going for it, but overall it’s just a dull but drinkable Pale Lager.

Tastes a lot like Heineken, but a little less skunky and a little drier. Barely perceptable fruit aftertaste which is kind of interesting. I paid $2.25 for a bottle of this, I think it was overpriced. Also bottle is 11.2oz, not 12oz. $6.99 for a six pack would be more in line. Aroma is weak. Also I think it could use a touch more carbonation. Overall a pretty decent lager for a hot summer day. Not too sweet, not too bitter. But I’m disappointed with the price and the bottle should be 12oz! If you like PBR, and I certainly do, but you would like to pay 3 times as much for it, check this one out!

I don’t see how they (the brewer) can call this Belgium’s best, there are a myriad of better ones from Belgium.  It is really only a "nice" average beer, with an adequate head which left some lacing and the slightly hopped and malted aroma - taste was much the same.  Colour was a clear yellow gold.  An upmarket swill.  Good TV adverts, though!
Poura very pale golden colour. Very light malty aroma and a light malt and hop taste.  Nice dry finish.  Good session beer.

Slightly more complex lager than usual, nice dryness with taste of hops, grains - good mouthfeel. A better choice for a macrobrew. 4.4.7.4.13.
Re-rate March 2016, about 6.5 years later, a late saturday night, one left in the fridge, thought I’d check my rating and whattadaya know this one really deserves a little more attention after so much of a little while. Another country, another continent, a bottle found in wherever with I hope a little more attention paid to than the last one I had done tried way back in 2 zero-zero nine. It pours with a good head, reasonable creaminess, okay golden body with some carbonation but not too heavy. Aroma is soft cardboard and hops, not disgusting, but just typical. Very, very, typical and uninteresting. The flavour is a lot of forgettable lager, no taste really, with a vague dry hop finish. Oh, this one doesn’t age well - after all my journeys into Belgium this macro beer just does not measure up, it’s a boring lager that insults the great brewing traditions of that country. Drinkable in a pinch, but a real snoozefest to be sure.

Considering that this beer is 20 euro cents per 25cl bottle you can’t expect too much of the flavour and Stella pretty much delivers on those expectations.
However in my opinion it is refreshing and significantly better than many of its other rivals.

Transparent with a pale golden yellow color. Smells pasteurized and almost skunky. Crisp and light in flavor. Not as boring as say a Bud Light but not as refreshing either. It does have surprisingly good lacing as other reviewers have pointed out. Probably the worst Belgian beer I’ve ever had. In my opinion, it’s not worth drinking.
Pours a straw color body and a white head with legs.  Smells clean and skunky.  Flavor is crisp, malt, and some skunk.

330 ml bottle. Finland.
Pale golden colour with thin white head.
Slightly hoppy and malty aroma. Malty flavour with touch of hoppiness. Not bad for a Pale Lager.

Pours a golden yellow color with a two inch white head.  The smell is very skunky and a little hoppy.  Taste of yeast, a bunch of carbonation, and a suprising finish.  One of the better pale lagers I’ve had.

Very Clear pale straw pour with a white quick settling head. Somewhat cheesy nose very little floral (rose) and some corn. Clean dry feel with some tingle left on the tongue. Taste is bitter with a sweet finish.

The beer’s nickname is WifeBeater... enough said.  It’s on tap everywhere, always tastes the same... filtered and pasteurized, pours perfectly clear and yellow.  High carbonation, no lacing, skunky aroma and taste.

Ah Stella. I’ve got a bottle of the stuff in one hand and a Ricard and water in the other. Brings back sweet memories of the Loire; the heat, the storms, the flies and the slow decent into a semi-psychotic state. I’m drinking this on an empty stomach to so Rock ’n’ Roll!. A friend at work describe Stella as like drinking petrol. That’s a bit harsh. I like it’s grain-edge and its, "I’m about to pass out", body. Long live Stella.
Golden appearance with a bit of a skunky aroma. High carbonation so it doesn’t go down as smooth as some other beers but is still very refreshing. One of the better lagers out there.
Pours a pale yellow.  Aroma of yeast.  Strong bitter, pungent flavor of yeast.
Basic pale lager with it’s color and head. Good lacing was suprising. Kind of sweet with a bite at the end. Crisp beer. It wasn’t a drain pour but nothing to write home about.
pours a loight golden color with some fizzy head, no lacing. fairly high carbonation, but overall it is a well balanced beer, nice and crisp with a light/sweet finish.

I have had from a bottle, and on tap in Belgium.

Ok, head nothing great, kinda fluffy.

Aroma- skunky

Color is straw, normal color.  

Taste is very bland and skunky. One of my least favorite beers.

As everyone else has said, this beer is skunky. I completely agree. Nice fluffy head, but the beer looks straw like in color, just like every other pale lager. I like darker pale lagers. Slight pilsner aroma/taste, but other than that, there is nothing much to this beer. Not a bad texture I must say. 22 oz. bottle from Greens on Ponce De Leon.
anyone smell that? oh yeah, its skunk alright. if you can get past that lovely aroma, its not bad, for 2 or 3.......
Smelled a bit skunky, and tasted so as well, with some breadiness.  Overall not bad, but I wasn’t reaching for another after finishing.

My work had a little get together and someone picked up a sixer of this.  I was surprised to see I hadn’t had it yet.  I was pleasantly surprised.  Crisp, skunky taste with a refreshing finish.  Not too bad at all.
Pale yellow with a thick white head. Skunky aroma. The flavor was kind of malty with just a bit of bitterness to balance it out. Not too bad.

Tap. Pale amber pour with a small white head.
Bread aroma with some grainy malt. Very faint (lacking). Some light grassy hops.
Plain bready flavour, again with a tiny hint of grassy hops.
Light body. Reasonable.

Bottle.  Pours a crystal clear pale yellow color topped by an inch thick, rocky white head that slowly settled to a thin head and left some spotty lacing.  Aroma of pilsner malt, a light graininess, dough/bread, and some light grassy hops.  Smooth, crisp entry with some light maltiness and light hints of dough that transitions into a a light fruitiness (orange) paired with some soft, grassy hops that linger into a lightly bitter finish that reveals faint hints of sweet honey.  Soft carbonation and light, prickly mouth feel.  Overall, a non-offensive lager that is pretty dang drinkable and seems to avoid that overt skunkiness present in many foreign pale lagers.  Not bad.

Stella is great! Always reliable and never on the shelf long enough for the cursed green bottle effect. Poured out the usual large white rocky head the is retained just above beer level. Ample messy lacing, nice bright clear gold colour. The first smell that hits is lemon followed by bready malts, grains and low floral scents. Always has a faint skunk but I’m used to it in this style so no biggie. Taste is always refreshing but never exciting. Grains, slight fruit, middle to end bready malts and average bitterness. Light to light medium bodied. Smoothly carbonated. Goes down smooth and dry with little bit of bitter / dull aftertaste. Probally nearer to average than I rated it but tough titties.

One of the best on the market. The aroma is pleasant and comes nowhere close to the skunkiness that might be first expected when considering its competitors. The coloration is a light golden, topped off by an adequate yet unobtrusive head and fine carbonation. Possessing one of the most balanced flavors around, this beer is remarkably consistent in first impression and finish, and is amazinlgy and refreshingly balanced between sweet and bitter, with neither malts nor hops overtaking one another in the overall character of the beer.
belguim i love you i plan to visit this brewerey if i can and i tell im never leaving

Pour from a 12oz bottle. Golden color with two fingers of white head that slowly dissipates, leaving ample lacing in the glass. Aroma of weak malt dominated by hops. Very well balanced flavor with a fine maltiness at the start and excellent hops smack in the finish. 


Sometimes my slack and sleeping senses require the thunder and fireworks of ales, stouts, and craft brews. But the voice of fine brewing speaks gently… and it speaks here.
Pours a golden yellow, with okay head.  Aroma is of grass and skunkiness.  Flavor was very bitter with a skunky aftertaste that turned my taste buds. Overall a very light in taste and quality beer.

Aroma - light grass, skunky. Appearance - Clear golden with a medium head that dissipates quickly. Flavor - grass, skunk, light sweetness, light bitterness. Palate - light body, thin feel, lively. Overall - A nice refreshing beer that is light on taste. Not the best of beers but good for what it is.

Enjoyed from a 12oz bottle in a pub glass.  Pours a light golden to medium yellow color with a relatively fluffy white head.  The nose gives notes of malt sweetness, but only to a limited extent.  On more than one occasion, I’ve gotten a skunked sample due to the Germans and Belgians’ mis-guided choice to put their beers in green bottles.  On its best day, the nose is ultimately slight, but not wholly inappropriate for the style.  The palate is thin, but does give some notes of what one would expect from the "Premium Lager" style.  Pilsner malt sweetness and a touch of hop flavor (and I do mean a touch) come through as the most recognizable flavors.  The finish seems to be almost right in the middle between sweet and dry.  Overall, a good example of the aforementioned style, but don’t buy the advertising, it still pretty much sucks.
hay, grass, leaves, clove, skunky, pale, clear, white foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium sourness, paper napkin, thin feel, average carbonation, bitter,

I don’t understand the hype of this beer, every where you go you see signs hanging from the out side of bars advertising they have Stella WHOOPTY FUCKING DO!!! This beers popularity is based on being over priced and the fact its served fancy glass people think they’re drinking some fancy import that they hope will impress the local bar stars (sluts). Don’t get me wrong this is not a bad tasting beer it has a nice golden colour a nice white head and a sweet grassy aroma. The taste isn’t watered down and its quit refreshing, its just not worth the insane amount you pay for it. I guess I have to give this beer a good ranking because its not swill its just way over priced, and that’s the only reason its so popular. Good job marketing team!

Extremely overrated, though nowhere near repulsive. Points deducted because it’s a ripoff in Australia, and it’s fucking brewed here! sneaky bastards... Quite a bit of flavour for a lager, smells decent, would’nt go nuts for it. Buy it if it’s on special, otherwise spend your $55 on something truly worth it.

Clear yellow with a medium foamy head with average retention and minimal lacing. Aroma is sweet malt and herbal hops. Flavor is also sweet malt, a little too sweet for my liking of the style and herbal hops. Thin body with a watery mouthfeel.

Pours from the tap a very clear, golden color with a fizzy, small head that leaves low lacing.  Aroma is heavy of pils malt that leads to a very grainy note with light Noble hop aroma. Flavor is very grainy with a light honey sweetness in there, some mineral notes present as well.  The flavor is crisp and clean.  Overall a LOT better from the tap if you can find it, no skunky flavor and the pils and light hop spice really play well together.
My favorite swill. Pretty neutral aroma and, for that matter, flavor.. but it goes down smooth with no fuss. Not nearly as skunky as most also-ran American lagers.
Typical european green bottle pilsener. skunky hops and light sweet malt. Flavor is much the same.
Fine pils, refreshing, well-balanced, with a rich, chewy aftertaste with no bitterness. Hints of sweetness and cereals.

decent pale lager... usually the best thing on tap at your average club/bar. 

head is large and white also has nice aroma.  I’ll take it over your average economy beer in a pinch.

Bottle from Beer Frog Spring Hill.  Pours a clear pale yellow with a white receding head.  Nose is pale and maybe pilsner malts with a floral, slightly grassy bitterness.  Flavor is big pale malt with grainy character, floral hops, and lively carbonation.  Light in body and maltier than I expected.
Partial to this for some reason, dunno really why.  Maybe its the fact that you get to rip paper before drinking this one.
Eh just a middle of the road pale lager. Nothing really stands out about it, but it is still way better than the average American macro lager. LC
Drinkable....taste and aroma were not particularly noteworthy...it is what it is...

Draft. Good-looking frothy white head that diminishes. Pale yellow, clear body. The aroma is initially sharp with grainy malts and toast with a note of herbal hops and a hint of canned corn. The flavor is lightly to moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes much the same way, though slightly more bitter. Medium body, watery texture and lively carbonation. More flavor than most macros and with a little pils kind of bite, but only a little. I didn’t know until the bill came that the restaurant  charged $6.50. Maybe it was the Stella glass that drove up the price because it  wasn’t the beer. Can I say "sucker"?
very clear yellow color with foamy head. Smells a little stale, like the inside of a dive bar. Light grainy flavor, bitter almost waxy finish. Average, beer-y beer.
A solid lager with a crisp, refreshing taste and a pleasant if largely subtle aroma.
Draught.  Pours a light gold/dark yellow with decent sized white head.  Overly sweet aroma with malt and bread notes.  Grain prominent in flavour with bit of malt.  Meh.
Grassy nose, Poured a pale golden color, with a pure white head. Skunky, with a thin mouth feel. Poor after taste. After nearly 700 years, you’d think they’d figure out the green bottle issue.
Pretty good,grassy hop,probably the best Pale-Lager that i ever had,crispy grainy taSte, loads of white head, a nice surprise!

Bottle.  Appearance per the picture to your left.  Also it never left the bottle, just how it happened to be served.  Drinks like a light grain with a hint of malt, but overall this is water.  Dam near devoid of flavor or aroma but hell you think bud has drinkability this shit is off the charts i put down 3 like a bottles of water after running may have to rethink this one as a go to lawnmower beer.  Based on this rating system i would have to destroy this beer but heck i found a purpose for it.
golden yellow pour with light foamy and moderately carbonated head.  hoppy and grainy with a sound mouth feel. clean finishing.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a light gold color with a medium, foamy, white head.  Light grain notes in the nose with a hint of hops.  Medium-high carbonation with a light mouthfeel.  Notes of grain and a bit of citrus on the palate.  Perhaps lemon?  Short, clean finish and otherwise unremarkable.  You can certainly do worse in this category.

bottle, golden/yellow  colour, nice white head fastly fading away. Sweet, hoppy, watery, grainy, flowery. Boring beer with an artificial taste. This may be the most commercial pilsener in Belgium. It’s definitely not the best one. A drinkable boring pils.

Bottle, Golden color with a large white head. Aroma of sweet malt with a hint of hops. Flavor continues with more sweet malt/grain with a quick bitter finish.
Good Euro larger (Belgium Brewed OK
Australian version... watered down.
Bottle from Six Plates.  Been awhile since I’ve had this one.  Pretty uninteresting.  Pours light clear gold.  Mild hops and sweet pale malts.  Bit of corn.  Watery.  A bit metallic.
Draft pour. Clear golden color with thin white head. Mild malt aroma, kind of soapy. Flavor was pale malts with a slight hop tinge and a smooth finish. Decent beer.
A good beer that’s not filling like some beers. Goes down smooth with no bitter taste. And for an imported beer the price is right.
The beer has a light hop smell and in see through in appearance.  Overall a good tasting lager and it is served in a cool cup.
Good after a meal of Top-Ramen noodles and a string cheese. Relatively cheap. I like turtles.

Of beers commonly on tap at a lot of restaurants... a go to beer since the InBev-Budweiser merger.  It is light in hop aroma, pale with foam head as white as the paper they rap around the neck. Doesn’t appear great but is crisp carbonated and somewhat flavorful. Great palate and very refreshing. taste a hint of lemon.
lighty hop aroma,pale, clear, white foam, lightly bitter, light sweetness, zest,medium body, average carbonation,
Drinkable, refreshing, but dull and boring. Not a great beer. High carbonation, and a little on the watery side.
Yeasty, skunky golden yellow with white head.  Flavour is corn, malt bitter and funk.  Better than it’s Asian counterparts, but best left in the cooler at the store.
Light kind of Skunky. On line with some of the Italian Lagers that i have tryed. Grassy maybe a hint of Lemon.

White head, pale yellow body.  Very thin, crisp texture.  There was a slight citrus flavor present, as well as a slight hop presence.  Other than that, there isn’t much to this beer. I enjoyed the refreshing aspect of it most of all, which was appreciated when I followed it with a miller lite, which then tasted like crap.

Pours clear yellow gold with a full head and lacing. Aromas include grassy wheat, bread. Has a crisp, clean start with a nutty, wheat cracker taste and just a touch of balancing hops. Decent drinker from a massive brewer.
