Något av en "bakgrundsöl". Skapar en trivsam fond till avslappnat umgänge. Svalkande och uppiggande, fräsch. Ett öl som tar ett steg tillbaka för att orkestrera en trevlig konversation. Bra så.

This beer is more of a thirst quencher than anything else. CO2 aroma, light golden in colour. taste is generic with some mild hops and nothing else. Very simple and uninspiring beer. Good enough for college students. D-
I fell in love with this beer in Europe and was please to see it become popular in the U.S.. It is a no-nonsense beer that has very good taste.

Man, took me 1500 beers before I tried this one too. Alright, so it pours a pale translucent yellow with a one finger frothy white head. Aroma and flavor are as expected. Corn, grassy/hay, mild sweetness, metallic bitterness, some bready malt feel. Crisp. Better than American macro but not enough to justify the cost.
not a fan of this beer at all. rathe upleasant aroma, and the appearance lacks appeal.
hay, golden, clear, white foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium sourness, medium body, slick feel, lively, long finish,
Yellow pour. Looks like a frothy pee. Flavor is skunk, then skunk hops. Skunky, fizzy, not that good. Just because it comes in a fancy glass doesn’t mean it’s good, kids.
Similar to heineken and mythos. A little better though. Anyway I think it is too soft and the taste is no big deal. Too easy to drink.
Tastes like a good version of heineken.  crisp, clean, sometimes a little skunky.  could be better could be worse (heineken)

Bottle. A pale golden color with a big fluffy white head, lots of carbonation.Aroma of grain and skunky hops with a dash of citrus fruit aroma. Flavor is a touch of pale malt up front then a neutral carbonation and then some citrus/skunky hops. Light body with a crisp refreshing mouthfeel and finish,quite drinkable,and a fun try but not the best I’ve ever had.
25cl, from De Hopduvel Gent, not complex brew, yet refreshing, balanced, clear, small head, simpel brew

APPEARANCE: 
Pours a clear pale straw color with a medium large white head that dissipates at slowly. A little bit of lacing.
SMELL: 
Light sweet corn aroma with a hint of skunk.
TASTE: 
Crisp slightly sweet malt. Very clean, little to no hops bitterness.
MOUTHFEEL
Light body that finishes dry and sweet. Fizzy carbonation.
DRINKABILITY: 
Very easy to drink but nothing particularly interesting about it.
NOTES: BBCSD-0810-Patrick
Pale yellow-gold with white head that left a little lacing. Slight perfumy aroma. Fairly thin and bland but quite bitter. Slight metallic taste to it. There are many better lagers out there...

Clear piss-yellow colour, big foam that disappeared fast and left a lacing. Had a very weak smell, not existant almost. Tastes a bit bitter which saves it, besides that it was very watery. Had a lean taste but very boring. Probably the worst belgian beer Ive ever tasted.

I’ve always considered Stella to be a wholly unoffensive macro pale lager.  Smell is skunky.  Color is a pale and transparent straw yellow.  Has a little more bitterness than a typical macro, which saves it a teensy bit (As you can see from my other ratings, I’m a fan of hoppy ales).  I still think as far as this price range and style go, it’s just as I’ve always thought of it: unoffensive and cheap beer.
Stella pours golden with a nice thick head. Smooth hit on the tongue with a nice bitter bite at the end. Always a good drink to have.

Seeing as I was just in Belgium I suppose I should rate this from the source.  I would have taken some notes but I didn’t know that I hadn’t already rated it.   This beer maybe quite light in flavor and fairly light in body, however, it is very clean.  Very soft bready sweetness, quite crisp and dry, grassy.  Not skunked at all in Belgium compared to what makes it across.

bottle
yellow/gold pour with a white head. the flavor is lightly hopped w/ some malt.

It’s funny how our tastes change. When I was younger, and this beer first came to North America I thought it was great. The light floral hoping was a nice change from the flavorless Canadian lagers I grew up drinking. Later of course, I began having my eyes opened to the greater world of beer and, needless to say, ceased being a fan of Stella. Well, today I had one on tap to freshen my opinion in order to rate and I’m, not surprishingly, still not a fan. It amazes me that so many people here (north america) continue to pay uber-premium prices for this stuff when there’s usually something far better/more local/cheaper just  a couple of taps down......marketing is a powerful thing....
Looking at the fact that this is the most regularly drunk Pale Lager in Belgium and the rest of the world, I think the quality is pretty good. Looks nice and tastes above-average.

Had a bitter taste to it that I found difficult to attach myself to.  Not the greatest. 2.0

RE-RATE 3/18/11 Bottle from World Market.  This beer pours a very clear light golden color with a fizzy white head.  There is quite a bit of carbonation apparent in this one.



Aroma is of pilsener malts and grains, slight metal, and some other sweet notes.  Almost a candied sweetness.  I don’t think it’s skunked but I can’t say for certain that there isn’t just a hint of light striking.



As an aside, I was watching a beer special on the cooking channel earlier this week and it centered around this beer, Stella Artois and how it gets from the grain to the glass.  At one point they were inside the brewery and viewing the bottling line.  It was at this point that it was mentioned that all Stella that is bottled in brown bottles is reserved for the Belgians themselves and the green bottles are used for export.  The gentleman who was working there mentioned that this is due to the green bottles having a special treatment to protect them from the light.  This was absolute CRAP!  No amount of special treatment would improve green glass over brown.  I don’t know the real deal here, but if I were to guess it would be that green glass is cheaper to come by and American consumers don’t know the difference between good beer and bad beer so that’s why they use them.  Granted that’s merely speculative on my part.  If it were me, I would want the beer that has the furthest distance to travel to carry the most amount of protection.  But that’s just me.



The flavor mirrors the aroma.  Bitter grains and malts with some metallic flavorings and a bittersweet finish.  No skunk flavor at cold temperatures.  Drink it fast though because this style certainly does not improve as it warms.
Bottle. Poured a golden yellow with a white head. Has a skunky aroma mixed with malt. It is an ok beer that has a malty taste with a crisp, clean, dry finish.
No thank you.  sour/bitter taste midway through each swallow that means this was the first and last.
decent beer, the skunky smell added to the expensive cost makes this beer hard to enjoy thoroughly
Bottle. Pours a pale yellow color with a white head that diminishes quickly. Aroma is corn, grass and skunk. Flavor is all malts with some hops in the finish. An average beer.

500 mL Can. Pours a clear straw yellow with a 2-finger frothy head that seems to want to cling to the sides, leaving ample lacing. Bready/yeasty aroma dominates over the malt, grains, and hops. The flavor is sweet malt with a bready overtone and a definite yeast bite but ending in a clean finish. The hops are a bit shy here, but overall the medium body is no slouch for flavor. Beer Drinkers: you can’t drink this out of the can or bottle. You have to pour it in that goblet as seen in the picture. B for Belgian, B for Beer -oh what a beautiful 4-letter word ;-)

Spots a nice clear shimmery yellow. Good malt and hops fragrances. Very nice level of carbonation. I appreciate tha fact that the maltiness stands out eventhough it’s a light body beer. The low degree of hops bitterness (not hops taste) allows the sweetness in the brew to come forward. Crisp and clean, it’s easy on the palate. Highly refreshing uncomplicated pale lager. Do note that whereas this beer has a simple taste, it does not lack character. The various aspects to this lager are well balanced and, the interplay is neat.

Pours a clear yellow with a tiny white head... Aroma is bready with a nice mild malty nose, little to no hops... Taste is sweet with notes of bread again, no hops, thin finish... Not a terrible lager if i would be required to drink a pale lager....

I prefer not to call this a Belgian beer, it isn’t even brewed in Belgium anymore, it is brewed in Germany, blasphemy! This beer has a very cheap taste, a tiny hint of hops and a soapy aftertaste, I blame it on the mass production. Definitely not my cup of tea.
330ml. Crisp with bready, yeast malt nose and taste. Way better than most macros but very plain. rather bitter.

nice golden color, bit of a skunky smell, almost no lacing.  med-light carbonation.
Flavor is mostly skunky malt and very little hops.  notes of sweaty sox and corn.  OK, I trashed it a bit,  its still drinkable tho.  Pretty sure I will not pay for it again tho.
Tap.  Pours a golden yellow with a medium white head.  Aroma is rather hoppy; taste is slightly hoppy as well.  Finishes well, goes down easy.
Bottle and on tap. Pours a yellow gold and a nice big white head.  Classic crispy  refreshing taste, smooth and a mild hop bite to finish. A lighter body and a clean finish.

Stella poured clear and gold with a one finger head that stuck nicely to the side of the glass. It’s aroma was crisp and malty which was reflected in it’s taste. I love carbonation and this one had plenty which complemented its smoothness. This is a very easy beer to drink.

"Predictable lager from a major manufacturer". Yes and no. The beer  definitely not offending any one, but it is the most beautiful fresh beer to pour. Its colour, fizzy bubbles, head and even its bottle and label is fantastic. My favorite ’night on the town - tap’ when available, and favorite refreshment in the sun when on bottle. 

 Found on tap in ’The British Pub" Copenhagen, large cans in Metro and Føtex, bottles not predictably found in Copenhagen.
Great for getting me in the mood for a little wife beating.  Check the bottom of Stell Artois Wiki, it’s a pretty funny story.

Draught, fluffy head that stays for quite awhile, clear pale yellow colour, strong hoppy nose. The taste is a melange of malty and grainy sweetness with a hoppy bitterness that ends with an unpleasant sweet bitter aftertaste. Has a little more body and character than normal macro lagers, i’m just not sure  i like this character.

Drinking this one at my friend Pete’s new house in Dilworthtown - he is a loyal Stella drinker.  Pours clear light gold with a thin white head.  Aroma of light hops and barley/grain, flavor of light citrus hops.  For an everyday beer, this is one of the more drinkable ones.

12 oz bottle.  Poured a clear yellow color with a two finger white head.  The aroma was very astringent.  I didn’t get anything else in the nose.  The flavor was a typical pale lager, grainy with a bitter finish.

Pours a pale, clear gold with a rapidly diminishing small white head. Looks like a generic lager. Somewhat floral aroma with a little yeast and very little malt. Flavour is of a slightly sweet malt with a bit of bitter hops that have a slightly sharp flavour. Carbonation is a little overdone but reasonable and mouthfeel is only slightly more full than the typical pale lager, which still means it’s rather thin. Finish is sweet malt with some floral hop flavours following. Not a bad beer and easy enough to drink. Just way overhyped and overpriced. It seems pale lagers are just a mediocre style overall and this one doesn’t do anything to change that.
On draft pours yellow, crystal clear and high carbonation. Slight floral aroma, typical lager taste with a bit more sturdiness to body, sweet note, and a bit of a hop finish.

Smells a little bit like a urinal cake. Pours a pale yellow with no head. A little over-carbonated. Despite the smell, no nasty aftertaste which is exciting. Not too sure why it costs so much more at the bar other than being from Belgium.

On tap at scooters in portland. Pours a clear yellow with a small white head that looks creamy. Aroma of yeast and slight hops. Slightly carbonated with a nice, smooth finish. Nice beer to take it easy with when everyone else is drinking mixed drinks.
On tap at Applebee’s.  Pours clear gold with a big white head.  Aroma of lager yeast, some hop and malt.  Very carbonated with a hop finish.

Still a nice smooth beer but not quite what you’d expect given the supposed reputation on this side of the pond (Canada). The beer has a fairly sturdy taste but is really light.  The finish is really nice and there’s no bad aftertaste so it does do all the ’regular’ beers one better because you don’t have to cover up the bad aftertaste with another sip. (hic, haha).  Smooth and light with just enought hops to taste good but not enought for there to really be a flavour or a theme going on.
From 330ml bottle. Aroma is sour and cheap. Very light blonde colour. Flavor is bitter a little hoppy and very sour in the finish. Its not bad. But its not that good either.
Clean, low metal taste, very neutral.  Low aftertaste.  All around pleasant and unobtrusive, however those are not qualities I enjoy in beer.  A nice beer for what it is.

can. Poured clear gold with diminishing white head. Hoppy floral aroma(sometimes skunky). Medium mouthfeel, bitter-sweet. Lasting alcohol bitter finish. Tastes like a pilsner but not as bitter. Easy to drink but nothing special.

This is the Budweiser of Belgian beers. Nice golden color. It’s a good beer but not a great beer. It’s an average lager that is dependable and a couple of notches above bud. Smooth with a little skunk bitterness on taste which is what you get with average lagers.

Pours smooth bright white head very light amber/gold body. smells ok kinda floral. Taste, very crisp, slightly floral and a nice hoppy bite.
not bad really I think it deserves a little better rateings.

Can, consumed in the correct manner - slumped in front of some football on the telly. "Wifebeater" is the national drink of the swill-drinking masses of England. Cardboard malt and honeyish chemicals give it a sweetish taste, balanced by something resembling hops. Heavy palate and strong enough to get you into a fighting mood. Thankfully I got this for free, so none of my money went to InBev.
Pours bright clear gold into a shaker. Bright white head with medium retention leaves spot lacing.  Adjunct and sour malt aromas. Tastes like the aroma with a crisp sourness and a gentle hop finish.
12 oz bottle. Clear Golden color. Not too much aroma. A bit of fruityness for the taste, a bit grassy, not a real hop finish, but clean finish. Eh. overated.
pours a clear golden blond, with a nice white head.  smells and tastes like an import lager. probably a small step above Heineken.
One of my favourite industrial blonde beer

Pours a bubbly yellow with a quickly dissipating fizzy head. Floral and fruity flavors present along with grain and plenty of carbonation. This beer both smelled and tasted like skunk to me. Unimpressive, particularly for a Belgium brew.

Wow..I was expecting something really good for a beer I just paid $10 for a six-pack.  I was kinda disappointed.  Do not get me wrong it was a decent beer, just not worth the hype or ca$h.  Poured yellow with lots of bubbles..other than that it was almost a pedestrian American lager.

It seems to be well regarded by many here in Australia but it was the cheapest beer I could buy in Tesco’s when I lived in Scotland. A drinkable pale lager, slightly grassy and mildly bitter -  nothing noteworthy.

22 oz draft poured in tap at bw3 (schererville, Il). Poured light straw yellow, transparent body, with small white bubbly head that dissipates to a film. Aromas are light subtle grainy sweetness typical of a lager. Initial is light on the palate, a little fuller than most lagers. Grainy sweetness with subtle bitterness on the backend, a touch sour almost. Maybe a touch adjuncty, but smooth. Typical imported lager. Finishes a little bland. Ehhh.
On Tap in the USA. Just about anywhere in the world. A safe beer when unsure or surrounded by Macros. Nothing special.

Bottle.  Pours clear yellow with a persistant frothy head.  Smell is of corn grain malt and lightly hopped.  Tastes like corn, smooth with lots of grain malts and a hop bitterness that slowly fades.  Very drinkable.

330mL bottle, brewed in Auckland, NZ so not the real thing :( 
A rather sweet aroma but with no complexity, some straw-like malt and hops with a bit of alcohol present.
An astringent bitterness with almost no flavour behind it. Some hops in there, but overall boring and watery.
I don’t hate this beer, but I don’t love it.
Bottle, actually imported from Belgium, not brewed in Auckland. Pours golden with white head. Grassy aroma, tastes of grassy bitter hops. Some candy sweetness as well. Finishes slightly dry.
Bottle: Light and nothing to it. A lot of hype about nothing. Most of the time it’s skunky.

the aroma is nearly non-existent but the appearance is somewhat pleasing...it is a bright golden color with a foamy white head and thick lacing and lots of bubbly action.  it is a light drinkable beer but the flavor is merely inoffensive and offered nothing to speak of other than some light hoppiness.  it has a bit of a creamy mouthfeel for a lager but the finish is fairly abrupt.  i wouldnt turn it down but i wouldnt go out of my way to drink it very often.

Bouteille verte de 330 ml provenant d’une caisse de 12 fermée. Nos yeux observent une bière de couleur or surmontée d’un beau col de mousse qui reste longtemps pour le style. Au nez on découvre des arômes de céréales fraîches et de houblon floral. En bouche le corps est mince avec une effervescence moyenne. On goûte des saveurs de grain frais suivit d’une bonne amertume pour le style. Une bière de brosse par excellence. Ma lager préféré jusqu’à maintenant.
Una de las cervezas "tomables" que actualmente se venden en botellas de 1l en Chile

bottle smells like cat piss and tastes like it too.  overlooking the skunked bottle the body is good but the finish is harsh and grassy and not the good kind of grassy.  i liked lagers but this one disappointed me quite a bit.  maybe on tap and fresh its a different story.
Back when I was young and naive I got suckered in by this one, believing all the hype...the hype was wrong.

Bottle pours an attractive straw yellow with a tall vanilla head.Aroma is fetid and skunky sulphuric hops. Taste is bitter and skunky with a hint of grass and a metallic twang. Subtle malt sweetness. Not recommended.
Good beer overall.  Has a slight skunky aroma but has a clean crisp finish.  Fairly light on other aromas.  Presentation and bottle are nice, and add to the overall impression of the beer.

Poured a clear light gold with a modest sudsy head. Smelled like biscuit and light skunk funk. Tasted moderately bitter with a crisp finish. Very light, but has the most body I have found for the style.  Not a huge fan, but definitely the best of the worst.
Last time at Olive Garden in Chicago, IL (by Midway), tap. Either tap or bottle not impressive for Belgian.

Draught. Clear pale yellow beer with small white head. Skunky aroma perhaps from the keg, bready malt and grain. Flavour is quite bland, pale malt with some grassy hop bitterness. Light bodied with some bitterness in the finish.

A classic lager, yellowish liquid below amedium white foamy head, grassy aroma with low tones of sweetness and low unpleasant acidity, some malt and lemon in flavor with low vanilla and metallic acid like flavors, hoppy aftertaste, refreshing and very drinkable.

I was given this beer for free - a sales rep was at my local store, and he shoved one into my hand as I was walking out the door - he also handed me a fancy stella artois glass inside of a velvet pouch that was three times larger than the glass was - I have had this beer before, but I have never rated it, mostly because I have never had the true stella artois EXPERIENCE, by which I mean I have never had it in a fancy stella glass that came wrapped in a velvet pouch - surely something that has its own fancy, cloth-enrobed glassware is one of the greatest beers in the world - all those times I had it in the past and thought it was mediocre must have been because of the inferior vessels used to contain this libation - let us find out - - - - - - - - no - no - it is still boring - how could such flashy presentation mislead me so?
Overall I was let down by this beer.  I have tried in a bottle and from a tap and both times I really was expecting more.
Outra clássica Lager que entrou no mercado nacional. Menos saborosa que a Heineken, mas fácil de agradar.

This lager poured a clear light yellow colour with a bright white , foamy head. To the nose there are scents of grass, grains, yeast and sweet malt. First taste was slightly watery with flavours of grain and grass. The finish is light with the hoppy grain flavour lasting.
bottle. has a fruity aroma. pours a clear light yellow with little head. has a sweet honey flavor with a warm aftertaste. very easy to drink but not much flavor.
Clear very light yellow pour with a finger of white head.  Big skunky pils aroma, pale malts, and a light hop grassiness.  Taste is malty, light pale malt, smooth with some grassy hop for balance.

Sorry Stella. 12 ounce bottle from Glenville beverage. Golden color was beautiful and I was pumped about trying this one. White head, looked clean and refreshing. Then I smelled it. Maybe it was a skunky bottle, maybe too much light got in. Or maybe not. Maybe it was just a bad beer. Tasted skunky. I barely could finish this one.
Crisp gold but I’ve come to prefer a little darker hue in even my lagers and pilsners. Taste is not reminiscent of Heineken at all and has this sourness. The sourness makes it inconsistent for me.

On tap at a hotel restaurant. Poured into a pilsner glass, bright golden yellow with a small head that left no lacing. Nice champagne bubbles rising to the top, though. Pungent aroma, skunky like a heineken. Flavor was less offensive - somewhere between cardboard and grains. Watery mouthfeel, nice carbonation (best part of the beer), and dry aftertaste. A place that serves this probably also serves more appealing alternatives - go for the alternative.

Draft - Gold with lacing formed a white head. some hoppy favor and aroma, but not too hoppy for style.  Better then standard cheap beers.  Good snappy finish.  This may have been better because served on draft.

Standard plae lager, but overall more enjoyable.  The appearance is true to the style, yellow, white foam.  The aroma is not bad, grassy, not sign of corn or other adjuncts.  The flavor has a grassy, earthy quality that sets it above others of the style (this doesn’t say much).  Good bitter finish.  OK overall.
Draught 0.35L glass at Belge. Pale white head had dissappeared when waiter carried it to the table. Bright pale golden colour. Grassy mild taste. Mild hoppiness at the end. MIld nose.
Not a bad tasting lager, you can do a lot worse, just not as reassuringly expensive as the adverts would have us believe
A decent enough lager. Refreshing and gows down easily, but it’s nothing special. I rarely order it anymore.
Poured from can. Nice golden color with good head that lasts. Nice flavor, not offensive. Very easy to drink. Good overall.

1pt 6.4oz bottle:  Aroma is somewhat of a skunky Saaz hop aroma, somewhat grainy, and grassy.  Appearance is clear and golden with a thick white head that lingers.  Taste is crisp and clean, nothing really offensive, lightly grainy, and a bit bready.  Palate is got a light grain note and aftertaste is light and crisp.  Overall,  It’s not really bad, not stellar but not bad.  Cheers!
The everyday beer for a regular beer drinker. It has enough taste, body and flavour to be preferred over watery, cheap beers.

Eh.......not too impressed with this one...maybe even more so after InBev brought AB.....always thought it was kinda skunky....taste was ok...nothing special.....I’d drink it again....but would not go to the store and pick up a 6-pack....had better...had worse

Had this out of a bottle at a restaurant.  Hadn’t had one in years, and looked forward to trying it again.

Didn’t get a chance to pour it into a glass, so this review may not mean much.  Smelled like a lot of other pilsners, nothing special, maybe a bit more hoppy that others.

Had a crisp, bitter mouthfeel, and about the same in the finish.  Wasn’t a bad beer, just nothing to write home about, particular for a ""premium"" beer.

Bottle from the LCBO
Much better than i would have expected
but still a week pale lager. Good on a hot day ice cold
A very nice beer. It is bitter and crisp and you can taste that it is quite strong. However - for some reason it is the only beer of which I can only drink 2-3 bottles until heart burn kicks in.

On tap at La Rez in Chapel Hill. Official Stella glass. Pours a pale yellow with high, champagne-like carbonation and a large, white head. Okay lacing. Nose is fresh grass, slight hops, grain. Watery body with a sour, metallic endnote. Aftertaste is dry. There is one overall taste and that is fresh straw. Pretty much the most expensive bad beer you can buy.

On tap at Cheese Cake Factory in Birmingham AL.  Pours pale yellow with plenty of carbonation and a light head.  Minimal inoffensive grainy aroma.  The flavor is pale lager…What can you do.  Grain present in liquid form, though this one has more of a noticeable hop presence (earth and spice).  Light watery body with a semi-dry finish.  It’s fine for what it is.
16 oz draft poured straw color with a huge head.  Grassy aroma and bitterness.  A bit of body but not much.

On tap.  Looks nice in the glass, with a foamy head, and some lacing on the glass.  Otherwise, a grassy, sour, and unpleasent bitter beer, with little else to recommend.  Overly carbonated to boot. I found little to recommend here, and quite frankly, have touble understanding the worldwide popularity with so many better light lagers out there.

Pours light gold with a big pillowy white head. Not much aroma other than a little spice, a little hops, and maybe a little grass.
Taste is decent, but nothing extraordinarily. High effervescence and dry clean finish. Drinkable.
Stella Artois is one of the world’s best- enjoyed beers. It has a full characteristic flavour ,nice appearance and sizzling aroma. Not the best beer around but it’s highly enjoyable.

I still can’t believe this is so popular with people around here.  Crystall clear straw pour with sparkling white head. Aroma of skunk, piss, grass.  Grainy, grassy flavor, some hops.  Medium thin body with prickly carbonation.  Not horrible, but nothing to rave about.
Nice Golden color with a good layer of head slightly sweet citrus aroma a little skunky its an alright beer i could think of plenty beers to get over this for the price ..... eh average swill
Golden color with foamy white head. Grassy aroma with hints of herbs and hay. Similar flavor of grass, hay and vegetables.
Good, but not great. Not sure what all the hype is about. Thought it was OK but nothing I would buy again at that price. There are better European lagers out there.
Pretty boring, just another macro lager.  Clear yellow, white head.  Light flavor of malt, mild hops, and apple.  Drinkable, if thats what your looking for.
First beer I bought when overseas.  Better than any American big run pale lager.  Green bottle makes for some skunk obviously, but it’s aight.  I’d take this over Bud any day.

Spicy aroma. Pale clear yellow colour with white head. Strong, bitter and spicy flavour. It,s so long ago, that I’ve had a Stella Artois that I had forgotten that a pale lager could not only be drinkable but also enjoyable.
overpriced heineken.  Totally not worth the price, not even worth the space in your stomach, blegh
11.2 oz. bottle, over priced and overrated, an average macro-lager, taste is a bit tinny and bitter, light gold yellow, weak head... I’d only buy if on sale. Cheers.

Draught...pours a small thin head which rapidly collapses, nice lacing, pale clear yellow....mild nose, really minimal character...tastes of mild hop....watery palate. Typical of the"better’ macro brews.
Draught. Clear golden with lots of head. Vegetable aroma. Light body, medium carbonation. Vegetable / hop taste. Refreshing, but not great.
hay, floral, citrus, leaves, alcohol, vanilla, ginger, pale, sparkling, aminimal head, lightly bitter, light body, thin feel, fizzy, bitter,

Tap. I succumb to the hype and tried one during a layover in Chicago.  Overall, this beer is decent.  A bit of sweetness with a hint of unfiltered yeast.  Good for a Pale Lager. Yet, this beer proves to me to be more of a fad or status symbol than truly a good beer.  I see and hear many people who graduated from the typical mass produced swill to Stella Artois and think that they have found somethng special. Must be good since it costs more, right?  Just another alternative to other country club fare like Heinekin or Corona.

Pours a transparent gold with a thin white head which pretty quickly sinks back into the glass. Not a very impressive appearance. Has a thick hoppy aroma as well as taste, with a hint of sweetness. Reminds me of Pilsner Urquell but not quite as balanced. A solid beer overall.

Aroma: A little crackery and floral; dry impressions overall. Appearance: Highly carbonated light gold with a foamy white head. Flavor: Matches the nose; crackery up front with some floral, grassy notes toward the finish. Palate: Medium body, sticky texture, lively carbonation, abrupt finish. Overall: Had a pretty fresh bottle I think; not nearly as bad as I remember.
Frothy head - piss coloured. No aroma, hoppy, grainy and watery above all. Come on people, stop buying this stuff. It’s not even cheap!

espuma de aparência inicial média e cremosa, coloração branca e reduzida longevidade, apresenta boa formação de colarinho. Seu corpo é borbulhante e de densidade rala, de tonalidade amarelo-claro. O aroma é clássico: pão branco e forte lúpulo. Seu sabor inicial é levemente doce e amargo, apresentando moderado amargor no final, de curta duração. Seu paladar é composto de um corpo leve, de textura aguada, forte carbonatação e um final chalky (lembrando giz), sendo esse seu único diferencial passível de comentários. Seu final é bem limpo e o amargor é balanceado
Light gold color, medium head. Light bodied lager style beer. Light malts, somewhat hoppy. Taste is a little bitter.

Well the Stella is one of the easiest beerss to drink, so if you dont like beers...go for it!! Light gold with nice head, weak notes of light fruit and malt. Flavour is little sweet, no finish, watery. No development and no complexit.... just plain and boooring :-(
Claro que la he tomado varios lugares y varias veces es la stella who stella yo stella

Served in the Stella Artois chalice 

[Eyes] golden body with a very nice white head.

[Nouse] Pretty mild a little sweetness malty and flowers.

[Mouth] Taste pretty good, is bitter, the carbonation is very clean Drink goes down very gentile.

Overrated. Pours a typical yellow color for this type of beer. Has a foul aroma which is almost skunky. Has a medium sized head. Taste very bitter and the typical european style pale lager. Nothing special here really.
Magnificent lager! Little to strong for my taste - a headache maker. Can’t imagine to drink this all evening long. But - one opf the best beers out there.
On tap one of the better lagers. The green export bottles however are very bad and watery. Stella Artois anagram, A Realist s Lot...

Draught, available everywhere.  Ah, where would we be in the UK without wife-beater?  A beer of last resort, to be honest, only to be sampled if faced with Scottish real ales (the ghastly Deuchars, for example) or the usual pissy lagers such as Carlsberg, Carling, etc.  Its looks are its strong point - think the colour of piss when you’re dehydrated, with a reasonable white head.  After that, it is all downhill.  Horrible skunk aroma, little or no hops, metallic after-taste.  Avoid if possible.

On tap.  Pours a golden color with a white foamy head.  Better tasting than US macros, which was my only alternative, but doesn’t compare to micros.  Had a sweeter aftertaste than other lagers, which was the one redeeming quality.
on tap - golden beer with white head. Malty sweet aroma. The same for the flavour.

Had today at Buffalos in Coral Springs.  Well this doesnt rate well, but it certainly beats the hell out of any American macro and so I choose to drink it when nothing else decent is on tap.  Sparkling yellow pour, small white head.  Funky aroma of malts.  Flavor is unique, but very malty...kinda funky, but almost in a good way.  Drinkable.

(Bottle, brewed at Belgium brewery).  Sweet grassy aroma.  Very light golden color with a substantial fluffy white head.   Taste is like a mild pilsener, some maltiness, bread and yeast, but only a faint bitterness.  The sweetness is unusual, and pleasing.  Better than expected.
Golden pint had lasting head and a nice flavor for it’s type.  A bit too light for me, but balanced.  Finish is too bitter; a pretty simple beer.

Taste 9/8 Bottle(Best by4/09) . Looks: Clear yellow with a white head. Aroma: Mild almost odorless. Tiny amount of malt. Taste: Intentionally bland. Clean, bright and better than most of this style of beer. Beer for people who don’t like beer.

Presentation: It was poured from green 11.2oz. bottle into a tulip glass that is similar in size and shape of a signature Stella Artois glass.

Appearance: It has a nice light golden color with very good clarity and a good amount of visible champaign like carbonation. On top it forms a big fluffy head that slowly settles and leaves very little to no lace.

Smell: The aroma has a delicate floral and grassy nose.

Taste/Mouth feel: It has a delicate flavor as well as its aroma. There is a mild sweetness that is balanced by light floral, almost fruity and mildly bitter hops. This mild flavor can become skunked very easily so look for as fresh a sample as possible. Its body is light and the finish is crisp and dry. The texture is slightly slick and thin with lively carbonation that makes it very easy to drink.

Notes: A good fresh Stella well have a good delicate and somewhat dry flavor that pairs well with food in place of dry white wine.
If your enjoying it on it’s own, or better yet have paired it properly, this is a nice clean lager with just a hint of it’s Belgain roots to add to the fun.

I thought it was great that on the episode of Anthony Bourdain where he went to Malaysia, they stopped in a little store in the middle of the jungle 3 hours from civilization and they bought a case of warm Stella. Pours light, clear straw-gold. Nice thick white head. Hints of lemon, wheatgrass and hops. Dry, malty finish. Very effervescent. One of the better lagers on God’s green earth, but if there’s something heavier i’ll almost always go for that.
(bottle) A dark yellow beer with a medium head. a slightly strong hoppy aroma. a little sweetened flavour, a real good lager

I really dont see what is so special about this beer.  Average, or less than, would be the word.  No flavor, no fulfillment, nothing.  Dont try to wow me with this thing called Stella, not worth your time or money.
Pours to lite golden body with minimal head.  Taste is watery and smooth.  Not much aftertaste.  Not a bad beer but not worthy of its reputation or premium price.

Not bad for what it is compared to.  Pours a pale golden color with a thin white head.  Watered down malty aroma with a malty, kind of sweet taste.  Not really worth the price bump compared to other beers.  Decent at best.
One of the most vastly overrated beers by people who think they like good beer, but don’t.  Sickly clear golden with a loud fizzing head, and gentle notes of corn and water.  Bitter, fizzy, not good.
Light, refreshing, subtle and goes down smoothe.  Perfect with a light meal or on a hot day while firing up the BBQ.

On tap, pint glass.  Clear pale gold with almost no head.  Aroma of light honey. Flavor initially has a touch of honey sweetness, but then turns to a long unpleasant finish reminiscent of stale bread.  Watery mouthfeel.
Often listed a beer that other people who rated some of the same beers as me rated, so I figured I better try it, right?  Okay, so now I tried it.  Okay, but nothing overwhelming!

Pours a light golden color with little head.  Not much of a smell.  Taste was of grains, malt and a little yeast.  The hops are present and the finish is rather nice.  I would rather have this than most American macros hands down.

Can’t get into my head that some people consider this great or at least above average. I don’t like the metal rotten veggie angle of this, the cardboard taste and the unclean finnish certainly don’t help either. A dismal beer with good marketing I suppose.
A watery, skunky and not so very good lager. Belgians should stick to brewing strong ales instead of lagers.
Have had much worse - not much to say that has not been noted.  Lived up to its reputation? I guess?

Bottle. Aroma is mainly yeast. Golden color with a fizzy white head. Refreshing, mixture of grain and slight malt and a slight bitter finish. Overall, a decent beer available at most supermarkets here in Florida. Perfect for summer BBQs and long drinking sessions. If you want a great tasting beer, then you can do better.

had on draft tonight at local restaurant. Pours golden with this white head. Aroma is water, yeast and malt. Flavor is watery with hints of malt, yeast and grass. A step up compared to most american macros but over rated.
I really don’t understand the fascination with this, especially in the States. Its an alright lager at best, nothing to get excited about.

Bottle.  Aaaah the lager.  A much beleaguered style.  This is the best macro pale lager in my opinion.  Trust in the Beligans. Very little head; Refreshing, tasty, not overpowering, and not too bitter.  Somewhat hoppy, and very Delicious
Fairly good. Nice hoppy finnish, really refreshing. Light bodied, suited for long drinking sessions.
Light and refreshing. One of the best " commercial pale lager " . Enough for a BBQ.
light pour with a nice head- watery flavor-step up from typical light crap beers.  Not my style... weak flavor
On tap from the Black Badger. I have nothing against this beer. Its light and drinkable but def over-hyped. However it has stood the test of time well.

From a 12 fl. oz. green bottle marked 02 2009 L 05089 G.  It pours yellow with white fizzy head.  Malts, yeast, and grass in the aroma.  A tad watered down.  Grains and malt in the favor with a slightly dry finish. Another 14th Century brew still alive today and I can see why.  Nothing spectacular but it is drinkable.
It was good, but not very strong. Stella is a good beginner beer but it is easy to loose interest with other more flavorful beers out there.

Stella Artois: watery mild yellow pour, but don’t be fooled!  This lager is packed with flavor.  The aroma is strong, with hints of wheat and barley.  Very sharp, bitter finish, which by my standards is devine.  Imported from Belgium, this beer is no let down.  Must be a fan of Lagers, delicious out of the tap, better out of the bottle.

on tap at the roadhouse sports pub in carpenersville very pale yellow with a thin wispy white head aromas of yeast and grains very mildly hopped taste is very weak a european version of of a crap beer like bud coors or miller don’t waste your time
I am not a gue fan of lagers.  To me, the majority of them taste the same.  I think stella is just smooth and not "watered down".  It is my favorite lager to drink in the summer.
Just not a fan of these bitter beers like Stella and Becks.  Very bitter finish

Skunky pilsner taste.  In 1926, Stella Artois was launched initially as a seasonal beer especially for the Christmas holiday market.  Watered down taste.  Not great.   They support Cannes and Sundance music festivals.  Crips, able to drink a lot.

Appearance: Pours a plain-looking, clear, yellow body with a tall, foamy, white head.

Smell: Grainy pale malts blended with corn kernels and vague floral notes.

Taste: Again, it’s grainy pale maltiness with maize and a slight sweetness. Touch of floral hops but no real bitterness. Just a touch of sour yeastiness. Finishes squeaky clean.

Mouthfeel: Thin-bodied. Medium carbonation.

Drinkability: Not quite reprehensible, but notable for it’s blandness and lack of character.

Whatever Stella is a good version of a macro produced lager beer clean finish nice hops crisp and refreshing I like to buy a sixer of Stella when I’m eating something spicy like chilli on a hot day, plus you can pound it and not get wiped out.
Very unimpressive. Decent floral aroma with a soft cream head but palate is contrasting and made me want to sneeze after every sip.

Cheap, sweet malts dominate the aroma.  Clear golden color with small lingering head.  One dimensional malts pound the nose and finish into nothingness.  Quite a forgetable beer.  This beer actually really sucks for having the fancy "import" status.  Same league as Heiniken.
Bottle. Pours light gold with a fizzy white head. Aroma is grain, hay, and a bit of grass. Light bosy. Flavor is rather faint, with a bit of grain and trace hops. Dry finish. Not bad.
Very skunky beer.  Very popular for some reason.  Strong hoppy tasting, with a very unpleasant aftertaste.

Budweiser’s European equivalent, although slight better tasting than the King of Beers. Very popular across the pond for many years and starting to increase rapidly in popularity here in the states, especially with Anheuser Busch acquiring the brand. Not bad for a commercial beer: golden color, slightly bitter taste for a lager. Nicknamed "wife beater" in the U.K. due to its relatively strong alcohol content for a lager.
The smells is nice. Skunky like a pilsner, has a hint of sunflower seeds. Little too oily, compared to other beers like pilsner urquiel.

A fine mixture of hops and wheat make this smooth lager a firm favourite. Easy to the palate with a clean crisp hoppy taste, this particular brew is a popular snifter in any UK establishment. 

Whilst pervaying the malty flavour of this fine lager the drinker is lulled into a "happy zone" with a warm glow that makes this beverage a welcome commercially avaible drink. After effects include violence and total memory loss that results in violence.
The beer poured an golden yellow with a soapy head.  The smell is straw and wheat. The taste is flat and watered down. Not good at all.
Pours light golden. Nothing special. Much like cheap american lager. Have another? No.
Very smooth and refreshing. On the down side I find this beer to very filling.

Ugh, how plain. Macro beer in a green bottle - a poseur. No better on tap, except that it’s easier to avoid being light-struck. Large, thin head that disappears rapidly, leaving the clear straw-colored beer in the glass. Generic armoas and flavors of light malt, weak hops, and a hint of yeast (if you manage to get some that isn’t skunky). The palate is the same as Coke’s. Don’t buy it. Please.

Bottle, Victory Serices Club, London. Comes with dinner. Yellow, surprisingly flavourful. Not unpleasant.

I managed to not drink this ubiquitous beer during a month stay in Belgium. How ironic to be saddled with it in London thanks to the global reach of InBev. Not a style of beer I have much time for. At least it is unobjectionable.
pale clear yellow with a decent white head. aroma is of mild malts and dough. Taste has a little yeasty kick to it and finishes smooth. Extremely drinkable.
This clear yellow beer poured with a very thin white head. There’s not much flavor, but it is a crisp easy to drink beer.
Poured Pal yellow with a slightly fruity hop aroma.  Smooth with more flavor than most of the macro brews.  Finished crisp with no bitterness.

On tap, black angus. Havn’t had this in a long time, so I figured what the hell. Actually quite good. The color is a mild yellow, very nice white head with a lace that went all the way down. Very clean flavor, easy to drink, finished the first one in a matter of minutes. No strong aftertaste, much better than any of the budmillercoors offerings. Very nice.

Purchased 6 pack of 12 oz bottles at Schmidt’s Exxon in Tysons Corner. Pours a pale yellow, with a slight greenish tone with a very large, loosely packed head. The head  recedes quickly though. Aroma is belgian yeast, which is a little strange for a lager. My nose also detects coriander, crisp european hops and a tad of clove. Taste is a thinner than what the aroma suggests, very much like most lagers. Though it is clean and crisp and doesn’t suffer from cheap ingredients, adjuncts and the like, that its American cousins do. The style percentage of 88.8 says its all. This is a good lager.

This one poured with the expected pale yellow color.  The head was relatively long lasting for a lager of this type.  It had a straightforward moderate malt taste with a clean, almost biting hop profile.  It met the average to meager expectations I had for it as the ultimate "regular" lawn mowing beer.
Bottle. Disapointing in almost every respect: short-lived and unappealing head, and one-dimensional and almost acidic in flavour and on the palate Lacks character.

Can from the LCBO. Wow, I can’t believe it’s taken me so long to rate this! Not much I can write about this beer that hasn’t been said by 1606 people before me, so I’ll simply say that while I avoid the green bottles like the plague, I actually consider this to be a perfectly acceptable mainstream lager when I have it on tap or from a can, so my rating reflects those versions. When it’s fresh, it’s actually a very subtle, elegant beer despite it’s ubiquitousness. Not something to drink every day to be sure, but when I’m in a restaurant where it’s on tap alongside Blue and Bud Light, I’m not adverse to having a glass of Stella with my meal.

I don’t know why this beer is so popular. Belgium has the best beers in the world overall. This is not one of them. It’s basically a Belgian Budweiser, although certainly better than that. It’s a decent beer that’s better for the summer than for the winter. Fans of pilsners will love this one. I’m a stout fan so it’s just not my style. Not a bad beer, but not great either. It’s simply overrated.

pours a clear yellow with a lot of stark white, rapidly dissipating head.  Odor of straw and grasses, with just a dash of citrus hops.  The taste is predominantly bitter, which ends with a bit of a grassy aftertaste.  A nice change from the general macros, but on its own, not a good belgium beer.
This beer has its place, but it’s not my style. Nothing to special here, a beer that falls right in line with other macro light beers.

I just about like anything from Belgium, but most are ales. This is a nicely refreshingbeer. Nose is malt/hop aroma; color appropriate for style; light on the tongue with a bit more body than most pilsners. More hop flavor and aroma would be more what I like. I have no problems drinking it.

Tap: light copper color.  Aroma pilsener-ish?
Taste: heavy carbonatioin with a dry finish.  Light taste and flavor that is hard to pinpoint but nice aftertaste.  Not my favorite beer and will most often pass on this but I would take this over bud, bud light and the others any day.

Solita e molesta lager di massa, improbabile non trovarla e non incapparvi almeno una volta nella propria vita. Sapore cerealicolo con estrema dolcezza e sentori metallici; una noia mortale, e con qualche fastidio pure.
Pint at Premier Inn hotel, York. Golden color, disappering white head. Aroma has malt and some hops. Flavor is malty with some sweetness and bitterness. Ok pilsener.
Severely overrated. Similar league to a Labatt Blue or something like that. Very light and dry.
Light, dry and hoppy with a bright nose.  In the mouth it is more of the same in this light-bodied beery.
Tap and bottle. More flavor and less watery than a Budweiser or Miller, but not too much. Clear color leaves much to be desired. Fills the role of Budweiser in Europe. Enough said.
Clear yellow coloured beer with small white head and few carbonation. Hoppy herby aroma. Full sparkling palate. Finish is hoppy, herby ending bitter.
330mL Bottle. Strong Floral hop aroma. Poors a bright clear pale golden beer. Good size white head, as in the photo. Lingering hop bitterness to finish. Better then Heineken.

Bottle. Poured a golden color with a small white head. Looked pretty much like an AB product. Tasted like one too. More flavor than a Budweiser or Miller, but nothing to brag about. I’d get it again if there was nothing better available.
Almost forgot, had a 500 ml can of this at my bro’s.  What can I say, it just another pale Eurolager.  Nothing special but not terribly bad either.

Tastes just like a Carona to me. I’m not sure why people rave over this beer. Maybe they think it is made well because it has a paper wrapper. Pours a clear light golden color with a medium disappearing white head.

On tap. Aroma of sweet malt. Flavor has more fruitiness than I’ve ever experienced in a pale lager (yes, this is the first time I’ve had this). Still, pretty watery body and not enough in there to make it interesting after a couple sips. Drinkable, but not preferable.

Pours a clear light golden color with a medium disappearing white head.  The aroma is bready with a touch of floral hops.  Flavor has a mild sweetness, bread, and a hint of herbal hops.  Watery, but a slightly better alternative to the other macro pale lagers.

Bottle 33 cl. Pours a pale yellow with a small white head and a skunky, malty aroma. The taste is thin and doesn’t hold up for long, it’s a bit malty, a bit hoppy, like your everyday lager. Nothing special or thrilling, not bad either. Just more of the same

On tap. Pours a golden yellow with a small head.  Aroma of sweet malt, light fruits.  Flavor of wheat, sweet malts, skunk.  Not very good, tasted exactly like the Spaten Premium Lager I’d had prior.  Wouldn’t get again.

0.33 l bottle. Golden color with small head. Malty aroma with herbal hops and corn. Equally malty and hoppy flavor with some tart fruitiness, honey and dry hoppier finish. Light bodied. There is something in this beer which I don’t like but I cannot put my finger on it.
thin, watery, bitter as in too much sun. (wonder if i got a bad sample, 3 sunburned aftertasting beers in a row from the same fridge in cph.)
Clear golden color.  Sweet with a little spicyness.  Maybe a bit skunky, but with a green bottle that’s hard to avoid.  A very clean finish.  Drinkable.
Stella looks like a great beer when poured.  The taste is average and comparable to Heineken.  There is no real aroma and palate.

Such a light-weight beer. Impressive in its’ restraint. The dry bitter hops last a long time. Starts out sweet and the bitter just keeps building. Very clean refreshing drink. Best before: 11/2008.
Wish I had another. From a bottle.
nice fresh pilsner high bitterness and hop taste very dry. perfect on a hot summerday
a lightly hopped lager... not your typical quality belgian brew, but better than most north american macrobrews.... needs to be properly stored or can turn skunky....
Ths is a great lawn mower beer.  This light, refreshing and hoppy pilsner is a great way to cap a day of yard work.

A very pleasent beer to have if you want to indulge and drink more than one. While my pals are binging with busch light I would break out a stella. Nice ale, not filling, and even bolder on tap. A fine commercial beer to proudly hold.

Tried this on a whim one night. Crystal clear golden color. Lasting bright white head, with a vaguely metallic scent. Pretty carbonated, but not oppressively so. Hoppy, and refreshing. The taste is hopelessly marred by heavy metallic notes. Overall a decent brew that I would take over Miller, Bud, etc...
Considering the "finest ingredients available" include maize I fell I’m being quite generous here.
great clear golden color- after that there’s not much to say. Lousy aroma- somewhat metallic taste, still better than a lot of pale lagers

Had this many times before both on tap and in the bottle. I it better on tap, where it is quite refreshing and goes well with the crab and shrimp Louie salad I had. Crisp, lightly grassy. Clear golden body, small white head, some lacing on the tap version. Good amount of yeast in the taste, a rather dynamic and characterfilled Pale Lager. Probably my favorite of the style.

Bottle.  Pours a beautiful clear gold color with minimal head and lots of lacing.  Like most lagers it smells pretty bad; lots of grains, some yeast, hops and metal.  Tastes of grains and yeast with a very slight sweet background.  Finishes dry and bittersweet, not a great aftertaste but better than most lagers.  Drinkable and widely available, but nothing special here.

Bottle.  Pours a thin gold with minimal head and a skunky Beck’s type hops.  Flavor is heavy on skunky hops presence with a nice grain background.   Still, things are a little thin and rather unidirectional.
330ml bottle from Country Club Liquors; Nose is light caramelly grain; clear gold with a medium white head; flavor has graininess, very lught caramel and light yeastiness.
Bottle poured into a tulip like glass. Light color and higher carbonation with a decent head. Light and crisp but it is still light and not a whole lot of flavor. A bit grainy or yeast like in aroma.
bottle in mbar Helsinki. surprisingly rich and strong flavoured for the style. not at all typical. +++  long and strong aftertaste. something rotten though creeps in the background.
Good beer for the most part but an introduction to greater European light beers and that’s merely it.  The style and taste is weaker than Paulaner but the packaging and reputation is better.
bottle, golden color, yeasty aroma, mildly hoppy with a decent finish, not too watery
33cl bottle from Systembolaget Charlotteberg.  It poured a light golden color with a medium head. It has a bitter-sweet malty aroma. It has a watered down malty flavor.

very good brew for the mass produced. i like better than hiney but not as easily available or as cheap. had on tap very suprised how tasty it was. my dad introduced me to this but at 8.99 a sixer i only drink on occasion. or when available. very impressed. only real complaint is that the bottles are 11.2 ounces. i know... teh metric system but come on make it an even 12
Had this many times, but most recently last night on draft.  Very yeasty and hoppy aroma.  Pours light with small head.  Flavors are crisp with strong bites of yeast and hops, but not hoppy per se.
Draft. Clear yellow color with white head. Typical beer for everybody. Draft version is more better than canned. Not so metallic and more bitter.

0.33l bottle and draft.

Pours clear with lots of carbonation and clear white head.

Taste is metallic, generic lager, nothing great but better than most lagers available in normal UK pubs.

For some reason the Stella on tap in Belgium seems ten times better than the UK version.

Pours pale yellow, small head. Average aroma, nothing stands out. Smooth taste, the hops only slightly come through. Straightforward, decent beer, but nothing extraordinary about it. Typical pale lager, I prefer it to Heineken.

the best thing about the beer is the aroma strong yeast smell, the aroma that make people say wow i want a beer, maybe not a stella but a beer. it has a pretty yellow color and a nice white head. flavor is sort of bittersweet and little yeasty, but nothing interesting about it. Nice fizzy feeling in mouth but thats all. Overall its what it is another non interesting pale lager that sells well to the hip Manhattanites  that shop at whole foods.

Pretty much what I expected: Beautiful packaging, high-prestige marketing, boring Euro-lager. Though probably the best pale lager I’ve ever had, if that means anything. Overall another commercial dud.

Pours a clear golden colour, small white head. Mouthfeel is moderately carbonated, creamy and semi-wheaty. Aroma is a bit skunky. Hint of lemon, wheatgrass and hops. Taste is relatively light, and unexciting.

12 oz green bottle form local Food Lion.
Pours a clear very light straw almost yellow. Sweet aroma of light european malts with a bit of spicey noble hops. Touch of fruity yeast aroma, but no green bottle syndrome on this one. Slightly sweet light malt flavor with enough spicey hops to balance. Very clean and moderatly dry finish. Light mouthfeel with bit of carbonic bite. Nice clean lager.

A refreshing sort of beer that you can drink after a hard days work. Pale in color. Had a somewhat distinct taste to it, which wasn’t bad. Not 100% sure what the taste was because I had a couple of these at christmas time...
Bottle and draft. Very herbaceous nose, slightly sweet initial taste, but finishes with a dry, malty finish. Refreshing every-day session lager for people who are not lager fans.

330 ml bottle. Pours a clean golden color, foamy white head. Slightly sour, malty aroma. Taste is clean, with notes of sweet malts and just a touch of hops. Better than the macro-brewery stuff and good as a session brew.

Had this by the bottle at Chicago O’hare. Pours golden, with foamy white head that sticks around. No real aroma to speak of, except a small amount of hop. Feels and tastes like standard western civilization pale lager, though it is a step up from American Macros. More hop character than most large production beers, but generally forgettable.

Bottle @ Dave & Buster’s Denver. Pours golden with a nice foamy two finger white head. Aroma is sweet with notes of grass and citrus. Flavor is Slightly hoppy which is nice citrus with a mild malt backbone. Finishes clean and lightly bitter. Mouthfeel is light. As I am not a fan of this style, I found this to be one of the better offerings in the pale/light lager family, that is widely available.
Well brewed full flavored beer.  Always fresh and nver stale.  Very good introudction to wonderful Belgian beer.
Une très bonne bière qui ce boit quand on veux prendre une petite bière relaxe

Rating this out of the bottle, but I’ve had this on tap and its sooo much better on tap.  A little skunky right out of the bottle.  Very sparkling clear golden color.  Very clean tasting with a slight hoppyness in the aftertaste.  Nothing much to write about.  It’s ok I guess, much better than Miller or Bud.

[On draught at Warwick Arms, Reading]Initial taste is sourness; slight citrus came through, very little bitterness at all.  Sourness lasted right through the drink and for some time afterwards.  Can’t understand why this is so unaccountably popular, it’s ’orrible stuff!
330 ml green bottle. golden colour.  white head. taste is hop and bitterness. kind of dry aftertaste .
Pale golden color, malty sweet n sour nose, watery body, fresh hops and flowers on mouth with nice aftertaste.
Draft. Pretty soft smell of citrus. Watery mouthfeel with some mild flavours,not above average.

Pours a clear golden color with a white head that precipitates good lace.  Aroma is mild, with suttle hints of freshly mown grass and citrus.  Slightly malty at first giving way to a subdued hop flavor with mild bitterness.  The very delicate taste and subtle sweetness makes this beer very versatile.  Try with a delicate fish entree.
Pale golden yellow color whit medium white, a bit soapy and lacy head. Aroma is sweetish malty and hoppy. Flavor is sweet malty with some fruits and hops. Light-bodied and carbonated palate.
12oz bottle pours golden in color, nice white head, not too bitter and not too soft, a pretty decent import

4 beer sampler at Old Chicago Slightly bright and bitter aroma, light fizzy head, body is clear with a yellowish cast, crisp flavor, the initial bitterness is somewhat metallic, but the finish is better. Drinkable but lacks character - not one I would buy again
i didnt find this as pleasing as most of the rest of you did. maybe i have no taste i dont know
Really good drink.  Very even in its character.  Light on the palate, with a beautiful color and very pleasant taste, with just a hint of bitterness.  Very drinkable!!!!
Draft. Light amber with small, bubbly brief head. Aroma of wet fur - not necessarily a bad thing. Tastes of caramel and tar with nice lingering bitterness. Mouthfeel light, thin.

Bottle. Pours a yellow colour with a white head. Aroma is thin - some malts and hops. Flavour is just like the aroma - thin with some hops and some malty caramell. It don’t taste bad...I mean it do not taste much at all. Just boring!

First things first: a very nice beer!  Very popular here in the Northeast.  Available year-round in bottes and on tap.  Just a nice, crisp, clean and refreshing beer.  Drink very cold, however, can change to almost a Heineken flavor as it sits and warms.

I don’t get why everyone’s so gung-ho about this beer.  It’s everywhere here, and even more-so in Europe.  It’s not an American macro, but it’s not a whole lot better either.  This one’s watery, light, and unimpressive on all counts.

Pours like an American lager, with a bright yellow color and a bright white head that dissipates quickly.  Aroma is light hops with some grains and alcohol.  The taste is similar.  Mouthfeel is a little harsh, with a bit too much carbonation and alcohol in the aftertaste.  Can’t say I’m a fan.

330ml bottle. Pours a light gold with fluffy white head.  Nose is yeasty bread, light hops and a bit of skunk.  Palate is mild with malt, mild hop and a bit of grassy spice.  Watery thin mouth feel.  This beer is better on tap and better than the American light beers, but not that great.  Not sure why it’s so popular – I guess because it’s a trendy beer from Belgium that’s widely available.  Nothing special.

...well, this beer has much hype, but does not live up to it’s name.  Been around forever, before even the fake jesus.  Heavier than you would expect, but has a clean finish.  Not much to set it apart from the rest, other than the consistent quality from the real imported version.

Pours a pale gold/straw with little head. Doesn’t have much in the way of aroma, but what’s there is nice. I like the flavor. Clean, crisp, and well balanced. Finish is nice as well. Predictable but solid pale lager.
12 ounce bottle-  poured a light golden yellow with a stark white head.  Aroma was faint hops.  Taste ws extreamly mild, almost absent, with high carconation.  An average, forgetable beer,

Pours a lovely golden color, with an acceptable one finger head. The aroma is sweet and hoppy. Not much more than heavy malt and honey flavors here to give way to a semiclean finish. Surprised to see not much lacing in the glass.

A friend of mine inro’d me to this beer a few weeks ago, and I was impressed to say the least. It has a nice flavor and a very smooth finish. I’ve had good chicken and good pizza with this beer, and it goes well with both,

Rated:21.11.2007

Bottle green, 500 ml

Appearance:Pours bright golden, shiny, well filtered, clean body. Carbonation is soft, head is white with a shade of grey, medium, quickly decresing and mostly disappearing. Some traces of lacing.

Aroma:Alcoholic nose, chalky, oily, maildly, hoppy. Aroma is not complex, one dimentional but still good. Hops is well preserwed even after the expiry date and are without a note of skunkyness. A hint of licorice, cristalice honey, a bit malty but not yasty.

Flavour:Front is sweet, beer is easy going, smooth in texture, drinkable, honey sweetness, then hops with it’s bitternes are becoming present a on palate, than you can feel malty touch, though not strong. Well balanced flavour, mare sweetnes dominating at finish, finish duration is short.

Palate:Body is nice, texture is wattery to oily, carbonation on palate is soft, finish feel is grainy, sweet with some hoppy bitterness.
Good Grief...  Why is this even sold? It looks good in the glass, and is cold nd wet, and well, it is sold as beer. but.........  Actually it is better than the Key West Ale offered as an option.

Golden colored, light, this beer goes down very smooth with very little aftertaste.  Refreshing.  Slightly grainy and sweet.  I’d say this one is ideal for sitting out in the sun and not a bad session lager.
Dec. 2007 - Light pour with decent head and lacing.  Faint funky grassy type aroma.  Clean smooth malty taste with a decent amount of flavor from citrus and spices.  Easy drinking...not bad at all.
Tap. Yellow with white head. Some malt, some bitter, perfect beer to beat your wife. Not really worth the time, and not a premium import, imho

Pours a pale yellow with white head.  Smells of bitter malt, and is a bit skunky.  The skunkiness goes away as the head falls, replaced by the bitterness.  Tastes very bitter at the begining, then evening out.  Decent balance.  Medium body with mild carbonation.  A decent beer.

Bottle, 330 ml. Golden colour, head is not too big but has a good retention and lace. Nose is grain and herbs, not too much mention here. Light body, taste is clean, again grain, herbs and some unexpected sweetness. Very refreshing. I’ve tried this one many times, on tap too. Maybe Interbrew is doing a more massmarket beer of it, but it’s still good, maybe without the whole character it use to had years ago, but enjoyable yet.

Pour golden yellow, large head that the beer is characterized by. Kind of skunky, but fairly bland. Better than American macro brews, but at $8 a six-pack, why wouldn’t you buy something better for the same price?
I don’t understand why they are pushing this beer on the US market...  all the bottles I’ve tried over here are skunky.  And I’ve had quite a few.

Great beer. I really enjoy the crispness of the beer. Golden yellow coloured. Medium sized head. Easy to find on tap. Probably one of the most marketed Euro beers. Classic beer glass with gold rim easy to find.

This is a pretty decent beer, although not my favorite, it’s up there. I would have to say that it has a full crisp taste altough there is a strong aroma to it, it is very good with a meat dish. I would recommend it.

It is a good beer. their marketing must be great because you see it all over. Not quite up to the upper standards of Belgium beers but tasty none the less. A slight after taste pours rather poorly. Better then many massed produced beers. I have had it in the bottle as well as tap and they are very close in taste.
A lighter colored beer.  I honestly wasn’t a big fan of this one.  It left a nasty after-taste in my mouth.  Almost like a light, bitter wine taste.  Not for moi.

11.2oz bottle.  Pale yellow-golden color, completely transparent.  Aroma is doughy and fresh.  Very crisp mouthfeel.  Doughy and full of classic lager taste.  Sweet finish.  Simple, well-balanced beer.  Not a good example of a beer from Belgium by any standard, but an enjoyable session beer nonetheless.
The nose is the weakest part of this beer.  But I like the bread & yeast taste of this lager.   Not hoppy... and as most shudder... I like that.

A lot of people have recommended Stella to me, but I had yet to take them up on this until last night. I can’t say I was overly impressed, but it certainly wasn’t a bad brew.

Straw colored and clear, very little head.

Had a very light hoppy aroma.

Was a little bitter, but otherwise good.

Well balanced carb level and after taste.

Definately drinkable, I could have had a few more.

Serving type: bottle

Poured a golden color with two fingers of thick, fluffy head. The nose was bready with faint hops present. The taste was very crisp raw grain and hop taste hits up front. A sweet wheat aftertaste is present in the finish. Not a bad lager. Much better than most domestic offerings.

London
Bottled
Some malt and some bitterness but not much to impress
Unmaltet grain - corn?
Pours a pale yellow color with a minimal head.  A mild flavor of hops and bitters with a slight sweet finish. A good beer thats easy to find when there is nothing else.
Bottle. Pours pale yellow with medium head. Malty aroma with some saaz hop notes. Flavour is fresh and sprinkly with light malty notes and some hops.
Light Saaz aroma.  Brilliant straw with small white head and moderate carbonation.  A farily decent lager, that’s just not too interesting.  Like a budweiser with some zing.

Tap. Extremely light amber color. Small head. Aroma of hoppy water. Has a mild taste that does not leave any impressions and finishes clean with not taste. An ok beer if you want to get drunk..... i guess.....

Very pale yellow, slightly effervescent, minute head, disipates quickly, grassy, herbal aroma, pleasant. Foams quick and fast once it’s in your mouth. Dry bitter flavor, hops lingers. Better then BMC.

Bottle 0.275L. Pours yellow with a fluffy white head that don’t do much for it. Florar/herbal touch to the aroma makes it quite pleasant, along with some malt and hop. The flavor is quite herbal and malty one, with a touch of hop. Nice bitterness as it’s taken, also very subtle one in the aftertaste. Very nice pale lager! / Corpo amarelo com espuma branca fofa que não faz muito pela cerveja. Aroma com toque floral/herbal que o deixa bem agradável, junto com algo de malte e lúpulo. O sabor é bem herbal e de malte, com um toque de lúpulo. Amargor bom ao tomá-la, também um bem sutil no retrogosto. Pale lager muito boa!
Of bigger beers available on tap, this is not a bad way to go. Not bad at all.
Pale yellow color with a mediocre head. Aromas of mild hops and a little malt with a slight skunky aroma. Taste is mildly hoppy as well.

(Sample from August 25, 2006 Beer Club Meeting; 12oz bottle from World Market on March 17, 2008) This is usually what I get at a bar when the selections are Bud, Stella, Heineken, and some other American lager. I think I just like screaming "STELLA!" at the top of my lungs in public.  Yeah, I’m sure bartenders have never heard that one.  Pours a very white frothy head.  Lots of bubbles.  Has a semi-sweet smell to it.  Standard pale lager color.  Extremely light body with something in the taste that makes the toungue water - at least mine.  Has a pretty barnyard kinda fume to it.  This is probably one of my favorite lagers suited for mass-consumption, thanks to the fact that it’s available at just about every bar around here.

Tasted at the brewery tasting room in Leuven.
Corny grain flavor.
Strong Lager aroma.

Bottle from Kegs & Barrels in Plano, TX. Pours a light straw yellow with white head. Aroma of malt, hop aroma has slight skunk. Flavor is pretty basic, malt, hops, very faint hop bitter. Mouth feel is light body with high carbonation....Overall, pretty basic import lager.
Skunky with a little bit of grassy/hay sweetness. Hop flavor lacking. The beer is watery, but relatively smooth and dry. Very average brew.

11.2oz bottle courtesy of Double D.  German skunky smell though some mild sweetness involved.  Yellow with thin head, kind of bubbly.  Semi-sweet and kind of watery. Intense bitter aftertaste which lingers on.  My first Belgian (sort-of) left a lot to be desired.

Grassy nose.  Clear yellow-gold with a decent head.  Very herbal and grassy with some spicy hop bitterness.  Well carbonated, with a crisp finish, and a bit of lingering hops.  Good choice for an easy drinking beer.

Bottle.  Pours a golden yellow with a decent white head that fades away.  Aroma is of hops and grain.  Taste is of hops, a little bitter, kind of sweet and the finish reminds me of cream corn.  Not bad as it is fairly smooth, but I didn’t care for the way it finished.  Overall, this is a decent beer, but not that great considering the price and the way the commercials portrayed it.

Tap-Really nice poor in the Stella glass. Clear blond gold with great foam head and carbonation.  Mellow hop aroma with a sweet crisp taste.  Good going down and quite refreshing, a slight hop bite but overall decent Pale Lager.  Would try again.
Pale golden yellow color with an average head.  Smell starts off sort of Skunky and finishes sort of light.  Light taste with a thin body and it is sort of bland.
A classic blonde with a clean finish concludes this reliable lager experience.  Safe, not challenging.
Very light yellow, with a pillowy head. Crisp, with a hint of green grass bitterness. A decent alternative to an american pilsner type beers
defiantely one of the better light beers out there, and with increased distribution, its a good go to beer when out on the town.  crisp maltieness, good floral hop aroma.  good beer...

Green Bottle poured a clear gold with a lasting white head. Aromas of straw, dough, lighjt spice and a hint of citrus. Palate was light bodied and crisp. Flavors of straw and light citrus with a crisp clean finish. 
 One of the worst Belgian beers I’ve had.

A - Wheaty
A - Light yellow with white head
T - Medium dry finish
P - Watery, but very drinkable
O - The Bud of Europe
Yellow pour, actually nice head, potent hoppy aroma.  Very metallic, very one-dimensional.  Overrated.

Good light beer off-gold.  White fine foam.  Smells stronger than American macro-swill.  Taste is a good sharp hop with moderate malt.  Satisfying draught.  I remember first stumbling across this on tap at a waterfront bar in Seattle in 2005.  I liked it then, I like it now.

Stella is cliche these days.  It is commercial, but it’s not horrific.  It’s aroma is subtle.  It’s appearance is the  standard lager look.  It’s flavor, is average, consistent with the pale lager variety.  Palate is pleasant.  Nothing special here.
Bottle, 33 CL, when i opened this bottle i was surprised. Nice taste, nice color. It is very drinkable.

If I’m gonna go for something fizzy and yellow, I’d rather it be this.  Pale straw yellow with a foamy white head and good retention.  A faint nose of sweetness and a little skunk.  Has a little more flavor that American Pale lagers.  I really like the bitterness.  Thin body.  If this is the style you like, this is one of the better ones.

On tap at the Brick in Cedar Rapids.  Pours a clear, straw-colored pint with a rocky, thick white head. Bready aroma.  Flavor is a rather muddy blend of malt and hops--refreshing at first but a little skunky on the finish.

Bottle. Low and dense near-white head. Brilliant yellow/golden color. Clean, light bready aroma with a scent of citrus. Inoffensive and fairly sweet malt taste. Notes of sugar and mild bittering hops. Light-bodied and easy. Drinkable, boring and cleverly customized.
This beer pours and looks well in a glass but I’ve always found it skunky, whether bottled or on tap.
I have tried this beer via both keg and bottle.  I cannot get past the overwhelming skunk factor in this beer.  To me, the only redeeming quality of this beer is the pleasing color.

Nothing really to say about this beer.  It’s from Belgium, but isn’t recognizably Belgian, it’s basically a not adjunct version of a budweiser or a coors.  Not total garbage, but nothing to go out of your way for.
11.2 oz bottle: pours clear golden yellow with white head, aroma slighty musty aroma, flavor slight malt with tons of carbonation. very simple easy to drink if not looking for much of any flavor.
was turned onto this beer by a friend, strong flavor and good taste will drink if in the mood for a "good beer" and in a place with a limited selection

On-tap. Pours slightly cloudy yellow, white head of fine bubbles. Heads hangs around with good lace. Smell is subdued of sweet grains and corn. Tastes similar to how it smells, sweet and grainy and malty. Very light, sweet hops in the background. Medium body, coats the mouth a bit, crisp carbonation. Not a huge fan, it tastes like Heine.

Bottle.  Poured a clear, light gold color with good carbination and minimal head.  The aroma reminded me most of toast.  It had a light body with a thin/oily texture with lively carbination on the palate, with a minimal taste.  Overall this beer is drinkable, but I was not impressed.

This is what a simple lager tastes like when Belgians brew it.  There’s nothing that stands out about the flavor or appearance of this beer, but there’s just no fault that can be found with it either.  It’s just flawless lager craftsmanship, in the best traditions of Europe.  It tastes clean, thirst quenching and a little sweet.  It has exactly the right amount of carbonation and it’s head behaves perfectly.  That is, you get a bit of a head that dissapates relitively quickly.

I love pilseners. The keg is the proper source as the keg is a direct extension of the brewery. Bottles and cans are pasteurized. That changes everything and one can only say how true their experience was.

This beer is very satisfying for the style. I believe it is not a true pilsener as the following day after a few litres I have hangovers from this beer. I say this because I am suspicious that this beer is made with the addition of some type of sugar. Perhaps a light inverted sugar. I still love drinking it but a true pilsener will not cause pain for the small amount, such as 3 litres, consumed in an evening. I still recommend you find it on tap and hopefully the dispensing equipment will be clean.

Bottle; in namesake glass:  Pale golden with nice white head.  Typical eurolager traits of continental hops and bready pale malts in the nose.  Sweet/bitter with some grain.  Dry and soft, unbalanced.  A decent lager whose beautiful glass masks its average characteristics.
Meh, easy to drink, with the barest hint of hops in the flavor, but generally fairly metallic and unimpressive.  Better than the bud/miller alternatives if that’s all you can get.
clear golden bier with a 2 finger white head. metallic, musty aroma, even though it’s from a bottle. mild hoppy taste that’s a bit sweet. Watery consistency.
Pale gold with a white head, has an unpleasant musty hop aroma.  Flavor is not great, light musty hop taste.  Not very good.
pretty much your typical lager beer, better than your normal BMC stuff, nice crisp taste and easy to drink.
good lager beer, with a certain sweetness to it (not as bitter as most lager beers). Pale golden glow, 2 fingers of foam, excellent on a hot summer.
Golden yellow with a thick white head. Better than Heinekin with a more full taste. Good drinkibility and crisp finish.
Poured clear pale yellow with thick white head, very appealing.  Aroma was faint but plesant.  The taste was not overwhelming with very little after taste,  more like a light beer.
crisp taste, strange aroma but ok decent taste not my favorite but still an ok beer
A very disapointing lager. Heavily marketed in the Uk, but more famous for its ability to induce violent behaviour than its good taste.  AVoid.

Pours a lightly golden-clear, decent white head. Aroma was a bit bitter, a little bit sweet, almost lingering on marijuana-type odors. Taste is crisp and much better than it smells, but still nothing too great. Moderately hoppy. It does go down relatively smooth though. If you’re a fan of pale lagers, I’d suggest going for this one. If you’re a fan of beer, I’d suggest staying away.
Oh my God, what a yawn. What a great big long yawn of a beer. I mean seriously. I can hardly be bothered to describe it. There’s just not much to describe.

tap, smelled a bit hoppy but really didn’t taste it at all. kind of a dry beer. good carbonation and great lacing. this is a good middle of the road beer for me. it’s not awesome but it’s not bad either.
