Light and crisp this is a good beer to finish a long night off with. I have also heard that the European version varies from what I can get in the states.

An Excellent crisp beer taste. Refreshing with a perfect amount of aftertaste. It has all of the flavor that domestic light beers can only hint at because they are light beers. It’s one of the best I’ve had in this style.
Easy drinkin’ without sacraficing flavor.  Smooth and a little crisp.  Touch of apple.  Usually get bottles, but on-tap at the right place it’s even better.

Proclaimed as the best Belgian beer. I dont necessarily agree.Its the most popular with comman drinkers because of its soft flavors. Its a decent beer that pours well with a nice head, but the flavor for a belgian leaves a lot to be desired. I would say best banquet beer.
On tap Fort Myers Airport. I had never heard of this beer before. Wiatress suggested it. Nice gold colormedium head. Slight fruit scent. Smooth taste. Liked it and would order it again.

Bottle.  Not overly impressed or excited about this one.  Pours smoothly with a little head. Golden-yellow coloring but pretty bland for the hype it got from some of the people I know.  Probably would drink it again if offered one, but would not buy it.
Pilsen above of the average. Dense cream, interesting aroma and average carbonation.
Garrafa. Coloração dourada, com um creme consistente no início, mas não tão persistente. Paladar leve, agradável, refrescante. Lúpulo e malte no aroma e no sabor, além de um leve metálico.

This beer is heavily marketed and readily available in this area. This is a very clear yellow lager with a half inch of white head. Not particularly lacey for a Belgian but predictable for a light (underscore light). The taste has a bit of malt but more of a fast light bitter flavor that finishes quick. On tap or bottle this beer is best served cold. For those looking for a light lager and a new label try it out. This isn’t rocket science just a light beer that should appeal to those who don’t like Dark, Belgians, IPA’s well pretty much not many beers.

You know you are in a shitty bar when you find yourself weighing up a Stella or a Pripps blå, I hadn’t rated the former so it got the nod. Pale as you would expect, white head. Aroma is plain, a little grainy with some light (but decent hops), nothing else really, the flavour follows the same line... perhaps a little sweeter than I remember. Finish is snappy, nothing too shocking.
Draft.  Not much aroma, but noticed some grainy malt.  Palate and aftertaste are smooth, but flavor is bland.

Bottle. Yellow golden beer with a white head. Slight mineral, earthy aroma. Very mineraly flavor with some spice and earth. Lingering mineral tones. Medium/lighter bodied. Grainy. Something just doesn’t sit right.

Bottle: Very pale body with very white head that disappears quickly.  Aroma is very toasty with noticable spicy hops.  Starts out like an above-average pale lager, with hints of sugarcane, then hits with just enough hops to balence the beer for a moment, before going back to the boring sweetness.  Decent body, dull finish...
Memphis-Draft.  Think White head with tiny bubbles. Sweet apple flavor with a dry finish. Perfect with some dry BBQ ribs!!
Nothing special and definately not worth the price I paid for it. May appreciate it more in warm weather since it IS pretty light and refreshing.

bottle - Pours a very clear light golden color with a 1/2 finger thick white head.  Very light spotty lacing.  Has a grassy, herbal hop and grainy malt aroma.  Sounds like a broken record, don’t it?  Has a lightly sweetened grain malt flavor.  Medium body.  Easy drinking Pale Lager.  Nice.
over-priced over-rated belgium import . . to buy one at a bar is fine, paying $30 for a case is ridiculous for this beer.

Bottle. Pale golden color with sparkling happy bubbles. Thin white head. The smell is sour and yeasty with notes of apple pie. Sweet light flavor, like watered down apple cider. Not much of a mouth feel. Good for drinking for the sake of drinking.

I’ve tried this in a bottle and on draft and both times this beer was a little disappointing compared to what one would usually expect from a Belgium. Very average. Would prefer something with more flavor especially for the price.

I was surprised to see this beer rated quite this low.  While is certainly isn’t as complex as many beers, I find it at least as interesting as someting like Pilsner Urquell.  It only came to North Carolina around 2005 so maybe it’s still a novelty for us.
Very average beer poured yellow with a small white head, with lacing on the glass through out.  Not much to this especially for the price.

On tap at the Cheesecake Factory in King of Prussia Mall.  Pours a translucent yellow with an average size foamy white head.  Light floral and grassy aroma with some grains, citrus and European hops.  Flavor of corn, grass, sweet grainy malts, light hop bitterness, some metallic and cooked vegetables.

Sweet aroma, with a hint of hops hiding in the background.  Pours a clear light amber, with little head.  The flavor is a hint of sweet, with an underlying aftertaste I can’t identify.  Drinkable... but not something I’ll go for if there’s anything better.

On tap. pours out a light very light yellow. topped with a white head. WOW the aroma ya nothing there to talk about. Ya but what about THE TAST just the same not much going on. well overall it is a pale lager.

Got this one in tossed in from a trade with a co-worker. Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a pint glass, light golden with a thin white head. Not much aroma, maybe a hint of baled hay and hops. The taste was grassy with notes of hay and grain. Very, very thin and watery. Not much here. It would truly be a shame if those drinking this regularly thought this was representative of good Belgian beer.
Overall not a bad tasting beer on draft.Not one of the belguins best but worth trying.Nice gold color and a nice hops aroma.  Would recomend .

clear golden color with a modest frothy white head.
smells hoppy and lemon. a touch of clove
tastes very clean. hoppy. very mild with almost no aftertaste.
mouthfeel is very smooth.
very very drinkable. this is a session beer for sure.

I think this beer is overrated and underrated at the same time. It’s very overrated by people who aren’t into beer too much, but it’s also made lesser by a lot of connoisseurs. IMO, It’s a perfectly moderate beer. It has a lot of flavor and body for a pale lager. Unfortunately, at some bars, this may be the best they have. And I would much rather have this than Heineken or Amstel and what not.
a good all around lager it’s not expensive and it’s easily obtainable. Agreed, it’s nothing fantastic or groundbreaking, but it’s still enjoyably crisp.

Pours a pale gold with a decent, albeit brief, thick white head.  Aroma of floral hops and mulching wet grass.   Smooth crisp mildly hoppy taste with sweet malt dominant.  A pretty decent Euro pils which at least attempts to remain true to the original Czech stye, unlike the more common northern European renditions.

Can. Head was small with a white slightly frothy sparkle. Spare lacing. Clear slightly sparkling body. Color was pale yellow. Aroma was light hay, straw, grain, grass. Light bodied with a thin texture and an average carbonation. Light sweet flavor with light notes of bitterness. Short finish.

It’s a cheap beer, but for it’s price it has nice taste. It’s a good every day beer if you don’t have the money to go out to the tavern every single night to get more expensive beer. It’s color is a rich golden with some frothy white head on top.

Had it on tap at local bar,James Joyce.It had a decent head.color was straw.Had that golden beer taste,that I don’t like,but also had some deeper flavors of chewy hops and rice.Wouldn’t buy it again,but it was at least worth trying.
This is my everyday beer. I like it, it’s not expensive and it’s easily obtainable.  Agreed, it’s nothing fantastic or groundbreaking, but it’s still enjoyably crisp.

Draught from The Outlook poured into a really tall ass mug - Pours gold with a 1 finger frothy white head; Lots of malt to the nose with a hint of some hops; TONS of malt along with corn and rice on the initial taste; Some light grassy hops on the aftertaste; Watery body; Little carbonation for a pale lager; Basic. No biggie.

Finally had a Stella Artois and it was under whelming.  It had a nice hop aroma but not a lot of hops were found in the flavor.  There was a corn flavor that was too typical of the style.  It had a crisp dryness.

The beer was light golden in color, with a thin white head. Not much of an aroma at all.

Some mild hops character up front, but no lasting hop impression. I guess it is nicely balanced, but still a bit thin for my taste.

Nice smooth mouthfeel with a crisp, dry finish.
Bottle. Poured a clear golden color with alot of carbonation. Armoa is nasty and can’t even pick it out. Taste is nasty also.
Decent.  It certainly tastes better than it smells, but I’d say it is beter than average.
Not the typical belgian beer that you would normally think of. It is just a good lager, nice clean taste and clear golden color. Good in the summer

I rarely give low scores.  But why waste your time on stella when you can have better belgium beer.  If your going to have one, drink it with a hamburger or something, otherwise, I wouldn’t waste my time looking for it, especially in a 100+ tap beer pub.
What a disappointment this beer was...yellow pour, with a big pure white head that reminded me of wool.  Skunky corn aroma.  Not much taste, except for the bit that hits you in the finish.  Watery.

Wife beater. Nuff said. Same old bog standard bulk brewed lager. Why this has become the British Lager of choice is intresting - the advertising campaign of expesive reasurence tapped into the upwardly aspirational attitueds of working-class drinkers of the late 80’s ant the same time as they shifted from the ’lower-class’, older image bitter to the ’younger’ larger beers. Stella has tried to repossition itself of late as a Belgian ’craft’ beer - the artois Bock brand brewed for the UK market, the new stemed branded glass, and 1950’s style ads - because in a survay Stella charted twice: at No1 as Stella Artois and at No7 as Wife Beater. Here endeth the leason.

on tap. various bars in nyc. people love this. people all over the world love it. well it’s not much better than the beers of my country (El Salvador), and those are the lowest rated beers i have ever entered on rate beer. If your thirsty on a summer day after mowing the lawn and you have no water, then drink this.

First time I had this was out of a plastic cup from a bottle at 1 a.m. in a dive bar. Made a quick judgement that I hated it. Months later I work at a bar that serves this beer on tap out a glass. Now I pay attention: Still nothing special to report, but I can atleast give this lager some props. I definitely crave it on warm/hot day in the NC mountains. Definitely refreshing and crisp. You’ll have to pay attention to the light spice that hits you in the end, but it’s there. It’s a Belgian brew, not in the "traditional" sense, but you get that nice kick in the back of the throat. Definitely a refreshing, carbonated and crisp beer for a warm day.

bottle . . deffinently over-priced . . but not a bad flavor . . but if im going to spend 7.00$ on a 6-pack i mine as well pick up something from a smaller brewer i havent tried . . but if this beer is around at a bar, its deffinetly a good choice . . very refreshing
overpriced, it has a decent taste though, very smooth and dry leaves pallete with slight malt after taste.
Pours effervescent with sticky head.  Dry, grassy, tinny, "ice-cold" flavour of a beer expecting friends to follow it down the chute.  Good with food.

On Tap at The Firkin in Glen Ellyn. Poured into the trendy gold-rimmed Stella branded glass. Golden yellow with firm white head. Smells hoppier than it tastes. This is a refreshing beer, but not at all up to the standards of Czech pilsners. A decent beer, but there are far better options.
Bottle. Golden colour with a white head. Aroma is fruit, malt. Flavour is fruit, malt, hay, dry.
Very refreshing. I definitely prefer draft to bottle. Easy to drink. Nice head for suck a light beer. A good palate cleanser between more potent beers
Man. This was bad. Smelled bad. Looked bad. Tasted bad. Just plain bad. Maybe I got a skunked 6 pack? I am not willing spend money on another to see.

Not a lager kind of guy, but I’d drink this over AB if I had the $$$ and a crappy(see less sophisticated) taste in beer.  THe other reviews say it best...but this one seems to have nice mouthfeel, and it is a great alternative to the same ho hum lager alternatives if available.

Ótima cerveja Pilsen, vendida long neck, refrescante e suave, não muito forte. Possui copo próprio para degustação porém é melhor beber na garrafa. Aliás garrafa esta que vem com menor quantidade das long necks normais. Coloração amarelo claro, bonita de se ver em sua garrafa verde. Gosto agradável, com predominância do gosto amargo do lúpulo, está entre as preferidas para dias de calor. O chopps é mais leve que um da Brahma porém é facilmente confundido. Valor de mercado alto, média de valor sendo o dobro das populares./////. Nice beer - pilsen, light, refresh, not strong. Good color.
I’ve had this from the bottle and on tap. I prefer it on tap. Pale yellow color tastes quite light and watery.

Bottle, from mug. Best before end of Jun ’07. White frothy head atop a crystal clear, very pale yellow body; a tiny bit of lacing. Skunky aroma hits you as soon as you pour it. A closer whiff reveals...cabbage. Mouthfeel is predictably thin, but somehow escapes being completely watery. Flavor is a bit metallic, but there is a very slight bite of hops. Finishes short and lightly bitter. It’s a Pale Lager, what can you expect?

I first tried this beer about 3 years ago when I was relatively young and uneducated (well I still am but anyhoo) and thought it tasted like a pilsener and thought it was bloody terrible... Now though, I taste the distinct difference to a pilsener and am quite enjoying it. A brilliant head formed at first but soon disappeared. The taste seems somewhat bitter; something I like in a beer.
Crisp, refreshing, and quality.  I recommend this brew whenever a pale lager is demanded for the occasion.  Good stuff.

12 oz bottle via Roth’s. Pours a crystal clear golden blonde with an average size white head. Nose is a stale grass & some yeast, and a slight skunkiness. Taste is pretty mellow. Starts sweet, some grassy hops, wheat, and ends with a mild spiceness. High carbonation and light body. Does not taste fresh. Green bottle curse strikes. Not much to say except that it is an above average but unfresh pale lager. I imagine fresh this would be very good.
The "good beer" that all the discriminating young professionals drink. Doesn’t taste like anything, but their glasses sure are pretty, with that gold band, and all. This product stinks on ice.

From my tasting notes at an "earlier" date.  On tap @ Old Chicago.  I remember the bartender was pretty excited to sell me this Belgian style beer, and then I tasted it and thought "pilsener," and he said, "No it’s a Belgian style," and then I realized in most establishments people like us will know a buttload more than people trying to sell us stuff.  Poured a clear golden with a creamy moderate white head--in the proper Stella glass.  The aroma was grassy and grainy, though cannot fully be rated due to dumbass smokers around me (I gave it a bonus point for that--it isn’t the beer’s fault).  Flavor is of Saaz, cereal grain, some sweetness in there with a moderately bitter biscuity finish.  Sharp carbonation, light in body.

This beer seems like it’s been popping up everywhere lately, so I figured I’d give it a try. And it’s the least impressive Belgian beer I’ve ever had.

It pours a yellow amber, lighter than a Pilsner Urquell but darker than a Beck’s. Head formation is inferior to both those other lagers, and Stella is pretty fizzy.

It smells very slightly of Saaz hops and tastes like a really boring European lager. That European sulfur-y skunky taste is pretty minimal, and the taste is not unpleasant.

Mouthfeel is OK - not too thin and carbonation feels about right to me. This is not a bad beer, but I can’t really fathom a reason to drink it in lieu of something else given the world full of better alternatives we have before us.

This isn’t my week for brew. Bottled, this "best of Belgium" came with a boquet of mildly floral wheat, with hints of new-mown lawn. The flavor was nothing at all remarkable--a tad wheat with the expected new-mown grass flavorings and a mildly floral-hoppy finish. A drinkable lager, salvaged from absolute mediocrity by the bit of warming provided by a decent--though not spectacular--alcohol content.

Mid-golden, clear with moderate carbonation. A small, white head fades quickly to a thin film yet laces in small, sporadic splotches. I’m glad I haven’t rated Stella ’til now because these bottles came in a sealed 12 pack which helped to protect the thin green bottles from being lightstruck. Sharp hops produce an aroma which borders on being glandular... it’s easy to see how a few hours exposure to the UV spectrum could push it over the edge. Otherwise, the nose finds day-old grass clippings with a few flower petals sprinkled on top. As the beer warms, a stray dog pees on aforementioned pile of cut grass. Flavor finds the appearance of sweetish pale malt under the dominant presence of saaz. Finishes mostly crisp with a touch of lactic sourness. Even though it’s fresher than I’ve had in the past, Stella is still far from the "Best of Belgium" it is being sold as (currently ranked 87th out of my 93 ratings of Belgian beers).


From my brother-in-law at Christmas in a misleading "Best of Belgium" 12 pack.
Bottle. Clean golden colour with a small short lasting white head. Aroma is hoppy and bit malty. The taste is well balanced with malts and hops. Thin mass produced pale brew.

Imagine the gentle rain falling on the plains of Flanders.  Imagine majestic horses striding across these plains, sipping the gentle rain from babbling brooks.  Imagine these horses urinating into green bottles and crafty Belgians slapping a label on them.  Boom.  I give you Stella.

Strong hoppy aroma. Light head with some lacing. Pale, golden color. Sweet, malty flavor with a light body. Hints of honey and floral notes. Smooth and lightly carbonated. Bitter finish. Overall, an average, decent beer.
Bottled. Sub standard belgium beer. This is what belgian beer is not about. Boring pale yellow colour with a semilasting head. Malty flavour with a hoppy finish.
Bottled and tap in Belgium.  BASIC beer.  Simple and pedestrian across the board.  Just an everyday pub bier in Europe but if you’re in the States spend your money on something better.

This beer is a great alternative to Budweiser no doubt.. costly but worth it. So much more depth than any macrobrew crap here.  Good beer to party with if you got the cash..This beer is Heineken’s twin sister
Bottle into lager glass - An average beer that is definitely overhyped. Nothing really special about it. I like it in a "It’s iiight." kind of way...

Dull is the best word to use to describe this lager.  Pours a chalky gold and despite this picture at the top left this beer has no head.  The flavor is forgettable and well dull.  Its slightly stronger than US macros but that doesn’t make it better.  Thanks to interbrew this stinker hogs tap space at chain restaurants all across America.  The thing I hate most about eating out in this country is how our choices are limited either bud, miller, coors or crappy imports like Heineken, Amstel, or this piss.
Nice poor, pale golden with nice bit of head.  Bit of a strong finish.  A good choice when found on tap with the macro brews.
Both the wife and I thought this beer was spoiled. We love Belgians. We asked for a sample and that was enough.
Crisp and hoppy with some descent flavor but very average and not really impressive. Good for those pick up a sixer on the way to the party beers.

Bottled. Clear, pale golden with a nice carbonation and a decent white head. The aroma has malt, hay and some hops. Thin body with a flavor of grain, malt, grass and hay. Bland finish with some hops. Nice lacings. Nothing special to this one. (061215)
A great intro beer into euros, but otherwise rather lacking. Reasonably crisp and definitely sessionable, but doesn’t leave you wanting more

For a macrobrewery it’s ok, but there’s better macrobreweries. Pale beer, pours with a good head which dissipates almost immediately. Medium bitterness with malty flavour, lightly hopped finish. The finish is better than the initial flavour. Easily obtained almost anywhere. Definitely not something to go out of your way for.

Pale straw coloured beer, very clear. Head dissipated rapidly. Very low malt and hop aroma - saaz, not particularly pleasant.
Medium bitterness dry, low carbonation not fitting with style - perhaps due to intial big pour to attain head.
Sweetness coming through after a third mouthful, good balance, morish.
Slight tingling on the tip of the tongue, possibly some phenolic fault - possibly from grain.
After warming a light hop aroma comes through of blueberries.

not bad and maltier than other pale lagers I’ve had.  Pretty light and not really anything special. However, it’s  unoffensive and since it’s pretty common, Stella’s a nice alternative to typical sports-bar swill.

I tried this at Charlie’s Ale House in Chicago. It was pretty good for me. Light tasting at first, with a bit of a bite at the end. A good starter beer for one such as myself...I have to admit with previous commenters. Its fun to say and you feel kind of cool ordering it!
Very good flavor. Makes you feel classy at the bar drinking beer out of a gold rimmed glass.
Nothing fancy, just a solid beer without any fancy bells and whistles. Good choice for the value.

This truly fell short of expectations. The varaint flavour in the brew all seem to be doing their own thing without maintaining any sort of balence. Its fine golden appearance can be quite misleading once tasted. Quite a dissapointment.
This beer is my Budweiser. I drink this instead of Bud or Miller products. Nothing radical about this beer, just makes you sound snobby at a local watering hole when you say "Artios"

There is nothing about this beer that separates it from lots of the other lagers in the supermarket.  It simply tastes like a somewhat malty beverage to wash down whatever food you have.  Not really anything that I would necessarily enjoy.  On the other hand, there was nothing offensive at all either.
I’m honestly not a big fan of this beer.  Maybe I’m just past the whole pale lager thing but Stella certainly didn’t wow me in any way.
Great taste, but just simply overpriced.  I’d go for a St. Pauli Girl just as soon as I’d go for a Stella.
Pours a clear piss yellow body with no head. Aroma is bitter, bland malts. Mouthfeel is thin with notes of carbonation overpowering the offensive and bland flavors. Average alcohol content.

It’s interesting...the first time I had this it was at a fancy restaurant and I hadn’t heard of it before.  I had it on draught, and thought it was quite nice.  Not clear yellow...more clear orange, or soft amber...creamy head, and champagne-like bubbles.  Strong aroma, great amount of bitterness for balancing the sweet malty flavor.  A nice beer.  
But since then I realized it’s a VERY common beer, and no one considers it very good.  It’s not bad.  At all.  Repect this brew, but don’t think it’s the best shit ever...

Not bad, not great. Poured a clear yellow at the bar with a thin white head. Got this because my friend loves it and she recomended it. I liked it better then most 
American macros a little yeasty action going on in there and then the refreshing crisp finish. Not a bad session beer for the money.

On tap at the Trivia Pub in Moon Twp.  Very clear pale yellow pour.  Good initial flavor and a Lemony yeasty cirus aroma.  A little hop bite with less than average carbonation.  Clean finish. Kinda like your typical pale yellow american beer, but perhaps a bit more refined. On equal footing with Michelob and Miller High Life, perhpsa a step behind.
One of the better pale lagers out there.  Clean, grainy taste with light hops on the finish.  Pleasant.
This is a pretty good beer. It’s got a weaker taste but manageable. Nice head on it too.
Average beer, nothing outstanding nothing "bad". Some what similar to mass domestic beers.  Looks and pours like Budwiser with the head a bit thicker and lasting a little longer.
Decent imported ale.  Aroma acidic, almost like vinegar with some bread and yeast present.  Medium body.  Bold golden yellow pour with a nice frothy white head.  Nice session brew.

12oz bottle, from a friend. Nose is mild with a hint of sweets, overall taste is rather "chemical" not a bad brew, i enjoyed it more as it warmed up a bit towards the 50*+ mark for the price cant complain not a bad brew.
Draft. Had a couple f these on vaction in Charleston. Typical imported lager. Not outstanding but, very drinkable and pleasant. Probably enjoyed it more becaue of where I was and who I was with.

My grandpa and I used to love to grab 2 ice cold bottles of Stella and just sit and chat while enjoying a head healthy, mildly sweet smelling, and damn enjoying beer that is crisp, clean and very refreshing! Right OPA!...not a bad specimen on tap.
A very enjoyable lager.  I have no problems with it.  Maybe the flavor isn’t distinct enough but its definitely good tasting.

330ml bottle - pours golden, bubbly, and clear. Aroma is slightly sweet, a touch grainy/bready...quite light. Taste is also sweet, but much more "full" than other macro lagers. Some small trace of hops (though subtle and you sort of have to look for it). As a lawn cutting, BBQ beer, this would certainly do the trick and there is nothing offensive about it. There’s just nothing all that exciting about it either. This style isn’t really my thing, but for what it is, it’s done decently with no real noticeable problems. It’s a basic pale lager, nothing more, nothing less, and certainly not the super-special ultra premium majestically regal thing they try to market it as.

bottle.  light clear and straw colored.  lively carbonation.  Aroma is grainy and lightly sweet, not much in the way of hops.  Taste is lightly sweet and grainy, with a clean finish.  better than the macro lagers bud miller coors but not something I personally would drink very often.

Draft at Hooters:  Light gold color with a white foamy head.  Aroma of hops.  Taste was of bland, stale hops.  Reminded me of an American mega brew beer, but with a particular european end.  I geuss it was "OK", but not as other lagers.  Drinkable I suppose, but not impressive.

Draft.  Light yellow with foamy head.  Definite mineral aroma and flavor.  Light and refreshing with citrus and mineral flavors.  Not very bitter or hoppy.  A nice refreshing lager.  Probably over-rated and over-exposed today, but not without merit.
On draft at Cheesecake Factory.  Pours golden with chunky white head that quickly dissolved.  Bready aroma.  Flavor was of grains and very yeasty.  Thin and watery with a nice bite of carbonation.
Medium-gold color, and a quickly-fading white head. Mild, leathery aroma. Flavor is hoppy, but I can detect some malt, as well. Finishes quick, with just a hint of bitterness lingering on the tongue.
Tried it on tap, nice tasting beer,very enjoyable, one of the better imported beers. yet to try it bottled.

This lager gets a bad press in the UK due to its strength and consumption by hooligans (its often coined "a pint of wifebeater").  However, as mainstream lagers go, its one of the best, along with Kronie.  Very pale yellow in colour, but strong and distinctive and hoppy in taste.  Not bad

AN excellent pale lager. It is not perfection as the ads claim, but it certainly tastes pretty good albeit not really complex. For some reason this beer tastes different in every country I tried it, from Italy to England to the United States. Typically though, when the beer is on tap it is the best beer in the bar (well not always).
Bottle on Halloween in Santa Barbara. Used to drink these in Brussels all the time. Just a pale lager, exported as more than. Nothing special, watery with a bit of a fruity, apples taste.

Argentinian licensed version to Quilmes: Pours a clear pale yellow color. Medium white fluffy head. Medium retention too. It diminishes into a good lacing.
Aroma is nothing special. It smells like a good lager with a little of malt, some shy hops and notes of fresh herbs, cereal grains and green apples. Clean and crisp as expected.
Flavor is slightly sweet with a soft bittersweet finish. Lots of fresh herbal notes and apple taste. A tiny metallic note detracts from this unfortunately.
This is a light refreshing drink. Thin to medium body, fair carbonation. Texture is watery but nice. Metallic finish. Not a bad lager but still has some ’Quilmes’ on it. Pretty much a crisper Heineken.


Brought in Mendoza, Argentina
On tap in fancy glass as standard. Very nice beer good easy drinking and throughly enjoyable.I enjoyed it one of the better premium beers.

Better than your average macro. Bought in tallboy can. Golden colour with body that is more on the simple side, but somewhat complex. Average beer with a kick. Tastes like a generic pale ale with a good exterior.
Bottle. Very approachable Lager. Golden color with fizzy head that quickly dissipates. Pleasantly bitter aftertaste that is not overpowering.  Crisp and refreshing.

Typical pale lager except for the price.  Can find myriad beers in this price range that are way superior.  Better than Bud or Miller, but thats not really saying a hell of a lot, is it?  Do yourself a favor if you like this style and buy a Pilsner Urquell and save some money, AND have a better beer.

This is a very average Belgian Lager. There is nothing wrong with it at all, but it just doesn’t impress either. It has a nice golden color, with an average sized head. The aroma is slightly hoppy, but not overpowering at all. The flavor is nothing to write home about. It is a solid lager, with a slightly hoppy flavoring and a watered down pilsner quality to it. Definitely not worth the price.
Although i like this lager, its abit too bold, as you only get the first nice sip, then the strong beer after taste.  It looks good, strong yellow colour, not very bubbly, with big head
never will... never have... dont think ever want to like this over priced bland skunky lager
An excellent belgian lager.  Like beck’s, it is strongly bitter with a hoppy flavor, but not as much as an IPA.  Worth a try.
Drank with Stegosaurus and Beereded_one at Newton brew fest. Eh not much to say about this. Skunky aroma with hints of corn. Some fruity tastes. It’s quite crappy.
Bottled at home. Simple lager very popular in Flemish part of Belgium. Pale yellow with big white head. Refreshing and enjoyable to drink.
A very satisfying beer. Goes down smooth and has a flavor that I cant quite place in any other beer. I would definately drink it again.
Definately one of the best lagers out there. Crisp and refreshing. Up there with my favourite Lagers. Popular for a good reason

A very pale yellow in color,with a very thick snow white head, with decent lacing.  A very faint smell of hops and a somewhat sweet smell.  Mouthfeel was light, medium bodied, carbonation decent and very fizzy.
This beer was sampled after allmost a month at sea, where there was no beer available.  So for quenching my thirst and a "COLD BEER" it served it’s purpose.  Overall it tastes like most of the "EURO" Lagers.  Would i buy it upon my return to the states, probably not.

From a bottle in a chilled mug: Pale gold and fizzy. Very weak, cereal aroma...virtually nonexistant, like the thin white head. Taste is surprisingly dry and refreshing. As the mug warms, this becomes somewhat watery. Definitely not as good as I’d hoped.

On keg. Sampled with Finn at the Hole in The Wall, Waterloo. Bright straw yellow. Small white head. Some fruity notes in aroma and taste, but hardly nothing more than sweet sugar water. Frail bodied (18.09.2006).
Bottled. A refreshing lager, with a soft fruity aroma. On the sweet rather on the dry side. Not great, but far better than many.
Draught at Hole In the Wall London SE1 18 Sep 06. Pale golden coloured. Watery. A pretty white lasting head. Aroma of hay. Dry bitter flavour. Unpleasant.
bottle. very pale yellow color. large fluffy head. corn acidy aroma and taste. very thin and usual. allmost nonexistent.
A pale blond color. Light cereal aroma. A lager similiar to 1664. The hop character was slightly less appealing, and maybe a little less malt flavor. Not really complex, but refreshing.

Draft.  Aroma:  Not much.  Light graininess and maybe a hop.  Appearance:  Classic pale lager: golden yellow and clear.  White head was full and frothy with decent retention.  No lacing.  Flavor:  Light cereal grains, cooked vegetables, a touch of hop spice.  Bland.  Palate:  Light bodied and watery.  High carbonation.  Overall:  To say that this was better than a BMC beer, is like saying lethal injection is better than the electric chair.  They’ll both kill you, but maybe the injection won’t be as painful.  The only strong flavor in this was an off flavor of cooked vegetables.

The so called "Wife Beater", but it doesn’t matter, it really is a great tasting beer.  Has a sweet and sour aroma with a tint of spring juniper blossom.  The taste is brilliantly simple and light despite having a rich and memorable palate.

Had one of these at a friend’s party last night.  12 oz green pop-top bottle.  I’m really not sure what all the buzz is about this beer.  It is an average beer with average characteristics.  Nothing very memorable for me.  It is lacking in flavor and comlexity.  However, it is fairly clean, smooth, and refreshing.

I’ve also had this beer on draught in the past.  I think it is better from a tap.  It seems to be smoothier and decidedly less "skunk" funk.
Bottle.  Color is a light yellow.  Minimal aroma and taste.  Not very complex.  Some malt and hops taste.  Bland.  Good for style, but not saying much in my opinion.

Draft at some pub in Princeton, because Triumph Brewing closed the brewpub to the public for a Party. Pours straw gold, with white head and tons of large carbonation bubbles. Faint aroma of sweet cereal. Flavor of creamed corn with a very slight hint of spicy hops on the finish. Seltzer water mouthfeel. Macro type beer trying to pull it off as a premium, like Heineken.
Bottle. Medium head with medium duration. Color is light golden to yellow. Aroma is mainly malt. Taste is sweet and malty.
Not much taste nor aroma. A little more body than typical BMC lager. An imported "lawn mower" beer.
Had it on tap, poors a golden color with a thick head. Very smooth in taste lacking bitterness. Not a very complex taste, but good and refreshing on a hot day.

(11.2 oz bottle (best before end 2/07) from Belfast Co-op) Pours very clear pale yellow with large frothy white head. Aroma initially skunky, then as head recedes shows some honey then finally becomes sort of sour. Hmmm. Mouthfeel thin, a little blunt. Sloppy spots of lacing. Weak honey malt flavor, finishes weakly bitter. Weak.
Highly recomended beer! Lovely head, great hoppy flavour. Very refreshing sweet after taste. Clearly one of the best beers going around at the moment.
Draft. Decent aroma with slight bitterness dedected. Good appearance, decent size head that stays. Decent flavor but nothing too special. Taste dies quickly and my tongue begged for something more.

Poured from the can (as part of a blind lager tast test - probably my worst drinking night ever). Very pale. A very metallic aroma. Grassy hops in the mouth and very dry. (For the record, and not surprisingly, I got only 1/6).

Biggish creamy white head shrinks rapidly, leaving coarse lacing. Pale yellow body with ongoing carbonation. Faint papery, grassy aroma. Smooth, fruity taste with hoppy grass notes and some chalk. Aftertaste is grassy bitterness and some chalk. Clean, some hops. It’s OK. (0.3l on tap.)

Clear yellow with a nice head when poored from a bottle.  Smells sweet with some slight off notes.

The flavor is a nice balance between hops and malt.  This beer always tastes slightly skunked to me, but I like it anyway.

Draught. Golden with white head.  Sweet, malty and slight hoppy aroma. taste is sweet, amlty and fresh. Had it at a bar watching football (soccer) and it went down quite fast along with some of it’s mates. Boring beer, ok pale lager.

Stella Artois
12 oz bottle
Recent bottling, gulped down 09/06
Medium pour in a pint glass

Poured a clear bright yellow with an average rocky mostly diminishing white head with good lacing.

Smelt of sweet grain and rice.

Taste was upfront light grapefruit rind bitterness followed by a moderate bitter sweet cereal kick that shortly lingers.  Mouthfeel was light, watery, overly fizzy and moderately astringent

Overall, just some average European pale lager, nothing special here.
Bottle. Clear yellow colour with a white head. Malty and hoppy aroma. Flavour is malty with a bitter finish.
I don’t know why but I was expecting something better. Very light and fizzy, minor hop flavor and mild malt sweetness. Otherwise sort of bland.
Green bottle corn stuff, just sweet corn and rice corn flavor, harsh bitterness for a lawnmowertype beer, I like coors lite better.

Bottle: Green bottle need say I more. Very hoppy, bitter and skunky. The bitterness stayed with you from start to finish and hung around for some time after that. For a beer that was brewed in Belgium, I was very disappointed...
Bottle. Clear yellow colour with a white head. Malty bready and slightly hoppy aroma. Sweet malty, slightly grassy flavor with some hoppy hints. Malty bitter finish.
Quite fresh, clean taste. Pretty intense for a standard lager, not bad at all. Malty and hoppy in a mild yet firm way. And cheap. (Btw: had it straight from the bottle and served very cold).
Light yellow in color.  Not much to it malty and that’s about it.  very basic.  I drank it just to have something in front of me.
Straw yellow with small head. Corny and some okay malt, a bit swee too. Not  bad for a basic lager.
Hazy yellow colour with white head. Corny nose. Fairly balanced if not too distinctive flavour.

On tap at Murphy’s on campus.  Light yellow appearance with a small, very white head.  Skunky aroma.  Flavor of grains (mainly corn).  A little bit sweet, but thats about all it had going for it.  All in all, not that great.

9.27.06: Cold on tap at Cotton: Pours a clear golden color with a frothy alabaster head. Aroma is of hay, sweet malt, light hops and hints of light fruits.  Taste is crisp; lightly bitter, sweet malt and notes of lemon.  Has a short, bittersweet ending.  Definitely better on tap than from a bottle.
8.29.06  Rating 3.1:  Cold 12oz bottle: Pours a clear yellow/golden color with very little head.  Aroma is of flowers and citrus. Light body lager. Tastes sweet and malty. Slightly acidic aftertaste.
Pour is a very clear yellow with a fizzy white head.  Aroma is pure skunk thanks the the green bottle.  Flavor is weak with no redeaming qualities.  The Bud light of Belgium.

On Tap-Poured a golden yellow color w/ a moderate foamy head. Moderate grainy aroma. Crisp, clean flavor w/slight traces of citrus & grass. Somewhat sweet w/a slight bitter finish. It’s a good beer, definately has a Belguin flavor to it. Easy drinking beer-but there is definately a lot of better stuff out there.
Draught. Colour pale yellow and clear, with good head which fades quickly. Slightly carbonated, chemical aroma. Sweet with a forgettable after taste.

Aroma was moderatly malty and lightly bready, heavy flowery hop aroma and a bit of a sweet yeast aroma, it poured light yellow, sparkling with a frothy white head that was mostly lasting.  The flovor was lightly sweet a great balanced taste and the finish was a bitter and refreshing.  light, livley, watery and refreshing.   Pour your buds and pbr’s down the drain and pick up a good lager like this.
One of the best pale lagers I’ve tasted.  I lived in England for 2 years and enjoyed this beverage every chance I got.  Nice crisp taste with a lasting bitter aftertaste.

Nice head when poured into a pilsner amd the carbonation bubbles up from bottom of the glass for a long time.  Not bad tasting but I do not like the after taste.  It’s drinkable but I definitely wouldn’t go out of my way to find it and but it

On draught. Unfortunately the best this hotel has to offer.

Dark straw colour with good head which fades quickly. Slightly carbonated, chemical aroma. Sweet with a forgettable after taste.
Bottle, pale yellow and clear, fizzy, unexciting, it comes to something when I have to drink summat like this.

On tap. Clear with medium head that fell fast. Light color. Strong aroma of noble hops and a distinct hops bite on the first sip. Refreshing, almost sour from the hops kick. Technical perfection, but no soul.
In Belguim they make nice beers, obviously they dump the crap on the rest of the world.

On Tap at Jakes Steaks in St. Louis. Nice deep golden color with a minimal white head. Aroma of citrus. Has a nice crisp taste that finishes a with a hint of hop bitterness. Not a bad beer but it is nothing special either.

A mini tasting of Orangeboom Premium Lager (NZ Breweries, Auckland) 5%, Stella Artois (NZ Breweries, Auckland) and Heineken (DB Breweries, Auckland).  I tried all three of these licensed brews on a sunny afternoon.  They are all similar and all pretty average.  The Oranjeboom was the worst - and with sugar listed in the ingredients it should be - it had not much taste, fizz or head and poured the same golden lager colour as the other two.  I had this beer in Holland and it was better than the Auckland version.  Heineken was the next - slightly more head but not much carbonation.  It had an astringent aftertaste that I associate with processed hops and industrial brewing.  The Stella was the best of the three with a lasting head and a hint of hops.  It amuses me that all three allude to a long brewing history on the labels - O associates itself with 1671, Stella with 1366 (hundreds of years before lager was invented) and H claimes to have been established in 1873 and won a Gold Medal in 1875.  That surely must have been the last time it tasted of anything good.  This long history is probably supposed to divert the punter from the fact that these beers are crap.  These are office drinks beers - the boss gets to say he’s bought the help something exotic and everyone has to be thankful.  The tragedy is that for just a pittance more per bottle you can pick up an excellent Macs Sassy Red or similar brew that really is quite tasty.

Tap at the Oceanaire Seafood Room in Seattle.

Pours a nice amber with a good head; the aroma and flavor alike are clean and well balanced with warm malt notes and enough of a hop finish to keep the beer from being boring. Obviously pale lagers need not be the most exciting style, but this is one of the better examples thereof that I’ve had, and I enjoyed it. Sometimes I’d rather have a well-crafted pale lager than yet another heavy-handed large-micro APA.
On tap. Not all that different from local pale lagers, VB, New, etc. a little bit fruitier aromas, though.
yellowish fizzy color and taste. quite a kick. had this during lunch with pizza in cambridge.

11.2 OZ BOTTLE.  I drank this ice cold - borderline frozen.  Pours clear golden yellow with lots of fizz.  A white frothy head disipates fast with trace amounts of lacing. Not a whole lot of flavor other than some spice, hops & yeast. The slight aftertaste is difficult for me to distinguish - it can best be described as a hint of clove.   I liked this beer as much as any of the American staples like Bud or Bud Light.  I’d drink it again.
To me it is a mediocre beer, at most one step up from budweiser. I wouldn’t buy it and just as well get a miller and save the money when I want a cheap beer.

Bottle into a shaker glass.  This one might have been better if I had tasted it out of the bottle and held my nose because it was skunk, SKUNK, SKUNKY!  After I let it fumigate out a little bit I noticed some astringent grains in there too.  This one developed a short-lasting, soapy white head and a clear, pale gold body.  Nearly undrinkable.

This has been my favorite beer for a long time.  It pains me to hear people speak so poorly of it.  It could be that I am unsophsticated in my beer judging, but I’ve enjoyed this beer since before it gained popularity in the Vancouver area about 5 years ago.

Didn’t think much of tjhis. Even less because I let it warm as I drank it. That is fine for Belgians, stouts and barleywines, but this beer needs to be drank ice cold. The beginning aroma and flavor were not much, and they got worse as it warmed. Finish was similar to drinking a BMC, dry with a bitter after-taste. I could have these at a party, if free and cold, but doubt I’ll be spending money on this again.

I wish I had read the reviews before I bought this, now I’m stuck 8 miles away from any store. I think the beer is a little old tasting (which should be normal) after its treck across the big pond. Nothing all that special. It tastes like a European Miller LIte with a dose of import and hint of skunk. I’ll take a fresh Bud over this. Thanks anyway.

belgium’s budweiser.  aroma reminiscent of heineken (same damn green bottle) that smells like someone poured a little salt or perhaps vinegar into my glass.  seems that the draft version is missing the skunky tang, but still exhibits the same light floral body and insubstantial backbone for something is not designed to be a light beer.  stlil not bad, but as far as belgian beer goes? it’s like the difference between watching a little league baseball game and watching the yankees play - sure, it’s baseball, but you know that the little leaguers are trying but they can’t play like the yankees.
Not a great beer, not a horrible beer.  Almost always on tap and is better than your cheep ass bud, but nothing special.....nothing special at all.

This basically proved the point that free beer isn’t always good beer. Pale yellow colour with more carbonation then is natural in a beer that is probably only a week old. Taste is almost none-existant with some light grains and a finish that is dry and nothing else.
Nothing to absolutely love, nothing to absolutely hate. Yellow, lightbodied, malty with enough hops to make it bitter, but none for aroma or taste.
Bottle. Very light, an average lager. An OK balance of hops and malt, but does not leave a pleasant aftertaste. Pricey for what it is.
You can just taste the chemicals. Disgusting.Don’t think I’ll be drinjking this for a while.
Yellow with white head. Little malt & hop. Thin texture. Unbelievable this is a Belgium brew. Anyway, this is in the category Average lager!

(330 ml bottle: BevMo in La Jolla, CA; Best Before End: Oct, 2006) It’s hard to believe that I’ll be 43 next week and I’ve never tasted even a sip of Stella Artois.  Given the price and the country of origin, I was at least expecting mediocrity from this beer and a somewhat drinkable pale lager, but after choking down this early birthday present to myself, this is still just swill, albeit fancy, overpriced swill from Belgium.  Sweet, grainy, doughy and metallic with a fair amount of cardboard in there too for good measure, just in case you were starting to think this isn’t THAT bad a beer.  Oh, it certainly is that bad.  Sweet, bready, grainy nose is equally noxious.  Light-bodied with typical carbonation levels, this beer isn’t even refreshing on the palate.  Pale straw in color, but if there’s one thing this beer does right, it boasts a perfectly clear body.  But then the beer even screws up the potential attractiveness by appearing nearly still in my Belgian tulip glass (which I hoped would help, but you can’t make a silk purse from a sow’s ear).  The white head is of average size on the pour, rising to no more than half an inch, and then quickly receding to a sprinkling of powdered sugar.  A single small strand of lace has the stamina to stick to the glass.  So, there goes one of the worst birthday presents I’ve ever had.  What a disappointment!  Anyone who would pay premium prices ($8.50/six pack) for a beer that’s just about as crappy as the other (significantly less expensive) pale lagers on the shelf, well, what’s that old proverb?  A fool and his money are soon parted?  Yeah, that’s the one.  If you’re gonna drink bad beer, then buy inexpensive bad beer and send the rest of your cash to me for my birthday.
There is nothing special to this beer, I think its more of an average, everyday type beer, but still drinkable.
This beer doesn’t suck too hard, but it’s over priced. This is a summer beer. It falls into the same wavelength as Heineken etc.....It’s not very tastey nor special but is better than Pabst.

A very drinkable lager.. comparable to Heineken, although Stella’s not quite as flavorful, but easier to drink...very refreshing, satisfying to use as a summer beer...nice head, but goes away quickly. One of my favorite pale lagers

Good alternative to Heineken and about as widely available.  Great on a warm summer day, but otherwise uninteresting.  Flavor was off and thin at the start, but improved on the finish.  This beer has been criticized a lot, but it is what it is, a light lager.  Overall not bad.

First rating33 cl bottle from Swedish Systembolaget. Light yellow color, white head. Malty scent with iron. Malty and bitter taste with a bit iron aftertaste. Medium mouthfeel, high bitterness.6/2/6/3/10=2.7Second rating(Draught at a pub at the north station in Brussels)On March 0, 008Pale golden color, white head. Malty sweet and fresh scent. Malty taste. Medium mouthfeel, low bitterness.5/3/5/3/10=2.6
Not much of a nose at all, clear with no head, watery lager with a slightly bitter alteration, drank it moments after being caught naked in a pool that I do not own

Poured med. gold with a short creamy head and a mild malty straw aroma. I wouldn’t go out of my way or pay a premium for any more of this but it is a light bodied clean tasting lager that was quite refreshing. Mine came out of a cardboard 12pk container  so skunkiness wasn’t a problem today.
okay for a bar drink...golden body with large white head...aroma and flavor are of a typical lager...this beer is heavily carbonated...thin watery palate...nothing special here

Figured I had to try this even though I suspected it wasn’t very good.  It finally became available in Wisconsin.  Pricey at $1.49 a bottle or nearly $8 a sixer.  Best by 05/2007.  The beer pours to a pale yellow body with decent visible carbonation and a thin frothy white head.  The aroma is corn and Saaz-like hops.  Perhaps bread dough and spicy hops.  The flavor I think is actually quite good for a pale lager.  It is lightly grainy, light bread dough, light crisp Saaz hops, corn on the finish.  Actually quite drinkable, but still fairly boring.  The palate is thin and watery with decent carbonation.  Pretty decent for a pale lager.  Not a drain pour 2.7.
Over priced garbage... little to no taste.  Minimal white head that disipates quickly, fizzy mild hops. I do not see what everyone else sees in this. Marketing is guess.
dough, earthy, golden, sparkling, clear, frothy, lightly bitter, medium body, slick feel, fizzy, lively, bitter, long finish, just a nice beer to drink on a warm summer afternoon.
Pours golden with small off white head. Skunky aroma. Tastes like water if you plug your nose. Update - Decided to try this on tap. It was much better. No skunkiness, decent flavor.

Light in both color and taste. Has some of that metallic flavor found in certain import lagers. The green bottle leaves this beer ripe for being skunked.  Luckily my bottle only suffered slighlty from this.  Nothing special here, moving on to something better.

Finally decided to give it a try.  Nothing stood out about this beer.  In fact, as far a pale lagers go, this was probably one of my least favorites.  Both aroma and flavor were rather weak and not very good.  Oh well, at least I’ve tried it and can now not have to have it again.

Draught.
Clear yellow coloured with a lasting white head.
Sweet aroma of malts, grain and fruits.
Flavour of grain with malty notes.
Harsh finish.

Made an average appearance, poured a clear pale golden with a foamy white head that settled in a thin soapy lacing, good lager carbonation.

Had largely a clean nose with whiffs of husky grain and a bland lager maltiness.

A softly crisp and smooth light bodied mouthfeel, too light a body for my taste, also, because of aroma and taste, below average drinkability.

Taste wasn’t that appealing, veggie and husky, your basic sweet bland lager maltiness and a dryish malty finish.

When compare to other pale lagers coming from eastern Europe or those brew here by different microbrewers here in the US, this is below average, no real reason to buy it.

Poured yellow with a fizzy white head.  Strong grassy saaz hop aroma... surprising.  Flavor is cream, toffee, a bit of grassiness.  Hops are actually quite detectable in flavor.  Light fizzy body.  Not half bad.

Pours clear light yellow with a white head - just like every pale lager in the world.  Aroma is slightly skunky malt with not much of anything going on.  Light mouthfeel with lightly fizzy carbonation & lots of it.  Initial taste is lightly malted with a touch of husk, then an offputting light skunkiness sneads in.  Finish has a touch of spice.  By far the most boring Belgium beer I’ve ever had.

500 mL can:  From what I hear, actual Stella, on tap, in Belgium is a different experence than over here! This is an over-revered product, like Heineken in the can.  I mean, taste it:  there is nothing pleasant and smooth.  It is bitter and fizzy and thin, and that awful finish lasts, leaving a sour taste in your mouth.  Better lagers out there for sure.
Stella Artois is a high quality light, golden lager. It has a decent pour with a nice head. One of my favorite import Pilsners. Nice strong taste of hops.
I just can’t stand the smell of the heinekin style lager aroma anymore.  Not sure if its all of the ale’s and stouts I have been drinking lately.  This is just too sweet.
Refreshing beer... nothing fancy as far as flavor goes... ever so slight hop bitterness.  Along the line of other European lagers in a green bottle... not bad.

Pours golden with a very thin wispy white head. Aroma of bready lager yeast, clean bitterness, and biscuit. Taste is bready, with sweet toasted malts, industrial lager yeast, and a mild herbal bitterness. Mouthfeel is thin bodied with lively carbonation. Not bad but not enjoyable.
A very smoothe beer.  I like the aluminum on the bottle, makes the appearance look fancy.  The taste itself isn’t anything out of this world but a very smoothe lager.
Moderate hoppy aroma. Avg frothy white head. Fair lasing. Mostly diminishing longevity. Clear yellow body color. Moderate bitter initial flavor. Palate light to medium. Watery texture.

This is the best imported lager (I say humbly). Hoppy, refreshing, clear, robust, alcoholic and drinkable.  Great with light foods or snacks.  Try them with Snap-Pea Crisps.  If this beer was more economical, say $10 for a 12 pack I think more people would make a switch to this great mass-market beer.  I don’t like the green bottles or the white paper wrap, but the aroma (malt, perfume, floral, licorice) and the bite (bitter and sweet) is simply delicious.  There is a reason it is the fastest growing import worldwide.  Use the expiration date, because freshness does matter.
Smells like urine but the color is lighter than you would expect.  Thin white head.  Pure corn flavour.
Clear pale yellow color with a thin white head. Sweet grain aroma. Sweet flavor of grain
Traditional Belgian skunk smell - at least the skunk taste didn’t follow as some tend to do.  Not an outstanding lager in my opinion just tried it becasue it was Stella.

As everyone tends to think, this is a regular Euro lager.  Green bottle and all.  Looks rather premium and will probably pop up in restaurants all over America in the near future (I.E. TGI Fridays).  Nothing wrong with it; if available, get it on tap.  Worth a once over.
There is nothing distinguishing about this beer at all.  No lace, no head, no interest on my part.  Unremarkable in every way
Bottle.  Golden liquid with a foamy head that lasted.  You don’t taste that much the preservatives.  Refreshing.  Good for a lager but not excellent or impressive beer.
Certainly not much different than most green bottle beers; average Euro lager

12oz bottle from Vons on sale ;) pours a very pale golden, more pleasant aroma than any american pale lager but still lacking as opposed to other pale lagers.  decent flavor, if not just because it isn’t skunked.  no opposable aftertastes, but no really good ones either.  quaffable, but not really impressive.  but, if its the best you can get.. go for it.

On tap.  Poured a clear, lighter bright golden with a decent cap of loose white head.  Nose was primarily of sweet malts, but picked up intriguing notes of lighter sliced fruits and caramel.  Flavor also had sweet malts and fruits.. little floral hops showed up, too.  Crisp, smooth, and refreshing on the palate... certainly not groundbreaking, but no complaints either.

I got this part of a gift pack from a buddy and finallly got around to tasting this lager yesterday. I honestly wasn’t impressed. It was a Heine clone only with less of a skunked taste. It just left me with very little impression at all. I wouldn’t buy this, but I’d drink it if it was around. :-)
Meh. Nothing spectacular. Like a stronger flavored Canadian, except not. Won’t buy again.
A light typical pale lager, has more flavor than many, but still not great. Would be good today, on a 100f Californian day!
A very light yellow coloring. Not much flavor or taste. All aftertaste and not good. Drank at Stag’s Head in Houston.

I guess cuz it said Belgium on it, I was expecting a Belgian beer. Maybe that was part of the disappointment. Otherwise, it was just another medicore import lager like Heinie (little skunkiness). Noticeable carbonation, seemed high for most lagers I’ve had. Would have another, but I won’t buy one.

light gold with a white head. nice head retention. aroma and flavor a little better than the typical european lager. decent amount of malt and a decent hop profile. light body. finish slightly hoppy dry and refreshing. decent lager.

light brassy gold w/ white head.
extremely light... flavor lingers long on the finish,a nd actually leaves a decent hint of hoppiness. very crisp and refreshing, despite the fact that i really don’t care for lagers much.
IGA Mtée Paiement. Praticly no aroma, nice label but thats it for the appearance. Calm in mouth. One of my best lager...I usually hate lager, but this one is my best lager.
Golden color with white foamy head.  Does not have much flavor, but has a very crisp, refreshing taste to it.  Medium to medium-high amounts of bitterness.  Fairly light compared to most lagers.

Like most other lagers, nothing special here .I can not understand the hype around this beer, it seems a lot of people who know nothing about beer think this is the greatest beer in the world . At least its inspiring people to try something new.

Nice to have around, still, not an inspiring beer. My tongue wants more.....well...everything, I guess. 
But still for some reason I like it.
Draft.  Alright beer.  Not very special actually.  Pretty much tastes like any other pale lager.

Not a big fan of Stellla, its has a rather strong taste for it’s alcohol content. I wouldn’t describe it as smooth. For being ’reassuringly expensive’ I don’t feel it is worth the money.. If you like this type of taste, maybe you’ll like Becks.

This is one of those beers I keep going back and trying time after time because everyone seems to like it. However, I just don’t get it. It does look pretty when poured in its special glass, but the taste just doesn’t do it for me.

The imported version of this is absolutely miles different from the product brewed on licence. The imported Stella would score about a 4 but the local version tastes watered down and lacks the hoppy aroma that distinguishes great pilsners like Urquell and others. When in NZ I avoid any beer brewed on licence...
I tend to like darker beers, but this is good stuff. Becoming more available. Needs to pull some market share in the US to bump out the Miller Lite/Bud Light trends.

After a disaster with a certain famous American beer, I thought I hated beer. Until I met Stella. Got a can in Belgium.  Pours golden yellow with nice head. Very yeasty and bready, mild hops. I’ve since found I like stouts better, but this is the best lager I’ve had.

Instigator of a million unecessary scuffles, Stella’s reputation as a promoter of bad temper precedes it. Nevertheless, its refreshing breadiness is worthy of delectation, in the absence of alternatives. Lacework and a discernible non-metallic flavour out of a 284ml metal tube. I could list several dozen more insipid (and undeservedly popular) lagers, but instead I’m off to kick in a phonebox and throw stones at the vicarage windows.
Lots of hype preceeded this.  Much ado about nothing.  Pale yellow, small white head.  Nothing of note in the aroma or the flavor.  May as well have been Bud Lite.
33cl bottle.  Refreshing lager, better than most in it’s class.  Nothing outstanding but cetainly better than average.

Stella Artois is a high quality light, golden lager.  It has a decent pour with average head.  It’s becoming more and more commercial, but still one of the top light lagers in the world and should gets its due.

This must be one of the most overrated ’import’ beers in Canada/USA. The beer is modified to fit the market. Over here in Canada and the US, it is a shadow of its real Belgian way of tasting. Go to Belgium, have some Stella, and its lovely. Come to North America, and its a travesty. Its not even ’imported’. Most, if not all, is made ’under licence’ over here.  The most amusing thing about stella here, (Im a Brit living in Canada) is the way its treated over here as some sort of revered sophisticated beer. Even served with great ceremony in silly little Stella glasses with huge heads, the barmaid having to ’knife’ off huge amounts of fobbing. Beer should not fob excessively. if a beer is fobbing alot, theres something wrong with the fob chamber, or the dispensing, or maybe the cellar/flashcooler is too warm.  Im sorry to burst youre bubble guys, but in the UK, it is white trash beer. Yup, the beer of thugs, soccer holigans and plebs. The taste over here is kinda tasteless,wastery, overfizzy garbage.  Little aroma, insipid appearance, minimal ’clean’ flavour, with a finish so short, you wonder whether one is actually drinking beer, or water with a tablespoon of beer added. No hoppy bitterness in the finish, and no lasting complexity after swallowing.  This is ’beer’ for people who either dont know how beer tastes (and dont know any better), or dont like the way real beer tastes, if the latter, then this is really sad, as good beer should be as complex and satisfying as wine.
Does not look like much but given what it is it is not bad.  A bit grassy but still clean and crisp enough to be refreshing.
better known as a nelson or winnie mandela. this beer is everywhere, personally im not that particularly fond at all, but i wont say no to sharing a few nelson’s with mates.

Nothing to see here.  Move along.  Still reading?  OK.  This is Belgium’s version of Heineken. A tiny bit stronger.  If this is the best a bar has, I’ll drink it.  Otherwise, blech.  I’ll pass.  Girls like it.  That’s how it got an 8 on the overall.  Gets them too hammered though.  It can get ugly, so keep an eye on her and switch her over to Fat Tire before she does too much damage and starts to cry or causes a scene or hits on your friends.
From draft. This is junk.  It’s only redeeming quality is a decent "buttery" palate.  It tastes like Heineken Light with no aroma to speak of and just a bitter and thin grassy, skunky flavor. Why?

nice golden color.  Slight skunky aroma. Taste was a little grainy with malt and citric flavor. Finished with a bit of dry hoppy flavor.  Over all was expectimg more with all the hype of had 600 years to get this beer right.   Good beer but dose not live up to the hype.

Richer aroma than most pale lagers, not too skunky at all. Lokks as good as pale lager gets, with right amount of bubbles and a nice didhsoap head. Very agreeable flavor, certainly more Belgian than Dutch. I drink it when it’s available.

People made such a big deal about resturaunts and bar’s here getting Stella.  I finally couldn’t avoid it any longer when my selection recently was bud or bud light, miller, or stella. SO I finally caved in. Somewhat skunky nose,followed by some astringent type corn and malt. Never really opens up. Taste is the same, some floral hints to pick out but mostly a skunk who just dined on a few leftover citric fruits. yawn

Golden, clear pour with a small white head that faded away halfway down the glass.  Smells of floral hops and citrus, tastes of the same with some fruity tones.  Bartenders seem to praise this beer, but it was a bit of a let down.

Pale golden color with a medium white head. Aroma is floral, sweet and slightly metallic. Flavor starts lightly sweet followed by a crisp hop bitterness finishing kinda dry and grassy. Medium bodied and watery with lively carbonation.
Pale skunkyness. Bitter finish. I just keep getting reminded of how lame it is with all of it’s advertising on trucks and billboards.

Subtle fruit aroma, pours clear and golden.  Flavouring is slightly sweet to start and ends with a touch of bitter hops. Overall a very nice lager and one of the better mass marketed ones but not outstanding.
12 oz bottle, this was an average  beer, gold, clear, light, refreshing, too expensive for what it was, not bad but, too many superior lagers, would have another on sale.
Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Pours golden with a white head. Aroma is  sweet. Flavor is sweet, carbonated, not bad, but not great.
It does not have much taste for a larger. I find it is way to light,it reminds me of other big comercial beers. Not the best example from Belgium
Not good, not bad but a good session beer if you’re somewhere with a limited selection - this stuff is everywhere lately.
A pretty standard beer...The guy at the liquor Store seemed to be pretty impressed by it. Its not a bad beer at all... just not an outstanding one
A good pilsener even in a can. Long time since I had my last one! Slightly fruity fresh pilsener

my friend got me one of these at a bar.  i couldn’t help but wonder if it was accidentally a miller lite or something.  horribly light texture, no particular taste.  a definite pale lager.  i guess i was expecting a pistachio taste for some reason (prior experience?).  not there obviously.  rerate: some hoppiness, more than usual.  but even more light-flavored than bud light

Faint, slightly sweet smell.  Slightly sweet taste with a bit of a bitter finish.  Taste is weak though.  Not much too it... It’s an okay beer I guess, not as strong as many lagers I’ve had...  Not repulsive, maybe I’d have it again.
Not sure why peple are down on this ber.....I think this is a true classic and can enjoy this one anytime of the year....great beer flavors and great palate.  Get it in the correct glass!

Beer pours a rather sickly yellow with a frothy, whipped egg white head that is nicely retained.  Aroma is lightly skunky with a decent spicy hoppy note.  Flavor is grainy, malty with a decent spicy hop finish.  A good beer for a blazing hot day in Texas.  Will buy again.

Bottled. Pale yellow, full head when poured. Strong hops, good carbonation. The nose is sweet malts, vegetables and grass... not to apetizing.. looks and feels better than it tastes. A good girls beer i guess.

Very nice drinkable Belgian. Nice head forms when poured into tulip galss. Totally different flavor when poured into a pint glass. The tulip pour was heady with a slight hop bite. The pint pour was like drinking a Bud.

Not much of a fan of this.  I realize it is continuing to grow in popularity but I find it pretty bland with a stange, funky aftertast.  With so many other great Belgiums out there just leave this one alone.

What can I say about "Wife Beater" that hasn’t already been said before? Stella has really taken off in Canada over the past five or six years, thanks largely to a marketing campaign in this country -- I’d dare say it may even be the No. 1 European brew over here. Aside from a slight skunky smell (not NEARLY as bad as Heineken, mind you) this is an all-around good pint. A word to the wise, though: If you’re visiting Canada and you pop into a pub to order a Stella, ask that they pour it into a regular, standard pint glass. If you don’t, they’ll probably pour it into one of these pretentious one-pint glasses which resembled an oversized wine glass. Draught beer should ONLY be served in standard pint glasses, but that’s just my opinion.
This is a nice light, smooth and easy drinking beer for the everyday consumption
Miller Lite with a fancy name!  Urine colored.  Very light on taste.  In fact might as well have had a glass of water.
Just like American macrobrews. I.E. not very good. Pale, watery, bland. ’Nuff said.

If nothing else, this is very ordinary.  It is not a bad beer, but does not do justice to most of the other products that come out of Belgium.  Calling it the Budweiser of Belgium might be a little tough, but not too far from the truth.
One of my all time favorites!  Like beer in general, it is an acquired taste.

I actually have notes on this. Let me sum them up:

Pile of shit kgwthxbye.
Clear yellow color with a great head. Ordinary lager but not a bad one, No spiciness in mine...

You’ve got to be kidding me! "Beautiful", "citrus", "hoppy"????  Well, mine WAS from a can, but I’ve had from a bottle earlier, and I didn’t finish that either, so I don’t think that I am biased by the can....

There is little about this beer that makes it noticable over a Tecate or a Corona. And I am not being biased by style, there is much more complexity in a Beck’s, which I recently had, or a Sam Adams.  

Pours pee yellow with an eggshell head, no corn or rice flavors.  I think that there is only barley in this one (so it gets over a 2).  No spice on the finish, in fact rather flat on the taste meter.  There are much better options, even in Panama. I don’t understand why, when I visited NYC last summer that this beer was so freaking trendy....Rolling Rock is better. This beer doesn’t deserve being Belgian.
Bottled. Beautiful. Citrus aroma, fruity flavor, smooth finish. Recommended!

Preface: This was tasted after a few scotches and Miller Lites at the hockey game. I don’t think this one is as bad as a 21 rating. It wasn’t great but it did have some body and a little spiciness. Also, was plenty drinkable. I could put quite a few away in one sitting.

A light, pale yellow colour with a weak, white head. The nose is an immediate tinny, citrusy aroma, with some hoppy notes after. The taste is also of dry hoppiness, but rather tasteless in the finish.

Bottle, 330ml. A pale yellow-coloured pour with a large fizzy mostly-diminishing head. Faint aroma of hops. Not much in the taste department, but a reasonable bitter finish for this type of lager. High carbonation. Drinkable, but not great.

from the bottle. poured a yellow with a small white head that left no lacing which would have been hard to do in the plastic cup I was given to drink from.. aroma malt grainy, wheat, with  some hops at the finish. flavor, malt. sugar, some of the hops popped up nicely. this did go well with the cedar plank roasted salmon I was having for dinner last night.

Grainey ,bready malt aroma, pale gold classic lager color, distinct full grain taste,the result of a balanced malt ,hop blend,body is surprisingly light for full taste,lacks the slight sweetness of American Premium lagers.

Bottle. Soft, pleasant aroma and a very quick finish. Crisp, clean taste that is a superb choice for refreshment after a long day. Pours beautifully into the unique Stella chalice glass to create a discerned look. One of my favourites.

This beer is not bad if I could replace the crap at my bar I would ride my bar of 5 beers that taste worse and replace them with stella. It is well balanced with hops and malt crisp taste not too bad.

Reviewing bottle and tap. Bready, lemony, oxidized penny on nose. Decent bitterness though perhaps somewhat stale tasting and soft. Nothing particularly unpleasant. Just a nice enough beer with lunch and a sandwich. A belgian PBR.. and that’s ok.

Yeasty, wheaty aroma.  Pours golden, with a frothy white head.  Tastes pretty good, definite wheat/yeast taste as well.  The body is great, good carbonation, gives me a filled feeling.  Very similar to Becks, although this is slightly more yeasty and slightly less clean than becks.  Not a bad Lager by any stretch.

Stella is a beautiful light amber color.  It’s kind of urine-looking, which I just find absolutely gorgeous, and it tastes wheaty.  There’s a very yeasty hint to it, and it goes down very smoothly.  The aftertaste is kind of sharp, and it reminds of cheap champagne.  I can probably drink a million of these in a row.  It’s not the most alcoholic thing in the world.  It’s kind of like the beer that cheap commercial beer drinkers could drink to become introduced to the world of imports and such.  The head is white and delicious, so don’t even worry about a slow pour with this one.
Pale yellow.  Very dry, very quick finish.  Slight hint of citrus but the bitterness predominates.  Not very exciting.  Not much else to say.  Tastes like the formula for a macro beer.

Bottled. (Brewed by unknown Algerian brewer).  Pale yellow, relatively firm head. Heavy on metal and vegetables. Sweet with unclean adjunct flavour. No bitterness. You can’t go much more wrong than this in Algeria, as the local brands are at least decent.

500 ml can. Thick fine-laced white head. Clear light golden. Soft aroma with notes of granny smith apples. Not really much flavour other than hop bitterness. Perhaps a little light maltiness at the beginning. Medium bodied. Aftertaste slightly metallic and have slightly harsh hop bitterness. Starts out fine, but the finish is terrible.

Bottled. Pale lager with foaming head.  Strong lacing.  When I’m in the mood for a few lagers, this is one of my top choices.  It has the right blend of hops and malts.  I find this leans on the sweet side with a decent hop presence. Good alcohol content! Refeshing...

1. On Tap at the Witton Chimes, Northwich 12/03/2001 Some malt and hops present. 2. On Tap at the Witton Chimes, Northwich 05/06/2001
Smooth on the palate with some alcohol present. 3. On Tap at Lavins Wine Bar, Northwich 30/06/2001 Light on the palate hoppy and refreshing. 4. Bottle 25/08/2001 Golden coloured strong in alcohol and hoppy. 5. Can 27/10/2001 Golden coloured with some alcohol present.
6. On Tap at Cord Bar, Manchester 23/12/2003 Clear golden smooth malty with a crisp slightly creamy finish. 7. Bottle at Bar Bar, Manchester 23/12/2003 Clear golden crisp malty with slightly bitter finish. 8. On Tap at the Barley Mow, Warrington 19/05/2004 Golden coloured crisp and smooth on the palate. Some alcohol present. Lasting malt finish. 9. Can 28/08/2004 Golden coloured crisp and hoppy. Slightly dry malt finish. 10. On Tap at the Venue, Long Eaton 23/09/2005 Clear golden coloured crisp and hoppy. Slightly dry malt finish. 11. 22/12/2006 12. 30.06.2007 13. 03.12.2007 14. 15.12.2007 15. 20.12.2007 16. 08.06.2008 17. 24.08.2008 18. 28.12.2008 19. 15.05.2009 20. 21.06.2009 21. 22.06.2009 22. 08.11.2009 23. 08.11.2009 24. 02.01.2010 25. 27.02.2010 26. 13.03.2010 27. 13.03.2010 28. 05.04.2010 29. 12.01.2011

"Belgium’s Original Beer"?  I can certainly see why they decided to try other brew recipes, then.  Well, it’s not bad.... let me rephrase that; it’s not terrible.  But it’s certainly not the best I’ve had.  Pours transparent hay hue into the glass, with a decent head.  It smells of earth, hops and slight skunk.   Funny, some lavender mixes in as the beer warms.  These aromas transfer directly into the mouth, as the malt is hidden somewhere within the hops on the front end of the pull, and disappear completely into a mild peppery hop finish.    It goes down well enough, and certainly would quench the palate, but I’m for certain there are a lot better beers that will do the same trick, but are much more enjoyable.  Nothing special here, sorry.
Bottle.  Light golden clear pour with a little head.  A slight grassy aroma.  Had a smooth malty flavor.  Had quite a few and enjoyed them all.
I was expecting alot more from this beer.  I had heard it talked about as if it were some great beer but to me it tasted like Bud Light.   Definetely not worth the extra cost.
Poured golden amber in color with white head. Sweet malt aroma. Full flavore ale with bitter malt finish.

a local resurant had this as a draft, and it really wasn’t that bad. aroma.. wasn’t special, the appearance was a perfect yellow amber beer color, the falvor is kind of hard to explain. It’s like a pale lager with a slight kick. A lot better than what most places have to offer (altleast ot the lower end of the scale). I would pick this beer over most any places that bad just basics.

i found this too be horrible, bottled at a friends house, i had it out of the bottle but i don’t think that would make much of a difference with this, i’ve heard alot about this being good, and well, it’s not.

On tap at Morgan’s Chicago.  Pale yellow body with a medium white head - this looks like any Pale Lager.  Aroma wasn’t much.  Flavor was decent, I didn’t detect any of the skunkiness endemic to many lagers.  One of the better lagers I’ve tasted.
I admit it.  I like Stella Artois.  There is almost nothing better on a hot, muggy New York day than to be greeted with a proper glass of ice-cold Stella.  Beautiful clear gold.

Yeah, I like this stuff, loathe the marketing campaign and the hipsters that have adopted it. Just like frat-dudes took Jager, hipsters are taking this as their sub-cultural beverage. It is usually offered in it’s own, proprietary glass which probably adds to the extreme cost.
On the taste, 
BUY A MILLER HIGH-LIFE!!! One of these at a bar’ll get you a six pack of high-life bottles.
The head is usually outstanding. Whereas high life tastes like creamed corn, this tastes like kettle corn.
Seriously, someone please do a blind taste test with stella and high-life head to head.

An off yellow pour with no head.  Aroma was as previously stated, a bit skunky.  Taste was that of a bad pils with extra carbonation, reminded me of the one time I tasted Bud Ice.  In the category of belgium beers it is at the bottom.  It seems to be an acceptable replacement to bud, when ordering a bud isnt acceptable.

I discovered Belgian beers back in December 2005.  Never seen any sold in a 12 pack.  I should have known better.
