This beer has an earthy, skunky aroma, pours a crystal clear straw color and shows good carbonation.  It has very little to offer the palate.  Is this the Belgian’s answer to Bud?  No wait, that’s not fair to Bud.

this has become very popular for some reason. skunky aroma, smalll white head. piss-yellow appearnce, very thin. bit of bitterness, hoppy taste. there are many belgian beers superior to stella, that’s for sure
Poured from tap.  Slightly skunky odor.  Fairly pale in appearance with moderate carbonation.  Picked up the light skunky taste immediately.  Just not a real quality drinking experience for me.

Bottle. Poured a gold color with a medium white head. Maybe my nose is broke, but I can’t make out the smell. It certainly did not have the skunky smell I have heard and read about. Nice clean taste with a slightly bitter aftertaste. Not a great beer, but it was OK. Better than Heineken which I have heard it compared to.
another generic but drinkable beer. jumped itself into popularity 6 or so years ago and has become an acceptable staple.

Draught in the suburbs of Paris.  Malt aroma, golden fizzy pour.  Hopped, much more bitter than expected, essentially a Pilsner.  Treeeeendy, but a good quaffer and easy to find. [3.3]

Re-rate after some time.  Green-glassed bottle here in Bloomington in late May 08, best before Jan 09 - can they really mean that?  Lightly grassy and grainy aroma, sweet with a touch of caramel.  Pale, nearly clear yellow pour with a soapy white head.   Taste is very sweet, nearly cloying, with reminders of syrupy corn.  Light bitterness lurking along the bottom, a touch of grain and metal, nary a whiff of hops.  I’m surprised that they’re able to get this kind of bitterness without obvious hopping, this actually has a little in common with a North German Pilsner; soft water?  Light body but not watery, crispish taste.  A good example of why we should all re-try our earliest ratings; Bass, for example has stood up to my improving palate reasonably well; by comparison, Stella is a failure. [1.9]

Re-rate in August 2010.  I’ve had this maybe ten times since on tap, and am midway through a sixer of fresh bottles - there really is no comparison.  An insipid little money waster in glass, really needs that fresh, ebullient crispness from a pull to showcase what it’s all about.  Fond memories of this one.

Bottle and Tap - Various places in England. This is trendy beer, both in the U.S. and in the U.K. In almost every nightclub and pub in Oxford. Those of my age bracket (20s) drink it all the time. Color is pale yellow to gold. High carbonation, with a foamy, thick, white head, which was surprising for a lager. Strong hop aroma. Refreshing, clean, but sharp to the palate. Left no noteworthy flavors behind, but not the harsh aftertaste as is found in many American macros. Was as fresh out of the green bottle as it was from the tap. Not good enough though for me to fork out the money, although my friends drink it like water.

Pours a lively gold color. Medium sized head, though not many bubbles. Smell of butter, vanilla, and hops. Taste is smooth, creamy, finish is slightly hoppy and clean. Just enough character to distinguish it from many other mass-produced beers. I love Stella.
golden color, medium not lasting head, nice hop bitterness,it  taste like a better pilsener!  the best "regular" belgian beer i ever had. ingredients on the bottle, pure natural.

over priced clydesdaleurine from bud.
made from CORN,drink a 40 oz. instead.

Bottle. Pours clear, pale golden with ample white head that susided slowly into a thin layer. Quite skunky sour smell.
Sweetish malty flavour with a rather disagreable touch of maize. Short finish with a pronounced hop bitterness. Not a memorable lager.  I beg to disagree with mrchug645 of alb (?) New Mexico: if you really like Pilsner Urquell (and I do) you must NEVER try Stella Artois Lager as it would constitute a cruel and unusual punishment. I did actually have a bottle of Pilsner Urquell  after having Stella Artois and the pilsner  tasted divine and renewed my faith in beer.
When you first open this and pour it into a glass, it has a rather distinct skunky smell/taste as noted in other comments that slowly goes away. Not so bad.
A very nice beer to have on tap. Goes down so smoothe. Stella Artois have a nice thick head of foam.
Bottle. White and surprisingly lasting head. Yellow clear body with a good deal of carbon dioxide. Malt flavor. Some hops flavor unfortunately rounded by the use of corn.
Clear golden color with a medium white head.  The aroma is pretty skunky though.  A light to medium fruit hop taste.

I’d have to say that in the land of grocery store lagers, you really can’t go wrong getting this one if you have no other choice and you are staring down a cooler full of Bud, Miller, etc. Light years better than that swill, it still comes up short compartively to other beers. The pour is probably the highlight of the brew, as it looks incredibly inviting. Aroma is somewhat grainy with a tad of hops. The flavor is just your standard lager, nothing falling too short of what you come to expect it would taste like. Like I said, a good choice if faced with gutter swill but I’d pick a hundred other beers if available. Problem is, that unless you are in a specialty store you probably won’t get them.
On tap.  Nothing remarkable.  Watery.  Not a lot of flavor.  Hard to believe this is from Belgium.
good beer for a pilsner pours a yellowish golden head that is very crisp.if you pilsner urquell you should give this one a try.
Good white head, diminishes fast. Rather watery, with a clear bitterness. Wonderfully fresh, especially cold (though that isn’t the best recommendation for any beer)

If you want, you could order this beer like Marlon Brando in "Streetcar". The bartender, if he’s polite, will smille, perhaps chuckle a bit, and act like he’s never heard that joke before. He will then serve you a skunky but otherwise exceptioanlly bland light lager with no descernable character.
E xtremely skunky odor.  Body is extremely watery and light with a skunky aftertaste.  Not impressed at all.  Similar to a Hieneken or Beck’s, Belgium deserves better.

Tap - This could have been much like the piss poor American pale lagers that are oh so common, but the citrus notes and bit of hops bite save it.  It’s by no means a great beer, but was altogether a pleasant draught to quaff at the bar.  Granted I’d had a few drinks already...
Une bière douce, fragile qui commande une ambiance décontracté et benoîte.  Elle calme les esprits et réchauffe l’atmosphère par le velouté de son arôme et son gout pointu!
son gout vient plus de sa reputation. gout faible, biere overratée. comparable a une biere populaire de chez nous, par exemple la bleue mais qui coute pas mal plus cher

Pours clear golden with minimal foamy head.  Crisp, clean, slightly corny flavor with mild bitterness that lingers.  Seems to have a slightly more biting carbonation than most beers.  Overall, unimpressive.
An okay lager.  pours straw yellow with big head.  The aroma is of grass and is a little sweet.  The hops do give it an okay balance.  Nothing to rave about.  To expensive to just drink in the states

This pint had a slight aroma not unpleasant, I thought the brew was crisp and pretty dry, I felt the head retention was decent. Slight bitter after taste. Will be happy if the lite batch I’m brewing now turns out this good.
Spent $8 for a six pack.  There’s nothing special about this beer, other than the fancy packaging.  Ranks with Heineken as another overrated overpriced beer.  Bah!
Poured yellow with a foamy white head that stuck around like a freeloading guest. The head and nice lacing could not make up for the average flavor and awkwardly hoppy aftertaste.

Light yellow pour from a tap.  Almost no aroma.  Typical lager flavour with a tad more bite, and a little bit of pleasant citrus in the finish, perhaps it’s from the hops?  If I’m going to get a beer from belgium, this isn’t it.  If I want a light beer, this isn’t it.

The yellow, light yellow was far to pee colored for the likes of me.  The head was light, though a nice foam for such a small head.  The smell, sheesh, like strong American-beer stink.  Hoppy finish.  Pretty smooth, but relatively uneventful.  Ho-hum adequately describes this beer.  Wish it lived up to the commercials on its website...Then again, my favorite beers don’t have commercials...coincidence? I think not....  ADD-ON: The head just keeps on lingering, a nice foam...and this is a self pour, not from some tap...from the bottle.  Amazement and disbelief cover my face.  And the lacing has been nice too.

i don’t usually gravitate towards lagers that you can see through, so easily... but i had to satisfy my curiousity, piqued by what little attention it had previously afforded me. at first, i wanted to dismiss it as flavorless American-style. but it was crisp and slightly citrusy. not the "puked-up-a-little" flavor that i am reminded of when i see "Belgium" on the bottle. not exactly my favorite, but a good thirst-quencher low on the alcohol, but on an empty stomach, i can still function rationally. for what that is worth. lots better than expected.

Imported from Belgium to America I figured it would be something different.  In the end it reminded me of any regular American Pale Lager, only not as good.  Minimal head, and piss yellow.  Certainly not worht the $7.49 I payed for it.

This beer is crisp and smooth but is so boring that I fell asleep drinking it! Not much taste and very homely hops. I will never pay $7.99 a six for this crap again when I can get Shiner Bock, Yuengling, or Sam Adams for the same price or cheaper!
Ce n’est pas la meilleur ofrente de la Belgique, mais pas mal meilleur que Heineken et Beck’s. Assé désaltérante, bonne en été, mais meulleur en fut.
A nice drinkable beer.  No skunky smell like Beck’s.  Nicely hopped, smooth, nice mouthfeel and no unpleasant after taste.  I couldn’t tell much difference betwen the bottle and on tap.
Nice white medium head. Golden colour. Lots of carbonation Very small aroma of grain and hops. Flavour: corn and hops with notes of citrus. Pleasant bitter finish.

Pours very clear pale golden with a medium head. Grainy, corny aroma with no skunk. Flavor has notes of grain, corn, some lemon and a solid amount of hop bitterness to balance it out. Medium body with a smooth texture and lively carbonation. Decent head retention. Not great but far from the worst thing I’ve ever had.
you will be sick of this beer quite fast, they have it everywhere, and its just a weak belgian beer, there are many better lagers, but this will top the likes of Heineken.

Bottle. Light yellow colour with an average size white head.  Aroma is of straw and a little bit of flowers/perfume. Flavour is of light bread and grains - light bitterness with very light sweetness.  Light body with average carbonation and a light bitter finish.  Only slightly better on tap.

Pleasantly Surprising for a lager.  Poured a clear gold with lots of bubbles and a nice bubbly white head that dissipated fairly quickly but left some nice lacing.  Light on the nose - not much there, but not offensive.  Started smooth, a little sweet, and ended with a decent amount of hoppiness.  As a lager I was not expecting much - but think I will keep this on hand for those lager-heads out there.

Medium head that dissipated average.  Could not detect much of an aroma (dissapointing for a Belgium).  Golden color.  First taste...very smooth, not sweet nor bitter.  Slight hops, but not overwhelming like an IPA.  To me, the finish is more sweet than bitter.  This is an excellent Lager, if that’s what you like.  I would definitelt buy this again if I had company (I live in the US where too many people are used to that Bud stuff), I think they would really like it.
Decent white head with great lacing. Plenty of carbonation also. Light gold in color. Slight hoppy aroma. Flavor is light and crisp. Finish is slightly dry and a little bitter.

Hazy yellow colour with white head and some good legs.  Aroma is a bit grassy with a slight hint of pear.  You know its a Stella from the smell.  Fairly balanced if not too distinctive flavour.  Overall not too bad.

On tap at the Hilltop Inn. Ephrata, PA. Served in an Artois glass, no less. Not much in the nose, I was expecting more hops. Beautiful golden color, thick, white, long-lasting head that left a wonderful lace down the glass. Great mouthfeel - full but not chewy. Mellow but rich malt flavor, balanced well by hops. Better on tap than in bottle.
A real surprise, and in a good way. Nice crisp aroma and a nice bitter finish for a lager. Slight sweetness in the finish that I foung interesting.
Run of the mill canned shelf tackle, but saying that it’s better than most. The bottom run of the Belgium ladder.
draught. Gold, medium carbonation, no head. Corny nose. Corn, sugar, cardboard, just noticeable level of hops. Nothing special here, just Belgian swill. Better than American swill though.

Long-necked stubbie. Nice summery lager- pale straw colour. Light, grassy flavour with a little hop to it. "Premium Lager" it is. Not the best though- suffers in comparison to locally-brewed Heineken for starters
A golden clear glass of slightly sweet corn tastin’ beer with a sticky sour finish-yum. And well worth $9 a six pack.

On tap. Clear straw-yellow color with a thin,spotty white head. Faint aromas of light malt, corn, cut grass and hops. Nose overall disappointing. Plate was fairly thin and watery. Lightweight flavors of sweetish malt, corn and some hops barely sneak through. Taste reminded me somewhat of Becks; having a German lager character (same yeast perhaps?). Quick, somewhat dry finish. Nothing offensive, but very forgettable.

I was not impressed at all with this beer, but maybe I’m not a Belgian fan. This had too much bite from the bottle than I care for, but flavor-wise it wasn’t too bad. This is not a good beer when warmed and should best be servered as cold as possible (maybe the bite will go away if served warmer?)

Aroma: Sweet, malty. ... Appearance: Deep gold, with diminishing head. ... Flavor: Crisp, consistent, lighlty sweet, but slightly watery. ... Palate: dry, pleasing. ... Overall: Decent stuff, but I won’t go out of my way to seek it.

Truely one of my favourites. Too bad about the price. A good pale yellow colour. The flavour has hints of maize, with a good hop-flavour. Carbonation is also just right. I can’t find any fault with this beer.
Gold yellow, some sprankling, average and diminishing white head. aroma is hoppy, some sweet malt as well. Rather full palate, light bitter finish going to bitter. Good lager

33 cl Bottel
Color - Amber
Head - White
Aroma - Malt, Hops
Flanvor - Malt, Hops
Commen beer

On tap at Clintonâ€™s Ditch in Schenectady. Served waaaayy too cold. Very corny flavored, metallic, slight hop finish. Overall crapness in a glass.

2014, edited review. This beer has grown on me, nice euro hops, dry finish, clean taste.
12 oz bottle Slighty bitter, i didn’t find any thing remarkable about it.  An okay lager with a high price tag.

Growing up in Belgium my wife remembers this as the Bud of Belgium. It was very cheap to drink on base. It is light in color and not to powerful in taste, but it has a little more hops than a Bud. It is new to the area and is better on tap then the domestics when I out on the town for the night.

Urine yellow with thin head with long retention.  Aroma is sweet with sugar and corn notes.  Flavour has the smallest touch of citric acidity, stale gum, and warms to corn notes.  Mouth is fairly thin with a mild amarillo like finish.  Drinkable, nothing special

Clear golden straw colored, white fizzy head.  Nose was corny, white bread, spicy, grassy hops, and lightly floral.  Corn flavored, some metallic spicy hoppiness throughout.  Light bodied, watery and thin, adjunct laden finish.  Belgian Budweiser...
Not much remarkable about this beer. Slight metallic aftertaste. Works fine for washing down bar food.

Pours a nice light golden yellow.  Aromas of hops, grass, and maybe corn.  Taste is crisp with a nice mellow hop flavor.  One of the better lawn mower lemonades.  I’ve had this beer in the states and when I was in Krygyzstan, the european version is much better.
Drinkable....taste and aroma were not particularly noteworthy.  Spare head and lacing, clear with lively carbonation.
Bottle. This is the belgium Labatts or Molsons. A mass produced lager with no outstanding qualities. If your looking for something to quench your thirst it will do that but nothing more.

On tap at Houstons, 27th street and Park Avenue South, NYC.  Clear straw-colored lager having no head.  Notable carbonation.  Clean crisp hop aroma.  Light bodied that starts with light sweet malt and light hoppiness. Finishes dry with light hop bitterness.  A very good crisp and refreshing Belgium lager  that goes will with roasted chicken and butternut squash.
draft, in france, spain and in the US.  Bottle can get skunky.  Hoppy and well defined for a lager.  Slightly bitter, enough for most meals and occations without stading out.

Bottle (green). Had this beer at a family gathering. My beer was skunked. So were the other guest’s SA beers  but that did not seem to bother them. When I asked them what they like about this beer here some of the answers I received : Seem to be popular these days, nice bottle, good commercial ads on TV, it is imported ….To each his own I guess. No need to go any further. Why should I drink a smelly beer when there are outstanding Belgians and local  beers on the market.

12/4/05 : 12 oz. bottle. Not a lot going on here in any department.  Completely inoffensive "thirst quencher"/"lawn-mower" brew along the lines of Becks, Heineken or St. Pauli Girl.  An overpriced session brew if there ever was one.



Re-rate on July 12, 2007:  Rating this to style this time around, and in a more appropriate season -- which seems more fair.  Lasting head, good lacing, pleasant aroma.  Nice hop bite for a pilsener.  A very refreshing summertime brew, and as good a pale lager as you’re likely to find in the local supermarket.
On tap. Pale-ish yellow, rich foamy white head. Alcohol, seltzer odor. Soapy mouthfeel and aftertaste, mild malts, smooth.
Mainstream European pale lager that does a better job than its American equivalents. Not as much hop character as some of its neighbours, but I like it nonetheless.

Part of a mix-a-six. 11.2 green bottle. Served at ~49° in a lager glass. Super pale yellow/gold with a white, hazy head. Aroma is noble hops, grassy, some (corny?) sweetness. Initial taste is mildly sweet, quite possibly nothing else. The midtaste is grassy, nearly skunky, with some offsetting sweetness. Finish is light and assuming with some grassiness at the end. I have to assume this beer once tasted better than this, but who knows? Better than american macros, though.

Slightly bright and bitter aroma, light fizzy head, body is clear with a yellowish cast, crisp flavor, the initial bitterness is somewhat metallic, but the finish is better.  Drinkable but lacks character - not one I would buy again.  (Now I know why it was on sale.)

Best part of this beer is the smell. If you are new to beer, do NOT dismiss other Belgian beers because of this one. It is a Lager, not the style that comes to mind when immediately when I think Belgium.
Tap. Pretty tasty and refreshing. I was surprised to find out this was Belgian. Refreshing, tasty, but nothing super special.
This is the best pilsner in Belgium and one of the best in the world, if it was up to me. It has a soft taste and the day after you won’t feel like you hit a train with your head.
I like this lager. Slightly bitter, but easily drinkable. Mass marketing done well.
Bottle. Yellow colour, more dark than an average pilsner. Quite a lot of malt in the aroma. Light bitter taste, somehow metallic.
Very little aroma and the color is a light yellow.  The head is white and short lasting, but conisderable lacing.  A slightly grainy flavor but light on the palate.
On tap.  When I think Belgian this is not what comes to mind, but then it is a lager.  As far as lagers go this is definately better than most of the beer brewed for the masses here in the States.
Bland, inoffensive, not skunky but ...mediocre.  "belgian" for coors drinkers?
Looks plain, no head, and yellow as piss. Had this on draft and it was surprising. Not a bad flavor and a bit of a bock type aftertaste. Very fair, but better than any American standard
Nice Beer, bit bleachy head.  Commercial beer, mass productionm  not highest quality. Nice on draft when you can get it.
The appearance was nothing to brag about with a spare head and lacing.  I also didn’t really like the flavor.
Draught at Federal in Durham, NC. Clear, golden color with thin white head. Subtle piney hop aroma. Grainy flavor with a hint of hops. Metallic aftertaste. Not particularly good.
I wasn’t able to discover anything redeeming about this beer, the taste was especially awful. Can’t understand what all the buzz is about.
Tap @ Oak Cafe. Pale golden with film for head. Nice lacing. Decent floral hop aroma with lots of skunk lager. Very unbalanced flavor all grassy hops and skunk. Not my gig.

US Bottle pour - Small fizzy white head atop a well-carbonated, sparkling clear golden body. Smells of grain, grass, and some flowers. Starts off slightly bitter and finishes dry in an almost German Pils fashion. Light-Medium body.
At first this beer didn’t do much for me, but I find it to be a good "thirst quencher".  Nicely balanced.
Draught. Very light in color and texture. No head. Boring. Light tasteless, barely better than domestic crap lager. Pretty dry, drinkable but not worth drinking.
somehow the aroma was either swimming pool or lcker room, maybe it’s just me.
I didn’t find this to be unpleasant at all. I rather enjoyed it. Crisp, rather grainy, but not bad. As a mass produced lager, quite enjoyable.
out of the pottle. clear, thin yellow color. fizzy. minimal head. tastes grainy with light hops. not worth a buy.

Grassy, flowery aroma.  almost no hops whatsoever.  Very plain taste.  Unpleasant finish.  I don’t want to say sour because Lambiks are sour and Lambiks taste good to me...  Perhaps "metallic" is the phrase I’m looking for.  At any rate, this beer is not really very good.
Straw golden with a foamy white head.  Aroma was grainy and floral.  At least there was something there.  Taste was floral and got worse as it went down.  Not much to brag about here.
Draft in Daytona. Clear straw color with small white head that diminished slowly. Light sweet aroma. Medium body. Small grainy flavor with a short finish. Poor brew.

taste kind of like heineken.  nothing really special here.  2 dollars a bottle at the bar down the road, so not a bad deal.  ill sip on my yeti after coming home though, so thats the best part of this beer - is knowing that i can drink an awesome stout after this.

Pours a pale, clear yellow from the bottle with lots of bubbles.  Head is thin, but hangs around, probably because of reinforcements from the bottom.  Smells light a a bit stale, some wheat field.  Tastes stale and lightly bitter, nothing to wrte home about.  Not a great beer, in my opinion.
This beer is decent if you are forced to drink an import. Still really bitter as most European beers are but after a couple you’ll start not to notice it so much.

Golden blonde with a frothy white head.  Not much in the nose, maybe a smidge of honey and  grass.  Taste is clean but not flavorless.  Some hints at citrus, slightly acidic but cleansing.  Not much in the way of hoppiness.  Not bad for a premium lager.

Half-litre can.  Pours a light, almost greenish yellow with a large white head.  Slightly skunky.  Flavour is lacking.  Seriously lacking.  On the good side, there’s no bad tastes, but that’s because there’s very little taste at all.  I’m actually drinking it as I write this, and I still can’t detect any real flavour.  Clean finish, but generally overrated.  Drinkable, though.

On tap. Yellowy gold with a substantial white head. Grainy nose. Weak grain flavor. Crisp finish, and it is oddly drinkable, but not a good lager, for sure. Maybe you keep drinking it to try to find some flavor.

Smells grainy and vaguely of yeast and...I don’t know, funky somehow.
It tastes even less and really isn’t hard to drink, but neither is it a pleasure.
It’s a disappointment, not because of the flavour, but because of a lack thereof.
Not one of my favorites. On poured on the light side and light tasting. Had at Orange County Social Club. Skunky tin can taste and odor.
the best of the available everywhere beers in england. Usually has more flavour than the other draught lagers. Tastes like the can in a can.

Bottle.  Poured out a light gold color and with a thick white head.  The aroma was a little skunky like a Becks, but I could also make out some hops character.  It’s light on the palate, but not watery like most American lagers.  The flavor was crisp and slightly bitter with some grains and even a little banana on the aftertaste which gave it a little character.  It probably wasn’t worth over $8 for a six pack but definitely better than our domestic lagers.
Pours just like any other lager.  Golden yellow with a larger white head.  Odor is skunky and flavor is like a weak henne.  Not worth the price by any means.
highly carbonated, yellow color.  Light body and mouthfeel and noticible sourness.

Gold color with a fizzy white head and lively carbonation. Very sweet citrusy aroma. Grassy as well. Honey almost. Eh... flavor is a sour, grassy mess. Too bitter and rough on the palate to be worth making a session of.
Grassy, wet sock aroma over a sweet pils base; rather flavorless and slightly sour; harmless, yet quite unappealing.

Draft: Typical mild and fresh pils-sort of malt with medium to low hop bitterness but still noticeable.  Somewhere between a helles with too much coarseness and astringency to the malt, and a German-style pils that’s underhopped.




Bottle: Smells and tastes like wet grains and sour, moldy hay.  Completely unappetizing, and this was a cold draft pour at a McCormick’s Fish House.  Horrible, horrible beer - I at least expected it to be somewhat refreshing and flavorless.
This was the first time I actually regretted that i wasn’t drinking a bud light.  Piss yellow, no taste outside of the dredges of America’s "Rocky Refreshment".  Too watery, poor carbonation
Had this beer at a local bar on tap.  At least they served it to me in a cool glass, otherwise it would have been a complete waste of my $4 for this junk.

Piss yellow with a film of white head.  Slightly lightstruck, grainy aroma.  Mellow grainy flavors with a tinger of bitter and floral hop character, this character particularly noticable in the finish.  Mouthfeel is thin and watery.
"Wifebeater" seems to be drink of choice amongst English pub-goers. Over-carbonated, fairly tasteless. Standard keg lager stuff. Have noticed that bottles of belgian origin tasted slightly better

on tap-pours a thin white head.  Color is clear yellow.  Aroma mild grain.  Taste is grain and a Corona like ingredient, but better.  Good carbonation. A good lager, which they tend to be middle of the road.
Poured a pale yellow color with a white head.  Malty doughy aroma.  Malty flavor with a raw dough tartness.  Not really a lager fan but not a bad beer.

It sucks to live in Oklahoma. Just played at a brunch, and the manager knows I’m a big beer geek. When we were on a break, he says "Boy do I have a surprise for you. We got a new beer from Belgium." He then pours it in a wine glass. I thought it was a joke. Slightly darker than my drummer’s Bud Light, but nothing worth taking seriously.

11.2 oz green bottle, poured into a Stella glass. 

Pours a clear straw yellow with a fizzy, short lived head. patchy lacing

Aroma is cookie dough under skunk pee.
a little wet hay also.

Flavor is malty, a little sweet with a slight bittering finish. 

Better than BMC but not by much. Tastes better on tap.

Well i might be rating this too high, but as a Lager goes, it is a nice pleasent easy drinking beer. NIce hop aroma and palate, not much malt, but that isn’t expected either. I guess it is a beer that is easy to rubbish since it is so damn successful and popular.

The most overrated beer in history doesn’t deserve a real rating. Instead I offer a variety of quotes from my session with this beer.

’"This is the sweatervest of beers"
"No one would like this if I called it Budweiser"
"No one would drink this if it was served in a shaker"
"Proof that every country in the world is capable of crappy beer"
"Hey man I’m not drinking any more of this, can I get one of your Unibroue’s?"

Bottle, 33cl. With so many good beers why would the belgians drink a beer like this? Beats me! Classic european lager, a litlle better than most macro lagers and also better than Jupiler. This said, nothing much else to tell. Body is yellow with a big disappearing white head. Aoma and flavour are just normal. Not bad but if you want a belgium beer, you’ll easily find something better than this.
330ml bottle. One of my favourite mass commercial lagers. It has nice distinctive hops which carry on through the beer. Could do with more flavour and the palate isn’t great, but otherwise ok

This has surprisingly little flavor for a belgian beer.  I had heard good things about it, but it tastes just like most flavorless American lagers.  Carbonated water with a slight beer taste.  I’d drink it in a pinch, but it is certainly not worth the premium price.
A light lager with a hit of that characteristic belgian yeast flavor.  Not too bad on a hot day, but nothing to write home about.  Quite malty.

Draught.  At - shudder - Red Lobster.  Poured clear yellow with initial bubbling and an average soapy white head that lasted quite a while and left a sticky soap-scum "lacing" behind.  Aroma of icing sugar and stale grains, a little sour and vegetal on warming.  Taste - whoa! - burnt straw and burnt sugar, incredibly thin mouthfeel, very fizzy and incredibly harsh - I couldn’t finish it.  I know, I know - "it’s better in Belgium."  Right.
nothing special.  a good light lager that held its held long enough, didn’t taste skunked, and like Forrest Gump says "and thats all I have to say about that".
Golden.  Few bubbles.  Light rim of foam.  Grainy adjunct aroma. Sweet.  Crisp.  Good balance between sweet and dry.  I’d drink this anytime actually.
Dark yellow with fine head. Sweet aroma and taste with an unfortunate cardbord flavour.

I think one of the rateberians said it best when he called it "Belgiums Budwieser".  this is better than the bud but that is not saying a whole lot.  it is golden in color with a large head that is not thick.  Light hops in the smell and the taste this is most assuredly a lager beer.  This beer seems to be getting the same attention as the brits are giving it...  seems all of the "upper class" are drinking this beer because it the beer to drink (not because of it’s flavor).  At least it is that way here in Dallas.

From the can (into a Stella Goblet): Pours a clear golden with bubbly medium white head. Aroma is slightly soapy and skunky.
Flavour is fairly bland and mild with a slightly skunky aftertaste. Very popular beer but nothing special in my opinion. 
Nice goblet though.

Standard lager color, little vanishing white head. Mildly fruity and alcoholic aroma. Medium bodied. Nice malty flavor with fruity and nicely hopped aftertaste. Mild alcohol comes up in the end, aftertaste lasts.
This is Belgiums bud...... And that says alot. This is very skunky, and an unappealing drink
Good beer. Definately not Belgium’s best. But a good smooth, light but flavorful beer.

Ordered a glass of this stuff at the Denver airport on a layover.  Paid $6.25 for one glass (I know it’s going to be expensive there, but still). It wasn’t what I expected, but that’s partially my fault (I saw Belgium and figured it was Belgian beer). This was a skunky tasting lager with a skunky smell, an unremarkable taste, and, at least at the Denver airport, a high price tag. If you’re a lager fan, try it. I’m not and wish I’d gotten something else.

Lager is now the most popular pub drink in the UK, and Stella is the best selling lager. Brits are very image conscious, and brewers have had a hard time keeping up with the current trends, but Europe is back in favour and Stella has been promoted hard in one of the most expensive, long-running and artistic advertising campaigns in recent years - pushing the acclaimed Guinness adverts into the background. Stella is seen as cultured, historic and very intelligent - the ads promote the idea that Stella drinkers are sophisticated and clever by using easily understood stories in French, and then complete the kick with the pay off line: Reassuringly Expensive. Mmmm, I may shave my head, support Millwall, live in a boarded-up council flat and beat up my crack-addict woman, but I drink Stella, therefore I exist in a fantasy world in which people think I matter. The British nickname for Stella is "Wife-beater" - at around 5% this is stronger than most Millwall supporters are used to (most British lagers being around 4% or less), so the yobs and thugs would get drunk and then go home and hit their partners.
Having said all that, this is a fizzy but inoffensive drink of little character. 

The UK stuff is brewed in Wales rather than Belgium. In the same brewery as the "Irish" beer - Murphy’s. This must be  the Global Village we keep hearing about.

It is a very thin beer, and thin on the palate.  It has a regular golden color.  But not much of a head.  The taste is sweet, with almost no aftertaste.  Nothing bad, but nothing special.  I think alot of people who dont really like beer, get into this one because of the sweet taste.
Your average european lager. Pale yellow, bland finish with very little hop character. Nothing memorable.

Extremely yeasty, rather malty.  Hops are an afterthought.  Like many lagers, too sweet--way too sweet.  This tastes exactly like an American "pale lager" to me.  When I get to the end of the bottle, it is seeming extremely thin and bland.  There’s absolutely no excuse for the high price of this beer...why pay this much for an import when you can either buy an import, or buy a better, cheaper domestic, (e.g. yuengling lager).

On a night when the Tigers wiped the floor with the Bulldogs at Telstra Stadium and even Tooheys New in plastic cups tasted like nectar, at the post-match celebrations this still seemed mediocre. It’s marginally better than most of the other big global brands, but not by much. Pale gold, skinny head. Plenty of cereal in the malty aroma. Very sweet in in the finish.
Bottle. Golden with a whity head. Slightly yeasty aroma. Goes down smooth without much flavor. Very crisp and non-ofensive. My mom’s favorite beer.

Average belgian beer at premium cost.
Goes down easy, crisp. Golden color with nice head.
Run of the mill beer, very average and not much flavor.  Watery and in my opinion LESS flavor than Heineken

Pours a clearish gold, thin head that diminishes quickly.  Aroma is S-K-U-N-K-E-D.  Not that I expected any different.  It’s possible that these euro lagers are pretty good when fresh and on tap, but I have not had a euro lager yet that was in good condition and was enjoyable.  This one manages to be a little more malty and flavorful than many others.
Tastes like every other european lager/pilsner.  Clean and refreshing.  A little more flavor than a heineken or something.
Golden yellow, with a very large frothy white head.  Corn, yeast and malt aroma.  Flavours are mostly corn and malt, a bit dry, very light.  Not that great, considering the price...

not as bad as i expected.
a very easy drinkable pilsner.
A bit sharp but less then jupiler.
good carbonated.
on tap-it pours golden with a decent head.taste is decent with a nice finish so all in all its not a bad beer.
This beer gets a lot of underserved attention.  Skunky-sweet with the taste of bread, almost as if someone dropped sugar into a Budweiser.  The finish is sickening-sweet.  Not a fan.

On tap - Poured golden with a nice white head.  Aroma is of sweet malts and yeast.  Flavor is grainy with a slight bitter hop finish.  On the palate this is light and crisp and clean.  A much better choice than the American macros at the bar.
Typical macro lager, but it had a slight bit of breadiness in the flavor that saved it some. As usual, carbonation and bitterness were too up front and covered everything that could be good up.

Apr05 - Slight sweetness and some hop aroma.  Clear yellow gold, with good lacing and head.  Slight sweet and pleasant hoppiness.  Some bitter tanginess, nice frothy medium mouthfeel, with lingering hops.  A bit too euro trash for my liking, but I was pleasantly surprised even though it is nothing extraordinary.

pours golden in color with a medium sized head, aroma is a little skunky and sweet, taste is also sweet with a small presence of hops, so far to date one of the better pale lagers i have tasted, but thats considering most are also macro brewed.

Clear yellow color with an average head and good lacing.  Aroma is very enticing.  The beer tastes slightly bitter and finishes relatively clean.  Nothing too impressive but nothing to complain about either.

to my regret, this beer is not any attractive for me.
we don’t select stera but Bass at bars in Japan.

This is like the budweiser of Belgian beers.   Nice color.  It’s a good beer but not a great beer.  It’s an average lager that is dependable and a couple of notches above Miller.  Smooth with a little skunk bitterness on taste which is what you get with average lagers.
This is a good beer.  It has a wonderful color and the yeast undertones add to the hops.  I do not get the Belgium out of this so I would say this is more like a Hefe.
A pretty descent lager with an mettalic aroma, but certainly not one of the best. (Bottle 25cl, can 33cl)

Bottle Picked up a 6-pack of this stuff cuz I got a cool free glass with it.  Typical slightly sweet bread aroma, very nice creamy white head that was still there at the bottom of the glas.  Otherwise  bright clear yellow with lots of effervessing bubbles.
In general pretty good...for the style.
The free glass I got is pretty neat !
I hate this mass produced metallic nonsence that i serve to all the bastards that come into my work, its nick named "wife beater" for a reason.
OK head breadlike aroma, typical premium lager, This was 5,1 ABV
"This Belgian lager has a light little fruity taste to it. No hoppy taste. Noticable carbanation. An average beer. Would drink it again, but not worth the money."

Can given to me from England. Aroma was little metalic but that may be due to the fact it was warm for awhile duing transport then re-refrigerated. Yellow body with big foamy head. Left lots of lacing and had some bubble action in the body of beer. Flavor would compare to most domestics in the states, but this one was not bitter or watery. Taste was smooth and at 111 degrees today a good refresher.

Actually very mild in all respects. Very muted nose, though a bit skunky. Pale yellow, with a very large head, and extremely carbonated. Flavor is not nearly as macro as I expected, with a bigger hop profile than I anticipated. Washes down fairly well, but leaves you with a feeling of emptiness, especially since it’s so thin.

Bottle. Medim yellow with a ring of bubbles. Nose is slightly skunky and sweet. Taste is very average and tastes like a sweet macro. The sweetness is a little over the top and does not mix well with the slight hop presence. Not offensive in anyway, but not great. This would probably improve considerably if I were eating with it.
On Tap at Kahootz:  Pretty light in flavor with relatively little carbonation.  No strong hops or malts present.  It had a sour grape aftertaste.  This isn’t one that I would go for again.
Very easy drinking lagerwhich with the strong marketing it has recieved  is the reason it is so popular not a lot of taste but a good everyday drinking beer

had this on tap in toronto.  i could detect no aroma, but the golden color, and thick head were inviting.  the flavor was very mild with only the slightest hint of a bitter aftertaste.  overall, i found nothing exciting about this inoffesive brew.

Miscellaneous
o Banana,Bubble gum
o Grape, Raisin, Plum, Prune,Date
o Apple, Pear, Peach, Pineapple
o Cherry, Raspberry, Cassis
o Wine - white, red
o Port - tawny, ruby
o Cask wood (e.g., oak)
o Smoke, Tar, Charcoal, Soy sauce
I finally tried this the other day.  I was not that impressed, but it was the only thing on tap that appealed to me.  Nice glass though.

Not very aromatic , but the taste is rather good. Stronger than most lagers with a slight touch of bitterness. Propably one of the best mainstream beers that you can find practically everywhere (at least here)
my friend said that this was really good, but i tried it and wasn’t too impressed.  rather common taste, maybe, mabye a bit of spice.  Not worth paying more for this.
Looks much better than it tastes. Grassy aroma followed by a predictable, simple taste. Quite bitter, which I usually like, but it just didn’t quite hit the mark for me.
Bitter, clean...A stylish beer thats good for pounding. Nice golden glow, starts off skunky, then finishes clean. This beer is the official beer for Valentines Day!
pours a light clear yellow with a white head.  No distinguishable aroma.  Flavor is crisp, refreshing, and not at all unlike a mass produced "beer"
Poured a nice head.  Good carbonation with a slight amount of hops throughout.  It was very refreshing and a easy drinking brew.  Very nice in the summer.
This is an average beer at best, but it has a little bit of a citrus bit and some grainy malts.  Why do people even bother with this style?
Little stronger than most draft lagers, smooth, goes down well but suffers, i assume from old inventory in some US bars where it tastes off.
Pours copper gold with a decent white head.  Smells moderately of straw and grass.  Taste is slightly bitter with some caramelly pepper undertones.  Not bad for a session beer.

Pale golden lager with a bright white, averaged life head. Aroma dominated by light malts and some noble hops. Malty flavour, with some doughy characters and apparent late hopping with nobles. Medium bitterness with a nice clean finish. One of the better ’Premium’ Lagers but a bit overrated as i dont think it is very different to many of the others on the market,  just has classier reputation here in Aus.
Beaconstreet tells me this is, in England, like Budweiser is in the US, just all over.  This was kind of skunky smelling...this was like Rolling Rock but slightly better
Pours a light gold with lasting creamy white head.  Not much flavor. Light and crispy beer.  Hoppy.  Slightly bitter finish.  Good lacing.  Not a complex beer, but still quite solid.
Good beer.  Nice crisp, refreshing flavor and a good finish.  Basically tastes like an American lager.

The 11.2 oz. bottled version pour clear and pale yellow in appearance with a medium bright white head.  The aroma features straw and light hops.  But, this beer is dry throughout--from initial palate to long-lasting finish.  Mid-palate is unremarkable; yet, this medium-bodied Pilsner-style lager is refreshing and thirst quenching.  A respectable offering in the right setting.
(Bottle 25 cl) Pale golden, decent head (for a pilsener). Dry, soft body. Pleasant alright with just the right dose of hops to distinguish it from the more bland macrobrews. An OK pils. 030897

I don’t know why I was expecting a Belgian-style beer.  This reminded me of a macro German Pils, only not quite at even that level.  Hoppy aroma, white fluffy head.  Very carbonated with hoppy palate and dry finish.  Very little to talk about here.
Very clean, drinkable beer.  Light flavor, goes well with spicy or strong flavored foods.

Pale yellow gold hue, soft foamy white head, but falls quickly, pale malt, floral hop aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with pale malt, sweet corny note in a mild hoppy finish. A standard international lager

(Draught at Koala, Prague)
Straw yellow colour, Quite good head with some lacing. Aroma from hops and citrus. Watery. Flavour from cooked vegetables. Almost no bitterness. Light bodied.
Bottled. Pale goldne colour. Small, lacey head. Weak, hoppy aroma. Typical pale lager taste. Worse than Jupiler.

Had a couple at an Indian pub called the Curry Pot right on the South China Sea in Stanley, Hong Kong, while enjoying Thai curry and watching English Premier League football on the big-screen telly! It was a heavy-duty cultural mellange that rendered Stella Artois a bit thin by contrast. But then, the food was spicy, so the lightness and drinkability were helpful. It took TWO 600 ml glasses to cool my tongue, and it was a pretty nice way to do it. My son had a less spicy meal (bad choice -- don’t order a hamburger at an Indian pub in Hong Kong!) and a Guinness Foreign Extra Stout (excellent choice anywhere on the planet!). He made both the worse and better selection than I.
Stella’s not a very powerful beer in terms of taste, but it had a nice head and a cool refreshing taste. This is not something to drink on its own -- it does well with spicy, hot foods, or with pizza.

For a low rated beer, this stuff is good on tap, only when the lines are clean. Pours nice with a big white head. Nice hop aroma and subtle spices. Tastes smooth with a nice peppery bite. Crisp and dry with some grassiness.

Pint can from VW Kelso. I used to think this was the biz, but either I’ve changed or this has gone downhill bigtime. I used to work for Oddbins years ago, and at that time they sold the" brewed under licence" version, and they also managed to get a parcel of genuine Belgian brewed stuff. The staff of the branch I worked in (well, 3 of us!) did a blind tasting to see which version we prefered..the under licence version won hands down!!!! I’ve not tried this for a long time, but I’m not impressed, nothing more than a bog standard lager now.

Bottle Green Mill. Chi,IL. Looks like a heineken and everything about it screams heineken basically. Light head with yellow body. Nose is dry. Very bitter and dry with little mouthfeel except a bit of stingyness.
Was not impressed, but this wasn’t a bad beer.  Aroma from the bottle was kinda skunky, head didn’t last long, watery aftertaste.  Highly drinkable, but nothing to write home about.

Stella is attempting to penetrate the US market for mediocre homogenized corporate import lager--and they’ve formulated the product just right to appeal to the ranks of Heineken and Becks aficionados.  Finely balanced non-taste, with a hint of overhopping to make it seem European.  Stella’s no better in Belgium or the UK, where it appeals to the same pretentious crowd.  I’ll order it where there’s nothing better to show the Belgian flag--though as I do, I’m wishing yummy Primus was making the jump instead.
The european bud light. I have drank this every way possible- warm, cold, bottle or tap.. anyway you get it, its still comparable to a mass-produced beer from the states. Pretty boring.

I have had this one a number of times but have never been particularly impressed. Sampled on draft for this rating the beer poured a medium yellow color with a medium sized white head. The aroma is light and fairly nondescript. The flavor has a light malt element but otherwise is bland and inoffensive.
Had a pint from a Bar. Absolutley stunk horribly, I mean like, really bad, like a farm. Tasted nothing like the smell, it was quite nice, and really looked good.

Transparent, pale yellow in color.  Frothy, creamy head and nice dissipating lace.  Smells like a lager - yeasty with crisp lemons.  Sticky and starchy on the palate.  Astringent yet crisp.  Lemon acidity.  Very yeasty backdrop, which distinguishes it from others in the genre.  Lemon shortbread aftertaste.

Poured from the tap, this pale yellow sparkling beer had a  medium sized foamy head that lasted a few minutes leaving some lacing on the glass. The aroma was light, crisp, and clean with notes of citrus and some of the characteristic skunkiness. The flavor was not particularly complex but easy to consume. There were notes of citrus in a slightly sweet malt base.
Not so bad for a lager...there is some malt sweetness to this which gives it a  rounder taste and less skunky than others...a solid thirst quencher.
Straightforward. A little skunky on the nose, but a good solid flavor and light finish. Not great nuance, but enjoyable all around.
Not your typical Belgian brew, but very good none-the-less. A good go-to beer (if you can afford it).

Faintly hoppy with some citrus notes, not too skunky, tastes fairly fresh. I imagine it would be better on tap, like you see in those cool commercials. Better than your typical American lagers, but it’s really nothing that special.

Aroma is a mix between rising yeast dough and a skunk.  Maybe not as bad.  Doesn’t look too bad in the glass although the head dissappeared before i got my lips on it.  My biggest knock is the flavor.  I’m not sure what it is but I certainly know what it’s not....very good.  Somewhat light, tingely, on the palate but I’d rather drink champaign or have a Duval.  Overall, it’s overpriced and I’m having buyers remorse.

I’ve rethought this beer after chilling it down a bit.  Still not great, but somewhat refreshing when very cold.

Tap at Saharra’s Cafe in Jacksonville.    The club was exquisitely bizarre.  The beer was  excruciatingly mundane.  I was talked into this one by a cute waitress.  Not much better than a Budweiser.  I wondered if maybe they had poured me a Bud by mistake. Not even in the same league with the Bass Ale I had there.    Even a Newcastle would have been better...   11-12-2005 ....  rerate from a 33cl bottle.  Clear pale golden, no head. Light skunk aroma.  Typical euro-lager flavor.  Boring.

33ml btl. I really like this beer, even though it’s light. nice aroma with a bit of citrus, hops, and hay. nice small bubbles with a billowing, lasting head. slight lacing. this beer looks a lot better than a crap macro, despite it’s lightness, and it smooth and pleasant going down with a bit of bitterness, and some dry citrus . i think this beer should be rated a bit better.
Pours pale yellow with a small white head and some spotty lacing.  Sour malt aroma with a faint hop nose.  Pale buttery malt flavor.  Smooth and light creamy palate.
Draft.  A nice clean pour.  Golden yellow and clear.  Not much aroma.  A slight sweet hint of malt and a light taste of hops.

A true french product...weak! Don’t know why the brit’s love this crap?
Must be alcohol.

Bottled. Hazyish yellow colour, mediumsized white head. Aroma of maize with hints of bread. Smooth flavour of bready malt, a bit grassiness and bitterish hoppy finish. Maize and hoppy bitterness in aftertaste. Very wellbalanced, but not that special. 6 2 6 3 10


Bottled. Pale yellowish golden colour, mediumsized white head, that leaves slight lace. Aroma is maize, mild grains, some bready malts as well as grass and some mild floral and herbal notes. Flavour is  quite similar in a quite nice balance. Quite ok for a "big" lager.
Pretty mild all the way around-aroma, flavor and overall impression.  An easy beer to drink, but nothing that stood out.     A good lager with medium body.
Thin laced head, crisp, no bitterness. Nothing stands out about this beer, but somewhat refreshing.

Had it on tap with dinner. Straw Yellow in color, thin head, and a bit of carbination.  No real noticable aroma.  First flavor was that of any other lager..nothing special. However, had a nice bitter finish that was surprising.  Too expensive for what you get, and very over-hyped.  Not a bad beer, but would not buy again.
Golden color with a large  white head.  Excellent lacing.  Aroma of sweet malt with a hint of hops.  Flavor continues with more sweet malt/grain with a quick bitter finish.  Medium bodied.

golden pour that is attractive in the glass with a thin lacing white head. very light aroma that has a hint of earthiness and straw. taste is light mellow malt with a lemony finish that has very little bitter. rubbery mouthfeel.

Draft in Whistler, Canada.   Golden yellow with an average white head.  I had expected more, and I don’t know why.  Hoppy aroma, but flavor was not overwhelming memorable, and the aftertaste was a bit metallic.

Draught.
Yellow with white head, fully diminishing. No lacings. Aroma and flavor light malty and hoppy. Light body, watery, lively carbonation.

Had several cans of this on British Airways while flying to London (March, 2005). Looks and smells like a low priced American standard. But it doesn’t have that awful overbearing corn sweetness that dominates most American beers. Light bitterness, goes down very smooth with a medium finish. Very refreshing.

Green bottle poured yellow with a good white head and heavy lacing.
Aroma was malty,spice and a bit skunky.
Flavor was malt, corn with a heavy metalic finish.
Great lacing, but not that good of a beer.

This beer does not offer a lot of flavor but personally I find it relaxing. It has a little of the skunkiness you find in Heineken but it isn’t as overt. It is definately one of the better mainstream commercial lagers on the market as it is a highly drinkable beer. However, it seems to lack a distinct taste that sets it apart from its competitors.  In a few words: kind of bland but not offensive.

Can.  Golden color with a decent white head.  Good lacing.  Aroma is a touch stale and lightly malty.  Lighter bodied, well carbonated.  Initial sweet tastes are quickly balanced by hops.  Somewhat crisp.  Decent
Sweet hop aroma. Clear yellow colour with poor head. Sweet malt flavour. Fizzy palate. Good summer BBQ beer when flavour is not important.
One of the best lagers I’ve had. Not too bitter, fresh flavor, can’t expect more from a standard lager. Great beer for a night out/on the couch, but not for tasting.

People call this wife-beater or some such unpleasant name. The common drink of tramps and low-lifes. Yet it has a classy advert on the TV. And the tag-line "Reasurringly Expensive". It’s a decent enough drink. Much cheaper in France where it seems to be regarded as the common and everyday beer that it is.

Thought this was Italian as I had it at an Italian dinner. Pretty good though it was slightly skunky in smell. It looked champainge like and tasted that way too. Very light but pleasent with a nice bubly body. Not earth shaking but good,
Just another pilsener like all the rest.. It tastes not incredible good, not bad either. A bit on the watery side.
A fairly decent lager, better than most offered at local bars.  Nice, crisp and fruity tasting.  Definately worth the money.

Classy looking bottle and label are a little misleading.  Although this beer is not overly bad, it doesn’t impress.  Enjoy it if you are offered one for free, but there are better ways to spend your $$$.
a good beer. It’s nice change of pace beer.  Clean crisp fresh flavor -- a summer time drink.
a very good beer. light taste goes down very smooth. kinda expensive for a six pack but still relatively easy to get.
The best and only way to describe it is a way too overpriced version of Budweiser
smells and tastes like every god-awful premium lager in the world. rotten stuff.

Straw-golden pour with a thick white head.  Aroma of hops and some off-aromas as well.  On draft, but smells like it came out of a green bottle.  Flavor is light on the malt and has the appropriate level of hop bitterness.  Once again, there are some off flavors as well.
Overrated.  Looks good enough, with a clear gold finish and full head.  Bitter taste isn’t too bad, but the aftertaste leaves me reaching for a glass of water afterward.  Overall, nothing special.

I tired the argentinian version brewed by the local Quilmes brewery. Watery, flat, a little dissapointing. Better than average aroma, perhaps fresh and with grassy notes. Too pale. I agree on the unpleasant afterstate.

Pours a pale yellow gold with foamy white head.  Aroma is very malty and sweet.  Flavor is also very malty and watery.  Taste is not very complex, but not totally flat either.  Overall, a pretty plain brew.

Pours a clear gold with a medium-sized fluffy white head. Aroma is of sweet malt. The flavor is sweet and malty upfront with a bitter hop finish and a slightly metallic taste that is unpleasant. A decent enough beer, but the finish almost ruins it.
A watery and slightly bitter pilsner beer. Light standard colour. Very similar to Tuborg pilsner in every aspect. A refreshing but boring beer - would be fine on a hot summers day.

my second most consumed beer after jupiler.  again, what a waste of my time in belgium.  but it’s quite nice.  i really wouldn’t mind drinking it even today if the supermarkets are not charging $14 + tax for 12 pack.  damn, i used to pay like 180 belgian francs for 24 bottles. (250 ml i recall)  that’s like $6 for 24.

Okay, so its a mass produced crowd pleaser from a huge multinational and I’m not supoposed to like it. However I’m hard up this week and 24 330ml bottles cost £10.99. And its still beer. Lager hop aroma (saaz?), hint of sulphur, grass, but not unpleasant. Taste fairly flavoursome, not too bland, finish fairly hoppy. Its not that bad, far better than the Millers, Budweisers, Carlings that I’ve tasted.
Poured yellow with a big white head...very malty lager...nothing special here...

Draft.  You know, I used to like this beer.  Then I went to Belgium.

Belgian Bud just doesn’t cut it anymore

Bottle. I was expecting crisp and clean and maybe a little light.Instead, found it to have a citrus/metallic note that comes of as kinda skunky, further muddling a nothing special beer. Another marketing scam.  I wonder if GM markets Chevy Cavaliers as luxury imports in Korea?
BUY AGAIN? No
White head with golden color.  Nose of the European cheap lagers.  Flavor of same, very light and nothing too special.  Clean finish.
skunky.....not good at all.  high price, poor flavor.  overall i was very unpleased.  dont think i will ever purchase it again
has a mild skunky aroma.  yellow in color.  very fizzy head.  tastes like your usual imported green bottle lager.  nothing special.  WAY too overpriced.
It seems to tase better in a tin, agreeable for lager. Alas overpriced, for a market saturated with mediocre lagers, it fits right in. Better then Canadian, but what does that say?
Marketing Guru set this up.  An average beer at best, sold to the masses as better than the rest?????  Funky glass makes it better then it actually is!  Taste is ’so-so’

Light gold with thin head that has ok retention. Boring nose, some citrus and malt. Similar in the palate with some malt, slightly stale, but is overridden with a dilutive note.  It’s amazing in Oz retail that soooo many punters this beer is the business.

On tap at the Elmwood.  Pours beaming Yellow with high carbonation.  Aroma of yeast and wheat.  Taste is more yeast and wheat combined with alittle grain and rice flavoring.  Pretty dry overall with slight hoppy flavoring.  Very water and thin.  Drank this beer in Verona and I remember it being much better then.
Blond color. The aroma has some paper, and the taste is very simple, but both show a light maltiness; correct bitterness. I used to like this one more in the past, but now not really…
tap at andy’s I was expecting far more, I don’t love largers, But I have heard and read about this. Deep yelow with decent white head. Hop aroma and hop taste. OK
Not bad, but  alitle bitter, for my taste, considering it is a lager. BUbbling and refreshing, it is ok.

Bought in the 12 oz single..good packaging.
The beer is a slightly deeper yellow than most American macros.Large frothy white head to start and lacing lasts all pint.
The aroma is pretty inoffensive and mainly of cereal for some reason.
again this is inoffensive on the taste buds,..bunch of sweet cereals..and very little hop.
pretty good in the mouth not too thin for the style.
Drinkability is this beers reason to be here and it does not dissapoint!

If you go into a Belgiun beer hold and ask for a stella, they will {probably laugh and} tell you that stella is only served under bridges and behind bus stations. Pours a EXTREEM blond, froathy head. Med-high carbonation. Aroma is pure fule {boose} slight grain, more fule. mouthfeel is holow, watery, flat. Taste is of malt liquor, corn, rubbing alcohol, unfermented shugar, yeast resin. aftertaste is watery, skunky, boose on the breath. Verdict: Save you’re money, this is a european copy of a american lager {why would anyone do that?} buy a bud and stop pretending you’re out for anything other than a drunk. cheers

i had this on tap @ the george clinton concert.poured a typical yellow with a froathy white head.the smeel and taste was of lemons,and a bit of corn.the palate was a bit acidic.i guess this is the begian bud?

Faint aroma of corn and hops.  Appears as crystal clear straw color with a creamy white head that dissipates quickly but leaves tons of lacing, along with a noticeable effervescence of medium-large bubbles.  Flavor of light malt, followed up with strong hop bitterness.  Apropriately thin palate that makes this beer light, bright, and refreshing.
Pours a clear straw colour with a thin head. Malt and adjunct aromas.Taste is pretty run-of-the-mill. Alright but nothing I’d go out of my way for.

Bottle.  Best before date:  01/05.  Pours a bright gold with thin white head that dissipates quickly.  Aroma is hoppy.  Taste is fairly balanced.  A little on the hoppy side.  Pretty bland.  There is a weird chemical aftertaste though.  Not too much better than swill beers.
From A Bottle,Tap.Dark yellow in colour,cold,fizzy,chemical aroma.I have heard it called wife beater,I don’t think I could drink enough of this to find out if it’s true.

On tap.  Light gold pour, small head.  Pretty boring aroma.  Flavor is also boring, just some skunky saaz and light sweetness, light feel, but honestly, the best lager I think I’ve had in a long time.  Very easy going and not too light to be boring.

this was aight.  more skunky than i expected.  i had it at an upscale place in manhattan which had some decent brews on tap so i guess i expected more.  no flavor, just kind of carbonated and boring.  slight citrus hint but not much.  kind of watered down, which was disappointing.

Status Quo brew or "How to brew the mildest beer that we can market the hell out of and push on mainstream 
America?"  pretty boring.  This is not why I drink beer.

A clear golden colour with quite a nice head for this style of beer. The aroma is basically insipid with nothing bad but nothing to recommend it either. It is clean and crisp on the palate and has just a vague hint of hop bitterness balanced by a mild sweetness. It finishes clean but unremarkable. Overall it doesn’t offend, it is better than some, but basically it’s BORING! I refuse to pay well over the price of a local lager just to be bored!

Seems like a long way to go for a beer that is just like every boring domestic already here.  I can’t think of one good reason to spend $1.50 more for this than an MGD, when I can’t think of a good reason to buy an MGD in the first place. Best thing I can say is it doesn’t take too long or involve much distraction to drink one.
Although sometimes referred to as a "Budweiser of Belgium," this is a decent pils type of brew. Had good pale maltiness to it, with some grassy/citric hop presence. Easy to drink.
This is a nice utility pils that is easy to drink.  If I have friends along for a drink who don’t think they like Belgian beers, I give them this and they are totally comfortable.

Along with Jupiler , this is the only ale worth bothering for in Belgium. No surprise they are both interbrew.
Nice beer for a night out, but only 2nd place here!!!
Good yellow golden pils. Clear pils nose. taste is clean, on the light side and ends with a hoppy touch.

Gold color with a quickly disipating white head and very little lacing.  Unpleasant aroma of skunk (and Heineken) with some hops.  Flavor not unpleasant but not memorable.  Very watery.  Finish was fairly dry.  This could be a fair warm weather lager but there are so many out there that are much better.
This is a very standard macro lager, nothing too different or special. Rather light and watery, fairly crisp, and thirst quenching when ice cold. I wouldn’t pay much for it, though.

Well, for the most popular beer in the world, it’s a damn sight better than Bud or some other such garbage. It’s an acceptable beer that will always quench thirst without necessarily offering great satisfaction. It’s light and kind of perfumy, and is best drunk before getting to warm or else forget it. A stadard lager with a nice glass and more reputation than its counterparts.

Not my favorite Belgian beer but, it’s not bad. The aroma is slightly sweet and cheesy with a bitter hop reminiscent of medicine. The flavor has a malt that is like wheat and there is also a citrus like taste. Thin Palate.

This was really dissapointing. More or less a standard lager, with a light feel to it.  Yellow colour, white foamy head. Faint aroma equally of hops and malt. The hop profile barely showed through and left me uninspired.

Yellow, nice sized white head. Pretty standard lager, aroma and flavor wise. Nothing special, and it’s a lot pricer than a Pabst...update...I just had a fresh unskunked six pack, and it’s better than my original rating. Upped to a 10 from a 7.

Bottle.  Yellow with pale white head.  Aroma of hops and malts, nothing else.  Decent flavor, average on the palate.  Last drop was as good as the first drop which isn’t saying much. Very average beer.

Very pale golden colour, with a moderate white head, that fades fairly quickly.  Pale malt aroma, a trace of grassy hops.  Flavour is refreshing, pale malt, light grassiness and a short finish.  I was lucky enough to get an unskunked bottle.  Okay, but like about a million other beers.

As a student at Leuven, this is the beer to drink!
and I’m so lucky that’s a beer I like a lot! It’s only lager, but when there’s a party, there’s nothing else I need!

Just another beer I have tried.  Unbeliveable!!!  This beer was ok, I had a six pack is this 75 characters?  Why do I see so many ratings that are under 75 characters???  Must be from the old school days, does spelling count on this site?  I hope not as most of us are likey 3 sheets to the wind.
Can. Very dark colour with a blue head (I must admit the light was a bit dodgy). Boring lager with slightly more body than usual.
Oxfordbackpackers. ligth golden color. Middle white head, nice head taste!  Weak aroma, malt. Bitter malty powerfull taste.

Draft. Golden lager with a thick big bubbled white head.  Corny grassy aroma. Lightly sweet malt and adjuncts with a wee bit more hops than you mass produced swill.  Body is medium, but beer is damned boring...and expensive (6.50 a pilsner glass at Pied de Cochon.)

If people decided what beer to drink on smell alone, no one would ever drink this beer.  I can’t even describe the scent...just that it was awful.  The beer itself is a pale yellow with a foamy white head, but not what I expect from a lager.  I guess the taste was ok, but again, not what I expected...alot of hops, with only a few bits of malts and a decent amount of bitterness.  Very thin body, and the aftertaste matched the original flavor.  If you are going to pay for an import, get a Duvel.

Ehh, who let the skunk loose?  Light yellow, lots of bubbles, decent, white, foamy head.  A little hops in the aroma to accompany the skunk.  Flavor is just weird...I guess some malts, but a pretty good hop hit.  Thin; watery.  Will never buy again.
Tap. fresh malt flavor. a boring lager. and a bad belgian. one is enought of those.
A little boring, but refreshing. Too thin. I wouldn’t have it again. I don’t see how lagers are becomming so popular in the southern UK when there are quality ales on draft and usually cask!
Solid lager.  Slightly bitter but not overwhelming.  Best when served quite cold.  Watch the sell by date.  The closer the bottle is, there’s a tendency to get quite bitter and unpalatable.

Hyped as some sort of crazy alcohol content super beer.  Not really that impressive.  Kinda sweet, with a bitter finish.  Hoppy with a honey hint of flavor.  Not looking forward to taking the next sip, but had to choke it down for the price.
(draft) I asked for a Belgian and got this awful thing.  I don’t like lagers, and this was a pretty bad lager.  Bland mixed with boring.

Nice lager if you care for the full bodied bitter type.  Sampled at Ferryman’s Pub at the waterfront in a gold rimmed girlie lager glass!!
Nice medium bodied flavour for a draft with a fantastic hoppy taste hitting you half way through a mouthful.  

Have had it out the bottle as well, which seems to have a higher ABV 5.6% i think, if  it’snt chilled it is quite bitter. but none the less a nice beer to drink on any ordinary occasion
Shining color. Compact foam but not much long one. Bitter with flavor of malt. Balanced.
Light golden colouration, pretty standard appearance. Floral hop and light honeyish aroma, some lemon detected. Flavour, light malt, drying bitterness and floral, citrus hoppiness. Very average
Stella is an ok beer but I  find it bland, and boring. I know in Europe it has a great name, but i think its just average.

Tasted, notably, at a romantic dinner to please my fiancé and poured into a stem glass. Glowed a clear gold with large irregular bubbles failing to form a head. Watery thin and overly carbonation leafy corn lager that made me wish I had ordered a glass of wine. Became a little sweet and cloying when it warmed. Bland and lifeless, massively advertised Macro-stew of a beer that didn’t even sit well with my food!!!

I tried diligently to avoid consuming this beer on my trip to Europe, but when our dinner plans fell through and we found ourselves at the emergency backup dinner establishment, this was all they had besides Bud, Michelob and 255ml bottles of Castlemaine, and I was way burned out on soft drinks... 




Anyway, aroma is very faint, just a little sweet, light maltiness and floral hop character.  Light-medium yellow color, very bubbly, average head.  Flavor is dry, malty and lightly bitter, clean and having a very light amount of hop flavor.  Balanced, I suppose, and not offensive, really.  Palate is crisp, the body is undoubtedly light.  Just sort of a generic "beer" type of drink.

I paid 3 bucks to add this notch to my beltloop, and at least it wasn’t a 300 dollar call girl who didn’t have 3 inputs.  Pale yellow with medium head and some lacing, which gave this a 2 for appearance.  Aroma of mild hopcit, and a noticable thiosulfate skunk odor.  Tastes rather bland, with some hopcit, and a fairly crisp, smooth finish.  I won’t buy this again, and with all the great Belgian beers out there, I can’t understand why this is so huge in Europe....
On draft.  I’ve tried Stella before in a bottle and this is much better.  A little bland, but easy drinking.

Weird, weird, weird.  I do not like it.  It smells and tastes like Pine Sol.  Yuck. ***Second Rating: After having this on tap in Boston, I realize that I probably got a skunky bottle before.  It’s still not that great, however.  It’s very light in flavor and has a bit of a corn flavor.

Well, it was free at the change of command reception.  That’s about all their is to say.  It’s a very average pils that’s not complex. Color and aroma is standard with no outstanding characteristics. A bit hoppy on the palate and a clean finish.  A snoozer.
Golden amber in appearance, with okay lacing. A great hoppy aroma. Really good on the palate. Nice and smooth, easy drinking. Perhaps a good session beer.
This beer smelt like pine needles when first opened up, but then that smell quickly dissipated. What remained was a smooth, enjoyable and pleasant light tasting mellow beer. Two thumbs up.
on tap. This was horrible, I may have gotten a bad pint but damn. Pale golden colour but the aroma and taste were entirely of wet stinky cardboard. Just a dank beer.
Doesn’t smell very good.  Interesting taste that I can’t put my finger on.  Slight bitterness.  Looks like a typical lager.
500ml can. Golden brew, creamy white head, lots of lacing. Malt and small hop aroma. Fairly smooth, decent maltiness, hop aftertaste with a slight metallic/mineral note.

Looks like your typical bottom fermented brew, nice clean light golden color with a decent white head.  Aroma of flowers and malt.  Initial taste was slighty lemony with a strong undetectable flavor that I was unaccustomed too.  Not unpleasant, just funky.
Out of the tap.  a light tasting yet full beer.  I can take or leave the beer for the price.

In the can aboard Brittish Airways. Gold in color. Lots of carbonation. Huge Belgian head upon pouring. In fact, I would call it frothy and pillowy. This beer smells like pork! Not skunky at all (in the can). Gorgeous lacing in my crappy little plastic airplane cup. Beer has a sweet palate with a low hop flavor. The killer head remains to the end at 30K ft. If this is the worst that Belgium has to offer, then Katy bar the door!
UPDATE May 2006: seems a lot more boring in the green bottle at KC Barbecue in San Diego. At least I got a free shot of Night Train.
UPDATE March 2007: On tap at Trovatos. Very pedestrian, as my pal bditty187 sez.
Pours yellow with white head.  It tastes fresh and has nice bitterness to it.  It is a good macro lager.  I would have again.
(bottle) your basic, crisp lager. i’m sure i could throw these back pretty easily. better than your run of the mill macro but nothing exceptional.

This was certainly the least of the beers I had while in Belgium.  I heard it refered to as the "wife beater’s beer" while I was there.  I wish our mainstream beers tasted like this though.  Poor as a belgium beer; but I would probably drink it if it was a local.

Gold tinted water is what it looks like.  cotton head that lingers around.  Little skunk aroma not like the other imports.  Not at all flavourful and very low carbonation.  Grass sourness whiel very watery.

Not a bad lager, but nothing exceptional.  A pale gold color with a decent head (immediately after pouring), it’s got a sweet malty aroma with a hint of bitter hops.  Better than U.S. macros, but I’m still tasting some corn-syrup sweetness here.  Clean, crisp finish.

Ooh, I liked this one. It was tasty.

I remember it as flavorful, with a good taste. The bottle it came in seemed very "upper class" if you will, and it was actually kind of a pain in the ass to get open... but very enjoyable none the less.

I have had this beer several times a while back, but recently had it at a high-end restaurant in my area who had it on tap.  This beer explodes with flavor with a great meal.  Filet Mignon was the choice that night, and I have not had a beer/food combo this good in a while.  A pleasant surprise.

White medium lasting head. Pale golden color. Aroma is malty with corn and light hoppy notes. Flavor is moderately herbal with hoppy and cereal tones, ending in a balanced, slightly hoppy finish. Light bodied.

Nice head with a golden color.  Smooth taste with a light body and a bit malty.  Has a bit of a skunk to it but that is the green bottle, I am convinced.  I do not think it is as bland as some, and I do get it only when on tap.  I refuse the green bottle!

Freshly tapped:
Appearance: clear, golden color, with a prodigious, snow-white head of foam, pristine, creamy, inviting.
Aroma: slightly hoppy, with a typical lager smell, dry and clean, still fresh, though this is the very last pour from this keg.
Taste: Crisp, tidy hop bite up front, slowly fading off, but returning with each sip, very smooth, eminently refreshing. A sweetish taste emerges, with notes of honey and citrus. Light bodied. Snappy, tasty, with a pleasant finish. 
I anticipated liking this less. In fact my first try was from a sample bottle provided free. Wasn’t moved, even disliked it, at first, but it grew on me. On tap, as you can tell from other reviews, it’s quite a nice, simple, thirst-quenching, quaffable pils. I can easily understand it’s popularity. There’s just enough flavor to make this well worth drinking, and not be just another "pizza chaser", bland lager.

11.2oz bottle: pours straw yellow with a white head. A bit of a hoppy taste, nothing too special, but not bad. I’d prefer this over most domestics, but I’m notabout to pay a premium price when there are far better beers around.

New review:
 The old review’s a bit embarrasing so I decided to rerate this. And is there better way to do it than fromm one of the fancy 0.75l champagne Christmas/New Year bottles of this, brewed in Belgium (Zagrebačka Pivovara brews Stella for Croatian market) ? The cork was damn hard to get out, and the pop in the end was weak.  Poured a pale yellow/golden colour with a big white head that went away fast leaving scattered lacing (App: -1). Nose... malt and peanuts with hints of maybe cabbage, sulphur and dust. (Aroma: -1).  Taste... fairly inconspicuous, flat, some nice lemony hoppines covering a malty body, some weak fruit, a hint of olive oil, and a nice herbal/grapeseed hoppy aftertaste. The flavor/palate ratings remain the same. You can certainly find a lot worse macro Pale/Premium Lagers, and I can dig the hops used in this, but I’ve had better. I was thinking of reducing the score a little more because they didn’t go with Stella Noël, and they only put the regular Stella in a fancy bottle, but nah. It’s a 2.5. 
 

Old review:

Well, it’s not bad, the colour’s nice, the taste is a bit malty, and watery, but not too much, sometimes even pleasant, passable for a lager. It wasn’t offensive at all, but I drank far better ones.

500 ml can. Clear pale blonde color, medium fugaceous head. Slightly fruity and malty aroma. Weak flavor of fruits and malt. Very weak bitter finish. Light to medium body, lively carbonation, watery texture. Cheap and boring.

bottle from local bodega,
palee yellow small white head,lost of carbonation. not too bad,althouh thid ant what i thnk of when i see a beer ’s form belgium.nothin much fun here

I thought the bottle I has was skuny.  It was a nice lighter color, I did enjoy that, but the taste left something to be desired.  The taste was skuny and it was a llingering skunk.  Not a fan at all, and in England it is like Bud or Miller, absolutly everywhere.

On tap @ the Northstar in Philly.  Finally decided to try it after listening to all the hype.  Poured the classic straw-yellow color with an average snow white head.  Not much of an aroma to speak of here, just a slight tinge of malt.  Easy on the palate at one degree above freezing, but let this beast warm up and you’re dealing with some pretty harsh metallic/pizza-doughy flavors as well as an unpleasant lingering aftertaste.  I can think of several other beers that I’d rather spend 30 bucks on for a case.

Good God!  I can’t believe I hadn’t reviewed Stella Yet.  Inundated with this beer everywhere you go.  So called premium... but it’s a skunky steely sharp and bubbly concoction.  Must be an acquired taste.

Bottled.  Another mass produced lager.  This one is malty but also sweet and really quite nasty.  Favourite of those Englanders who like getting drunk quick - say no more!Score 1.1
