Subsequent rating scored 2.5. Average becomes 1.8

On tap at P. F. Changs.  Served in a nice looking Stella Artois glass.  Pale golden/yellow color.  The nose was weak but it could be due to the fact it’s been heavily chilled.  I believe I made out some hops and citrus in the aroma.  Light bodied, heavily carbonated and quite mild on the flavors.  Simple and unimpressive.  This one’s only a notch above bud and friends.

Light gold, with a small head which fades quickly to a thin covering.  Aroma dominated by a steely hop, without any nice malt to go with it.  Flavour much the same, lacking in malt, but without enough in your face hops to make it stand out from its ilk.
Nice enough, better than megaswill, but not great.
Good, clean lager...I wish it would come to Michigan!  A lot better after taste than Urquell without the funky smell of Heineken.

The apperance is a pale yellow color with a moderate white head. The aroma is hay and lemons.  The flavor is pretty tame with some malt accents showing through. Not a bad beer for mowing the lawn but it offers very little complexity. A good simple lager that does offend nor impress.
draft in prague: very simple clean lager is what you have here.  a nice floral aroma.  not alot of flavors working here.  not worth the money, even in praha.
Did not like this one a whole lot. pale yellow lots of carbonation and some wierd after taste .

Pours a classic golden/yellow color. Has a sweet grainy aroma. Has a normal lager taste to it. Can’t really tell it apart from most brew of this style. Maybe a little more flavor than some. Also not offensive at all. Certainly drinkable, but it is really expensive for what you get.

Yellow hue, with a very subtle malt and fruit aroma.  Smooth and light mouthfeel with moderate carbonation.  Almost no hop presence with a finish that disappears rather ingloriously.  A pretty good session beer though.  If I could get this for $2 a pint I would drink it more often, but it’s always overpriced for what you are getting.

There’s not much there- very light but fairly well balanced.  It would be o.k. on a hot summer day, but not a sipper.  I’d rate it above  BMC and some of the Mexican beers.  At it's price, it's certainly overpriced.

Rerate. Pours pale straw yeloow with a film of a white head left afeter it settles. Smells musty to me. Not much for flavor. Fairly watery, reminds me of Molson or Bud. It goes down easy but it’s like drinking water.

Bottled. This was among the "premium beers" offered at a trendy nightclub. Served in a bottle that was nearly frozen. Even then, I must admit, there was a pleasant little hoppiness that even made itself felt through the cold. And there is something of a malt profile, perhaps like a watered down Duvel. Still, it’s a beer that’s trying to be the Belgian Heineken.

So this is the famed Stella Artois, that I have always heard so much about.  Well I expected much more than what it really was, but it was still quite good.  I love good Belgian brews, but I think this is a little more commercialized than a lot of the other really good Belgian ales and such.  Nice light gold color with a somewhat hoppy bite.
Had this on tap.  Not a bad lager.  Light but has some bite to it, which I like.  Definitely a big step up from the typical macro lagers.
I think that this is a good every day beer. fairly bitter, good medium taste that dosen’t stick around too long.
Golden color, light weak aroma and taste, light body, light bitter finish. .
Nothing much happening here. Your standard lager with a small bit of bitterness.

On tap. Pale golden color with a decent off white head. Strange aroma that I honestly couldn’t pinpoint. Flavor of wet
straw, with a mild hop bitterness. I think
Belgium should stick with ales and let Germany handle the lagers. They do it
much better.
mediocre OK interbrew that’s not metallic tasting. Had a pint on the patio at end of a hot afternoon and could cope. Malt lager that is pale and on bitter side.
Nice smooth macro import. No indication of subsurface taste like malt or citrus.
Well you certainly can’t fault the appearance. Can leave a lingering after taste that’s unpleasant though

Very pale yellow, extremely light-yellow head, good density & leaving some lace. Duff nose, chaff-like, a bit meaty. Hayish, grassy taste, slight acidity a bit lemony in flavour. There’s a note of adstringency in the MF, corresponding to a solvent flavour in the taste. Watery texture, and as said, adstringency. Well, bland and rough at  the same time, as expected. To add insult to injury, this came out of a plastic bottle!
i thought this was an ok beer. poured out light gold, with a very large head.  didnt have the most pleasent aroma, but overall was a very drinkable beer from a macro.

A decent choice on a hot day.  On tap on an outdoor patio.  Not a bad aroma, at least it had one, sort of grassy I suppose.  Taste was pretty watery and crisp, but refreshing enough.  Slight bitterness at the end.  Oh yeah, it had a huge white head.  Not bad for a macro really, especially on a warm day, and will always be a decent alternative at places with macro like tap lists.

Well Stella Artios Premium Lager Beer.  Definately delicious!!  Clean crisp taste to it.  I’m more of a simple lager drinker than anything else.  Pretty refreshing and goes down smooth.  Nice light aromatic aroma.  Not too much not to little in everything.  Just right.  Although it seems to have a dry aftertaste in the finish, which makes me thirsty?  Thus, I need to chug more Stella!!  I like to drink it when I wanna feel a little different.
On tap.  Poured a clear golden color with virtually no head.  Smelled a little bit like Heineken, but flavor wasn’t as skunky.  A fairly crisp beer, though Belgium can do way better.

Pours a golden blond with a moderate white head. Aroma is a bit skunky and hoppy a la Heinenken or Becks. Honestly I think all three of these are brewed from the same batch and bottled differently. At any rate, taste is mildy grassy and crisp with some malt notes. A bit thinner than expected. But what can you really expect from a Belgian macro? Sort of refreshing and thirst quenching on this hot-ass night. The mouthfeel is a bit overcarbonated while still retaining some whispiness to it. The finish was a bit crisp while having some wateriness to it. Not a bad beer but still too much a macro to really enjoy.

Must say that the bottled version can get that old Heinken skunkiness.  There is much difference in a clean line tap version; almost another beer entirely.  Tap version has above average body and flavor, okay nose and a little deeper amber hue than more massed produce product.  Drink on a hot sweltering day.  It’s all good.
crisp and refreshing not a lot of flavor but again, compared to american macros this is great.  on tap served in a really nice looking goblet

Pours pale gold with a large white head.  Aroma is malty and grassy.  Flavor is typical Euro lager.  A little sweet, a little grassy and a slightly dry finish.  A little skunky in the aroma and flavor, but I will write that off on the green bottle.  Not one that I will have anytime soon.

Well, not stella[r].   500ml can in Canada.  tasted very similar to Holstein N/A, which was bad, but I could drink it.  Maybe I’m just not used to a beer this "dry" yet, but I’ll take a Bass Ale anyday!

On tap. Belgian macro brew - not much else to say. It was a choice between Stella, Coors or Bud at the restaurant. Of course Stella blows Coors and Bud out of the water, but that is not saying much. Light yellow in color with no head. Not much to smell or taste or comment on.

I really can’t tell if there is anything truly destinctive about this Euro macro lager....it’s like so many others in shared character. If I was pressed for aa answer,  I would say the malt body is a tad heavier than most macro light lagers and the hop delivery is late (perhaps over stated) and bites too hard in the finish leaving the tongue very dry.

Poured a light gold with a smallish white cap that dissipated quickly. Aromas of boiled grian hulls with slight sweetness and a mild floral tone from the long boil of the hops. Very carbonated...slightly thin in the upfront mouth feel then mellows a bit as the malt sweetness and bready taste is departed then the finish is crashingly dry.

Not bad but hyped too much. A standard Euro-macro lager...the type of thing you would expect to see shamelessly marketed in cans.

Seeing it was from Belgium I had to give it a try (also being that the only other things to drink were dirty water.....by that I mean Bud and Coors.). Anyway it has a light gold color with a medium head. Typical lager aroma, but much less harsh than Bud. Tastes worlds better than the average beer at this bar, but still not that great. Alright at best.

Had this one on a plane (and a few too many at that... jet lag is a fickle mistress, my friends-- especially after a few brews) that was bound for Paris and then Stuttgart, Germany.  It was probably better at the time because of the anticipation of being in the Holy Land Of Beer- GERMANY.  I’d have it again, of course...  Typical lager with a hoppy finish and sllightly citrusy.
A European Swill Beer.  Had this in London I believe.  Gold Coloring, no Head.  Possibly fruity... not much to quench the tongue...next please...

Bottle pours light golden, medium white fizzly head, spotty lacing, with minor carbonation.   Aroma of malts, but mainly grass.   Flavor is crisp, easy, slightly grassy but without much grain.   Finishes grassy, but clean.   A definite summer beer.

66 cl green bottle. Very cold which is a must for thr style(& especially on a midSummer evening.Poured a clear straw with nice fat bubbles & white short lived head like most macro lagers.Crisp fruity & refreshing but not at all bitter. Full mouthfeel not a bit watery.Alcohol finish. A nice beer in its place. My wife buys it for me in the supermarket when she’s unsure.
Cerveza normal, no es escepcional, pero tampoco mala.Poco aroma, Poca espuma, sabor forzado.

This beer is so weak. I would take this over the mass marketed Buds, Millers, Coors and Heinekens any day however. The aroma is very very faint but quite nice. It’s pretty average. I would drink this but you don’t get much out of it as far as flavor and body goes. It is quite thirst quenching.

Bottle.   Barley malt and straw aroma.   Golden yellow with moderately head.   Mildly sweet barley malt and mildly bitter straw flavor.  Okay body.   Belgium's Michelob - suckering American into thinking this is the ultimate Belgian beer.

Tap: Very pale gold with a white head that lasted the wole glass. Good lacing right the way down to the bottom. Not much aroma to speak of, some hops and malt. Not much though. Taste was the same. Pretty watery. Great fine carbonation. Odd bitterness on the finish. Average.
Bottle/Draft - Golden yellow in color with a white head.  Aroma is fairly light but some hops and faint malt. Easy drinking, but uneventful.  Not my favorite.
Tap: Golden in color with ample head and lacing. Tasted the malts and the hops provided a crisp finish. Clean enjoyable lager.

Tap: Poured a golden colored beer with a nice foamy white head. Aroma is mostly light floral with some malt. Taste is very light and refreshing with again some malt and floral aspect coming through. Medium carbonation with light body. Very little else to mention for this beer apart from the fact that it seems to be better on tap then in bottle. Overall, a refreshing session-type lager.
A beer I didn’t much like when younger -- many mass market beer drinkers mistake the hoppy aroma for skunkiness.  Nice and clean but not spectacular.
I didnt used to be a fan, but the last time i tried it, i quite liked it. there is nothing remarkable about Stella, but it isnt horrid.

The Belgians certainly know what they are doing when it comes to brewing beer. A very nice light aromatic lager that goes down smoother than any lager I have tasted. Add a lemon wedge for enhanced flavor.
The good thing about this crappy beer is that it doesn’t have a nasty corn/metal finish to it like BMC. It seems they have covered it up with a malty sweetness. A very middle of the road beer.
Not alot of aroma, beer was poured cold from a tap.  Was a nice surprise for a mass marketed beer.  Slight bitterness start to finish.  Nice
This beer reeked of skunk apon opening. Faint grain/hop aroma. Taste pretty bland with some hop tingle. Weak malt flavor. Somewhat crisp. Overall, blah.

ok.  i pounded this and a warsteiner at the same concert.  both on tap, and pretty fresh.  this beer loses.  it might as well be PBR or Old Style.  drinkable, poundable, but not soul quenching.  ok.  thin on  the flavor, but not on the palate.  i bet this would be good with chips, though.  THE SHAH SLEEPS IN LEE HARVEY’S GRAVE.

Fairly decent clean tasting beer.  Wish I could find it a bit more often around here!  Sadly can’t.  Has a bit of eau de skunk to the odour and flavour, but chilled down on a hot day it can’t be beaten.
My favourite commercial beer.  A good and lasting head.  For a mass produced beer this is top notch.

On tap at Silk City.  Yep, I broke down and had a Stella.  Before I had no respect for Stella drinkers - now even less.  Upscale schlabberwasser with some malt and hops - but you guys should stick with Heineken or Grolsch.

Draught. Shame that, in the UK, this became a mass market draught lager as many pubs ruin it (and others) by serving too cold and too fizzy. Some pubs do manage to get the best out of Stella - a malty bite, a steady head, a lasting hoppiness. Not as good as the adverts make it out to be!
I was kind of disappointed with this one. Had that Heineken skunkness to it. Wasn't too flavorful and very carbonated. Thumbs down for the cost.

I didn't mind the taste of this beer, but the aroma is very skunky.  nice foamy head and lots of bubbles; I have to agree with many of the other raters who said there is a "metallic" aftertaste.  It is very hard to explain.  It's like Corona with a bit of a bite.

Canned - 500ml. Limpid golden body topped with a dense white head. Fair malty and hopsy aroma. Ordinary carbonated bitter taste with a metallic final. Nothing to impress me (can't believe they call it "bière de luxe"...), but it is still a step above Heineken.

Draft. OK pilsener.  Aroma has light malt, kind of corny, faint herbal hops.  Flavor is same as aroma.  Lacks rich maltiness that a pilsener should showcase, and the hops don't taste like the classic Saaz or German noble varieties.  Definitely better than BMC, but not on the same tier as true Czech or German pilseners.

Draught. Overcold, overcarbonated lager with faint chemical taste. When it warms up and loses the fizz pleasant hoppy aroma of pepper and grassy herbs. Reasonably full body with decent balance. Best enjoyed flat and warm!

Tap.
Clean eurolager, and even has a bit of hops in there, although not enough to call it a pilsener, sorry.   Still, dull dull dull.

This is a Belgian green-bottle layman's beer similar to the Dutch Heineken in many ways. I'd imagine this is what a lot of Belgians drink in an everyday fashion on return from work in the evening. Although not a true micro-brew, there are indeed some traditional elements to this beer - unlike many actual micros who throw around the term "Old-World Tradition" along with the mass-produced outfits, this seems to actually possess elements of an older style. Typical European spiced skunk aroma. The color of this beer is a unique, semi-opaque copper-gold. The head pours thin and dissipates fairly rapidly, yet the remaining trace-head laces well to the end of the glass. It could perhaps use just a little more carbonation. The body is surprisingly light, like tonic water that's lost its fizz (taste elements aside, of course), yet Stella offers a similar crisp alcohol "kick". Despite the thin texture and too much initial sweetness, there is a pronounced peppery aftertaste which is balanced ever so slightly in the negative by a vague, colorcrayon quasi-waxiness.

Appears a very light gold with almost no head. Aroma and taste are both a little sweet with corn. No real character here. This is a mass produced brew that is no better than any other light macro lager.

This beer is a very underated beer especially on this  website. It may not the most flavorful beer, but this beer is an extremely refreshing beer. It is a very drinkable brew, with faint hop flavors. Very good for a comercial mass produced beer to say the least.

If you look at my profile you will notice that i am a lager drinker. The cheap stuff, simple all american stuff. I have to say though, that this is probably the best import i've ever had. Most imports seem to try to hard for me. Too much flavor, too much color, too much aroma. Stella is nice and gentle, just the way i like it.

Weak and very overrated beer ,nothing special,its ok to have one or two cans after work,but its a beer drink,my off licence does 6 for £5 deal, so I buy it once in a while,in my opinion its a bit weak for the belgs

To me Stella Artois is like the parchment paper of beer. It is light, thin, crisp, almost waffe like. The color is the faintest golden yellow of any beer I've seen. It pours with a nice dense head that seems to dissipate after the first sip. There is a slight fresh 2 row malt aroma. There is little to no body, the beer is almost saline like, it is so soft. Crisp clean dry finish, almost like you've not even taken a drink. Stella Artois is truly a work of art, a real shinning star.
Not too shabby.  Nice flavour - bit of hops in there.  Pale yellow, a decent nicely balanced mass market pilsener.  Something about the Belgians and beer - even their macros are decent.

Clear greenish yellow with thick fizzy white head. Grainy skunky and adjunct laden aroma. Bland watery flavor that’s drinkable but lightly metallic and grainy like rotten cereal. Finishes watery & metallic.

You think its hugely common in the UK, try living in Leuven where it's made. Cheaper than water, I kid you not. Definately not a what I would call an overly fabulous beer but very drinkable and enjoyable.  Great for kicking back and relaxing.

Ah, the great and notorious Stella Artois.  It will always be there for you.  A smooth drink, only slightly watery, but always a reliable benchmark of getting messed up by degrees.  Stella floods the UK market, by far the biggest beer sold over there.  What amazes me is how such a hugely common popular brew in England is considered something of a posh beer here.  In any event, Stella has a mild taste and nice light amber color.  Not too distinctive, but certainly trustworthy.

[draft - Airport Marriott - Greece, NY] Pours a faint straw yellow with a decent white head, good carbonation and good lacing. Has a bit of a skunky aroma to it. Crisp taste with a slightly bitter aftertaste to it. A bit reminiscent of Heineken, but not as bitter.

Straw body and loose soapy white head. Nutty, grassy, skunky aroma. Crisp, flavorful, and fairly easy to drink but has some Heineken stink breath qualities. Still, I can't help but think that the world would be a better place if the Budmilloors masses converted to Stella.
The clear and crispy taste, backsup its tasty appearance and style, with a nice thick white head.

I was excited by the appearance of this beer upon first pouring it -- it poured an attractive golden shade with streams of bubbles and a good thick white head -- but I was let down by the aroma and flavor I experienced thereafter.  Aroma was pleasantly hoppy but weak, and the same was true of the flavor.  The brew was quite refreshing, but it simply lacked the strength of flavor that I was hoping for.  Not a bad beer at all, but it just doesn't live up to its appearance or its reputation.

(Bottled) Very pale golden color, largeish head with big bubbles and lace. Very mild, hoppy and somewhat fruity aroma. Citric-hoppy, slightly malty flavor with a sugary, slightly harshly bitter finish and no aftertaste. Light-bodied, quite smooth palate with balanced carbonation. A very easily drinkable, but not watery lager, with hints of the fruitiness of some lighter Belgian blondes. Not that bad, although it has no real taste to offer.
I can see from other reveiws that this isn't very popular, but I disagree.  Nice yellow color with plenty of carbonation, good crisp flavor of malt and nice hops. I could drink this beer all night.
Poured a head that looked like a glob of spit, which surprisingly lasted the whole beer.  Had a buttery aroma, warm bitter flavor.  Nice old beer.  I would have it again, though not my favorite

poured to a pint glass from a tap.  thin white head and bright yellow color.  little to no aroma, medium fizz, and light grassy taste.  it's funny that Belgium exports this, but since it's in a lot of bars now I'm assuming this is driving a lot of revenue, so good for them.

June 2002  Bottle. This is a lager that I have recently developed a taste for as an everyday cooler. It has no distinguishing features, is steady and reliable and leaves no nasty tastes. It is also quite reassuringly cheap. What more praise can one give?! The Ford Mondeo of lagers! Give that man a Stella! [2.5] 
  March 2004.  Bottle. Head to Head with Baltika Classic. Both are yellow. A big hit of sharp prickly rubber with the Baltika. Both have a co2 aroma. More hops in the Stella - a better balance of what flavour there is. Nothing obscene about the Stella - it’s drinkable. Stella beats the Russian. [1.9]

Dec, 2006 Bottle. Drinkable, slightly biscuity pale lager. No big off-flavours, though no character either. Mild, dry, soapy bitterness in the finish. Hoppier than the average global lager. Compared side by side with Skol and Carlsberg. Acceptable. [2.5]

April, 2007Tap, Clarendon, Gillingham A salty finish. An awareness of bitterness. Neutral. Drinkable. Assertive but not aggressive fizz. [2.3]

On tap.  Light golden color with creamy white head.  Poor lacing.  Odor was somewhat hard to pick out and was terribly weak to boot, but had mild hops and yeast character.  Front was mildly sweet with fizzy carbonation and a lightly bitter finish, some hop character.  Very boring, fairly drinkable and painfully overpriced.

Can
Pale yellow, foamy white head. Hoppy start, some bitter in the end. Tastes lame and metallic.

Bottle sample- Pours a head average for this style beer. Blanchy white. Body is almost a "bright" yellow. Kinda strange. Aromas of hops and corn. I thought it was flavourful at first, because it does have some bitterness to it, but that faded rather quickly, and the end result was a beer that tasted just above par. Nothing to write home about. I must admit though, they make it seem like the classiest beer in the world.

On tap in QC Canada.  not even the lure of the Chateau Frontenac could disguise the fact that this beer is an imposter.  Is has all the bite, but none of the body.  Its lack of artificial sweetness makes it better than the american standard pilseners, but not enough to justify it's "premium" status.

Bottle, pours that kinda scary clear, bright yellow that so typifies a certain bodily excretion.  Aroma is basic lagerish and slightly skunky.  Flavor is unremarkable pilsner malty with a nice hop bite.  Light body and highly carbonated.  This is one belgian that I have little fondness for.
This is the Budweiser of Belgium. Not bad, but with so many other really great brews, why is this so popular? Maybe because it's a good quantity, not-quality thirst-quencher.
What a marketing campaign, but a thin not inspiring brew to back it up. This would only impress a novice

Almost no aroma. Slight sweetness to it but the finish is bitter enough to make this worth buying in summer here. It has weaker flavors than more interesting lagers but that's fine when it's stupidly hot. And when it's stupidly hot it looks very nice.

I only buy it for home when it is on 25% off special should indicate the "overpriced for quality" factor..

In the home of dedicated drinkers, this is the UK's top-selling lager. High acclaim indeed for this Belgian brute. A superb lager, minus any of the typical European over-sweetness.
Spanner.
on tap:  pale malt aromas with sweet hop character. a bitter bite, that reminds me of bad beer taste.  one of the definate worse belgium beers, probably average for this style.
Liked it..the freshness and its cool factor was just right in the heat here in Australia. Better than most Aussie lagers. On tap almost anywhere in Melbourne.
very expensive beer, great taste, great beer for one of those chill nights to just hang with the guys

On tap at Ned Divine’s... Crystal clear, light yellow lager. Mild butterscotch and floral notes. Good bitterness. Light-bodied with a thin, watery mouthfeel and fizzy carbonation. Short, bitter finish. Why the f**k are they brewing a lager in Belgium? Just so BMC people can say they liked something exotic?
Clear golden colour with big foamy, but shortlived head. Aroma is mostly hops. Flavor is sweet with just slight bitterness. Palate is perfect.

An overpriced, but generally reliable pilsner. It doesn't smell much like anything. Straw yellow in colour, and a fair amount of carbonation. It tastes dry... perhaps even a bit bland, with just a hint of malt. Not bad, but there's usually something better to be had for the price.

Midlle of the road. Middle of the road. 
Why do we have to do it in the
Middle of the road?

Not much more than an typical, run of the mill lager.  Fluffy white head, crystal clear pale golden/yellow color.  Not much discernable aroma.  Mild malt flavor, no hoppiness. Nothing offensive in this beer, but not much good. Ho-hum.

WAY overpriced import.

Light golden yellow, small head... Appearances can be deceiving... and this one is, as it's the best thing about the beer.

Not much of a smell...

Taste... well, it reminded me too much of Corona with the lime added. I can't see playing $4.00 a bottle at the bar for this for the same taste as a crappy corona.

Yea it's drinkable, but definitely not worth it. You want this taste? Get a corona. You want a good taste, get something else.
First time I've had this.  Was expecting something more.  No aroma and little flavor, but true to the style.
Light, almost clear golden.  Little head.  I couldn't smell much, but it was getting later in the evening.  Taste was of some citrus fruit, maybe grass.  No real taste here.

Beer pours (in flute glass) a light golden colored liquid with virgin white head that lingers.  Aroma is of straw, grass, vegetal.  Flavor is of straw, grass, vegetal.  Like Rolling Rock, which isn't saying much.  This is a crappy yellow beer.  Sampled at 60 degrees Fahrenheit.
This stuff kind of sucks. It wasn't to bad when i started drinking it but as it warmed up a little it was like drinking cat urine.

Tap.  Surprised to find the Stella taphandle nestled in with a bevy of BMC at local watering hole.  Came looking fine, yellow-hay color, pretty nice looking head, fine white foam.  I'm not sure the beer had any aroma, it must have, maybe it was the smoke in the bar.  Flavor was somewhat malty, smooth, bit of a lemongrass bite that is nice.  A fine beer, but for the money I'll take the water next time.

A decent lager.  Nothing too special.
Clean...smooth...not really noteworthy in any way though. Not a bad beer...just not a stand out beer.
Green bottle skunkiness throughout not a good beer, but to be fair this is somewhat better on tap or in a can
Plain old fashioned beer in a fancy bottle and from a fancy glass.  Nothing special.

I have to say, opposed to the marketing for it, this is pretty much a regular old boring lager. It does look real neato in the suggested glass with the gold lip (extra wow!!? :). The smell is usually a nice skunk (greeen bottle) with a little hoppy grass. The flavour is crisp and clean but then it stops.
 Sometimes all you can taste is the alcohol, if you can believe it. There's nothing going on here, and you really can tell after you've had anything fuller bodied (eg. a glass of water). It's always billed as the premium, and waiters and patrons alike, exhalt the wonders of this brew. 
Dull. A bit better in a can, 50/50 on tap.       
   Belgian Budweiser.

Tap. Another case of wanted a beer and this was one of the few choices that wasn't Blue or Canadian. Pale yellow with a mild aroma - difficult to discern exactly what - and no head to speak of. Passable flavour until it warmed up a little when it began to go downhill. I'm sure I'm just adding to the list of comments about Belgium having its bad beers too.

In Belgium, there comes a time (in this case after about 10 hours solid drinking) where the mind can no longer appreciate the complexities of classic Belgian beers and the body can't cope with high alcohol blockbusters when something wet, bland and weak(er) is called for. In these circumstances, Stella is your boy. Bland and boring, but clean and dry - just what was required. Top marks goes to the Stella advertising chaps, who have managed to successfully market this as a "premium" (i.e. expensive) product in the UK, when in Belgium it is regarded, at best, as nondescript. Dubliner bar, Antwerp (well, the England footy match was on the telly), September 2003.
Hey, they make crappy beer in Belgium too!  I'd rather have a PBR or something.
Very good overall.  Tastes a lot like Hollande 1622.  Very strong hops taste and a nice color.  Pretty decent, but Heneiken doesn't taste too different either and costs a lot less.

On draught at Maynerd's of Excelsior, MN.  The beer was a gold color with some lace.  The aroma was very subtle.  The flavor was clean and sweet with a light body.  Overall, it was OK, but only compared to others that fall under my less desirable categories.
Better than average Macros- a half-step up from standard fares.  Nuttin' special- looks good, tastes okay.

White splochy head.  Nice lacing.  Golden color.  Aroma of rubber.  Smooth clean flavor with a little bit of a bite.  Tinge of sweetness, but overall, a typical European Pils.  I do like the smoothness, reminds me of czech pils.
Golden color, with little head. Decent flavor with a clean  finish. Above the average for macro stuff.
Pale golden, ok head. Aroma from almond. Not much flavour, watery, with some sweetness.
Golden, with a nice and creamy head. Has a mild aroma, maybe with some almond in it. Some malts, some hops, but it could have tasted more.Has an ok palate and some bitterness in the finish.
Golden color, white head. Fairly hoppy, bit of malt. Average Pils body. Decent for a macro.

Aroma from both bottle but primarily tap is hoppy with a small amount of spice which immediatly differentiates it from most macro lagers (in my limited experience.) Looks clear yellow but a bit on the lighter side that I expected. Drinks similar to other lagers with small amounts of malt and a bit of hops but very little body. Aftertaste was similar to the aroma (which was pleasing) just a hint of spice and a bit of hop. I give this extra points in overall impression as it manages to wind up beside all the other macro stuff on tap in Australia, I think it's real beer.

Draft at Coasters Brewpub. This beer's appearance consisted of a small sized white frothy head with fine-medium bubbles that were mostly lasting. The body was uncarbonated and transparent with a yellow-gold hue. The nose was lightly malty and the flavor was malty and somewhat bitey with an aftertaste. The palate was tingly and bitey and this was a light-medium bodied beer with fair lacing.

Had this on tap in a NYC restaurant.  Aroma of malt and spice.  A bit of a Heineken-like quality in the flavor, but not too similar.  The flavor is dominated by malt, with that bit of spice and some hop in the aftertaste.  A good beer, but don’t drink more than a pitcher at a time.

RE-RATE: Poured from bottle.  Aroma a dead ringer for Heineken - not a good start.  Appearance of a light lager, but paper-thin head persists.  Flavor is pretty much as I called it in the 1st review.  Has clean feel - very easy to drink.  Finished OK.  Decent.

TheDM and Hotstuff vacation brew 62.  This draft brew was enjoyed at Coasters in Eau Gallie Florida out of 1 of their 32 taps.  This brew poured a medium sized head of finely sized white colored long lasting bubbles that left behind a transparen very softly carbonated yellow orange colored body.  It had a medium strength malt hop aroma and a chewey mellow malt mouthfeel.  The flavor was that of a medium strength malt.

Draught, at Hogshead, Birmingham. Boring, tedious lager, which is omnipresent in the UK, and is indeed the no. 1 lager. Skunky falvour, dishwater aroma, looks like shandy and stronger than it needs to be as a session lager. Yawn...
another overrated lager, it's the only beer that i've tried from belgium i wont pay money for, maybe a more complex [if faint]flavour than most standard mainstream lagers.

Pours a golden yellow with a thin head. Decent lacing. Aroma is sweet and malty. A touch of hops on the tongue. Not a bad brew. Actually, it's pretty good for it's class. I expected this beer to be complete swill.
(bottle) Pale gold. Little aroma. Reasonably refreshing lager/pilsner. I didn't detect any skunkiness/metallic tastes--perhaps I had a fresh bottle. I'm sure the green glass doesn't help.
I was pretty impressed with this brew.  A little too expensive to geta lot but a nice change of pace.  Really like the flavor once I had a few.

Skunky, sweet and with that metallic cling-to-the-front-of-your-tongue type thing that comes with skunking. OK head retention and perfect clarity obviously, slightly creamy mouthfeel. Didn't think it was any good but then I had a Tooheys New and this killed in comparison.
Very nice dark lager.  Had one in Niagara Falls.  Nice finish, very smooth.  Comparable to a heineken
Dark straw color with a lid of white bubbles. Grass and malt aromas. Dry clight caramel flavors with a floral/dry rose finish. Nothing earth shattering for sure. Just another plain psuedo pils.
It was ok.  Very strong aroma, almost too strong.Nice foamy head.  Very light yellow color.

I think this beer is also terribly overrated, even if it is one of the best sellers in its demographic market or whatever.  It is still suffering from the green bottle blues.  A very sweaty musty skunk aroma and taste, but not as bad as some others.

I think this beer mostly suffers from being terribly overrated.  Its gaining increasing popularity (at least here on the East Coast) and even though it is gaining the status of newest beer snob beer at many sports and dive bars, I find it a little disappointing.  Its better than a becks or heineken, but has a bit of a skunky aroma (re: gym socks) with a very watery, corny, grainy taste.  Hint of apple cider as well.  Nice, unassuming finish.  Not bad, just not terribly great!
The REAL king of beers, aka "shoe loser" as well as "wife beater"
Very much like becks/heineken w/a strange offtaste.Not as bad as expected.Nothing to really seek out neither.It reminded me of this beer called Peter's pilsener.
I really don't know what the fuss was all about?  I had it in bottle so maybe I will have to try on tap.....will keep you posted!

Quite a popular beer here in the UK. Also affectionately known as 'wife beater'. Not bad for one of the larger brewers, I could taste some hops and a little of the grain, but, obviously, there are better Belgian beers out there.
Pale yellow gold with a frothy white head. Fresh pale malt aromas have a sweet herbal note. Flavors of grain are present in the background. Clean and crisp with a soft finish.

Had this on draught and liked it. Has a clear golden color and a nice little foamy head that left decent lacing. This beer doesn't have much flavor, mainly hops on the back end and a slightly cider flavor and aroma. I would drink this again in place of a soda. Nothing great but nothing offensive either.
I had this beer on tap at PF Chang's. It has a bit of a sweat sock smell.  The color is golden.  The head is light.  The taste is like a bud with a bit more flavor.
My first beer in Belgium and free in the Marriott's Executive  lounge. Pours a golden yellow with thick white head. Not much aroma to speak of. Goes down well if it is uninteresting.
This is a good everyday beer, good taste & body, refreshing but not up to the better Belgium beers.

Skunked. Golden clear body with little nucleation and light head that dissipates fast. Clean smooth flavour with minor grain flavour noticeable and a lasting bitterness. Mouthfeel is a bit flat. This is kind of one-dimensional and the green bottles are to be avoided but I would re-try this on tap. Bottle (green).

I tried the version brewed  in the United Kingdom and really wanted to hate it as it stands for everything I 
dislike-a mass produced British version of a European beer. But I was surprised as it has a clean smooth taste with some clear and pleasant flavours.Still by no means a very good lager just a passable one.

Smelt like Becks, a little bit off. nice clean amber colour but a very thin if not any head. tasted good enough with a nice sharp lingering aftertaste. Not bad but would have to better for me to go back there regulary.
tasted in croatia. smelled skunky. tasted pretty skunky too.  I didnt feel i had to get another bottle that was fresh to fully capture the beer's spirit.
On tap, terrible. Out of the stubby, terrific. One of many beers where the quality from stubby to tap is poles apart.

When I first drank this, i didnt have much to go on.  There is a lack of any real aroma and the taste surprised me.  It is rich from the barley,a smooth, slightly fruity pilsener than is finished off nicely with some bouncing hops - a good lager.  cheers

So here goes my first rating. Starting with my favourite lager might not be wise, but it might be informative also.

The appearance is nothing special, nice golden colour but the head soon vanishes. There is little in the way of smell, but what is is inoffensive.

It does have a good body for a lager and although I wouldn't mind more flavour it has a nice bitterness that most lagers lack.

Still, one of the best regular lager I know of and a good allrounder.

Rerated: this wasn't a very traumatic revisitation. More yellow golden than I remembered and even less head. Left some lacing though. Slight inoffencive aroma.

Nice hop profile, but I'd like to see the adjuncts (corn/maize) give way to a little more maltiness. That way this would be really good. As is, still better than most macro lagers, but overpriced.

I'm not too sure what's going on, but lately I've really been enjoying Belgium beers. I used to not care for them much at all. Stella has a wonderful taste that it smooth and suttle on the palate with just a hint of fruitness. A great beer to enjoy with a brat and while watching the Cubs kick a$$.
A crystal clear easy drinking smooth pilsener that is only lacking in a little bit of flavour.  Best on a hot day and better than most other european mainstream beers.

Crystal clear and yellow. Nice hop nose, I assume saaz, but not 100% Light body not as grainy as say Urquel, good lace.
Cheers

Absolutely crystal clear, concise, boring-ass pilsner. That's simple what this was. There is nothing here to be taken away, it seems like the epitome of what a pilsner has to be, but not what it can be, if that makes sense.
Based on draught version:  golden color, thin head, average tasting pilsner.  Fairly common pub beer in western Europe and Africa.
canary yellow in appearence and not much of a pilsner taste.  Would rather have a Pilsner Urquell instead.  The only good thing is that they were free.
Golden in color with a crisp clean and malty aroma. Hoppy and malty flavor. Light and refreshing.  I really like this beer. Clean tasting. Enjoyable.
Nice hops. The malt is a little watery in flavor, with hops being the emphasis. Great head. This is a good lawnmower beer.
Golden color with a white head. The taste is a nicely balanced malty and bitter combo.
next time will try with a lime in it if you get my drift, a little less artificial tasting than its Mexican cousin but not much better
bearly any head with an almost piss yellow color too it.  It was really refreshing, it had a pleasent malty taste and a nice finish that did not leave the mouth dry.

Middle of the road score on paper, but words fail me as to why the flavor is so damn good, as i said nice golden appearance but nothing special same with aroma of light malts but the taste is hard to describe but very refreshing but must be served at 5% and in right glass and direct in Brussels where they know how to serve and tastes even better

Nothing particularly wrong here, just very middle of the road.  Typical pils appearance, maybe a tad darker.  Draft, served in the corrct Stella glass.  Head faded away.  Smelled of light malts, a touch grainy, maybe grassy.  The flavor was soft, very clean, a bit of floral hops on the end.  Not watery, but not exactly full bodied either.  Stunningly average, easy to drink.
cool bottle, better taste... east to drink, very refreshing  going to go have  one right now

This brew always seems to get branded as the Belgian Budweiser, but imagine my delight upon entering a Homewood,Il "sportsbar" and seeing it on tap...a perfect savior from macros and cheap vodka!  Even cooler when it came in it's appropriate and branded glass.  The beer is no 50 pointer, but it is a decent grassy hopped, flavorful pils with slight touches of skunk from the bottle, but clean from the tap.

Pours a perfectly clear light golden yellow like a typical pilsener.  Aroma is sort of like an Hefeiweizen, with maybe a hint of banana--or is it skunkyness?  The head is a light white head which disappears into tiny lace.  The start is kind of cabonated with not much flavor.  It then smooths out very nicely and finishes with a bit of acidity.  Rating pilseners is always the most difficult, because they are supposed to be rather boring by nature.  One must not compare this to other complex styles.  From a pilsener perspective, id give this about a 6.5-7.0 out of 10.----re-rate 8/3/06. Boring malty start, with some toastiness. Finishes with a crisp, peppery, spicy hoppiness(5/3/6/4/11)~~~~~~~~Re-Rate~~~~~~~~7/24/13  The aroma has some corny DMS present.  Light vegetal.  No overt hops or skunk.  Meh.  Transparent yellow body with a foamy white head.  Starts with light sweet maltiness, before a touch of corny DMS comes through.  Finishes with light mineral flavors and a little crisp grassy hop flavor and bitterness.  Good enough.
A clean but body-lacking pilsner, very common in Yorkshire Pubs. Better than A-B Budweiser, to be sure, but not really a good British beer.

Keg version, brewed in Dunstable U.K. It's probably unfair to mark this crap, chemicaly mixed for the youth of Britain, but if Interbrew want to put their name to it to gain massive profits then they deserve it. It is sickly sweet malt liquor that could rot your teeth. They probably stir in some alcohol content as well. I can't find anything positive to say about it other than it looks ok.
Awful beer, tasted un-Belgian. The appearance is the only good thing.... It will give you also a headache...
Fairly ordinary flavoured beer, not much going for it in the taste department, easy to drink plenty of them but why waste your time?

A nice whote head on the inviting golden brew. A zippy hoppy aroma that really moves out of the glass. Surprised to discover this kind of round full flavor in a lager, bittering slighly at the end like a quaff o milk though not by flavor, more like a feeling. It doesn't spikebut rounds out, sounds a bit too fancy but I am intrigued.

Can bought at Brussels Midi Railway Station. No aroma detected. Malty orange flavor with some hopbitterness coming up aftert a while. Bland but not too bad for a international type lager. Or was it because I was thirsty and it was 35 Degrees Celcius?
not a bad pils, overall solid with nothing special standing out.  overpriced when compared to similar brands. especilly when sold in 11.2 oz bottles

Medium-gold, with a fairly reliable head. Powerful aromas of vinyl and skunk are the inimitable calling card of this Belgian lager, plus an undercurrent of cereal and sweetness. Skunk and a generous hop bitterness immediately appear on the medium-weight palate, with a thin, watery finish that fades away to wood. Very refreshing and rewarding, this beer is the best mass-produced lager in the world, and its surge in popularity means there’s still hope for this increasingly homogenous planet.
Not overrated, a very good pilsener, and cheap, it's my favorite pilsener !
Not overrated, a very good pilsener, and cheap, it's my favorite pilsener !
Hugely overrated beer but decent nonetheless. I can easily throw down three or four but any more and I reckon I'd quickly become sick of it. Don;t mind it on tap though.

Stella is really inconsistent.  For some reason, sometimes it's really good, and sometimes, you get skunky bottles.  Nonetheless, if you're in England and you want to get drunk cheap, getting 6 500 mL cans of 5.2% alcoholic beer that tastes a little better than average for £5 is a great deal.
Not great, but drinkable.  Couldn't complain about it, but it did cost me a little more than some others that I'd rather drink.
Not bad considering. Seems that about half the bottles I've had have been really skunky.
Nothing special... decent look goes with decent taste... smooth and easy drink...
Very light blonde with a small white head. Bread nose. Herbal taste with a watery texture, very easy to drink and clean. More hops would be enjoyable, but it's a decent mass-producted brew.

Had one of these on tap at Riva (on the Wharf)  while visiting Santa Cruz last Sunday.  This brew pours light sparkling golden.  The tight white creamy head is rocky with decent lacing and lasts to the bottom.  The nose is straight pils - a touch of grass and grains.  Keep in mind though I was on a wharf, where the smell of fish and cooked seafood predominates.  The taste is cereal and bready grain, balanced but shallow.  The palate was perfect for the day - light, creamy and soft, the finish feels clean.

7/19/03:  bottle.  uh!  god!!  fresh skunk stench as soon as you pop the cap on this one..  i wonder if they farm skunks to create this odor?  pale yellow body.  not too good, i just can’t get over the smell.   (just a suggestion... maybe they should rename this beer Stenchae Aromas).

A light straw colored with a wispy and quickly diminshing white head. Lacing.

Smells 100% skunked.

Watery, skunked flavor. The hops try to come through but they are quickly overcome by the skunk.

Typical smooth lager mouthfeel.
This is pretty much a middle-of-the-road Continental Lager.  Personally, I wouldn't call it a Pilsner.  I suppose some people will meddle the two styles.  At least this is much better than Heineken.
Nice beer for the trivial tap. A trace of toasted coffee aroma at the end, as a little bitterness after you have swallowed it.  Above the media, but nothing unforgettable.

April 2006 - 500mL Can. Crisp yellow body with a moderate white head and half decent lacing on the glass. Light muted grassy hop aroma. Flavour is fairly clean with very light bitterness over minute malt. Average palate. Pretty bland but inoffensive and lacking in flaws. Can clearly is better than the potentially skunky bottles. 5/3+/5/3/10
Oct 2000 - decent lager, less hoppy than some German ones, but decent beer for dinner. Not worth the $6 it cost me though... 4/3/5/2/9
Tap-just a pilsner, nothing special here. just had to give it a rating.  definately better on tap than the bottle.
Reasurringly expensive?  Well - it's overpriced, sure.  I just have no clue why it remains the beer of choice for so many. The only outstanding quality is how gassy this foul brew is.

Draft.  Absolutely no head. Mega-carbonation overkill. After tasting, was so unimpressed, I tried to chug it and it burned my throat into oblivion. Ouch! Crystal clear gold hue. I challenge anybody to differentiate this from any BudMillerCoors brew in a blind taste test. The epitome of "run-of-the-mill".
Piss colored, bland, but fairly clean, non-skunked, german hop aroma/taste. By no means any good.
On tap. Fairly average beer, more malt than anything, lacks a bit in hops and distinguishing flavors.
Pale yellow with very little head. Not much aroma to speak of; this can be said of the taste as well. A light pilsner, I can't say its objectionable, however it certainly isn't remarkable in any way.

Had it fresh on tap. Very nice, with a pleasant aftertaste, unlike when I had it out of a bottle, a green bottle, and the aftertaste was skunked.  A very inconsistent beer, had to re-rate it. Like it alot better when I was 18.

Lights skunky aroma. Pale yellow color, white head, fair lace. Thin, little malty, little hoppy, just a light pils. Short finish. The only pilsener my wife likes by the way. Probably because of the lack of flavors.
This is a very dissapointing beer, so much for the reassuringly expensive advertising. It is over-rated and not something I will be rushing out to buy again.
does not even come close to the other beers that i had tonight.  had a very average beer flavor and taste... the type that makes people drink budmillercoors.

This one's new in my neighborhood & I thought I'd give it a try.  Nice fluffy head and deceiving skunky aroma- this beer is somewhat musty with a flat finish.  I found this much like any other euro-lager (middle of the road).

I disliked this beer very much.  On a day in which I tried four lager/pils beers in a row (not as much by choice as by the lack of other options), this one was the least desirable.  Not much in terms of a nose and the flavor was not overly pleasant.  I'll pass the next time I see this one...
Pale yellow with a white head. Some skunk in the aroma, when first opened, but it goes away. Pretty unremarkable flavor.
No head, yellow color and no aftertaste.   However, its not bad and it can be found in most supermarkets if you are really antsy for a belgian.
Yellow w/ white, foamy head. Sweet bread-like nose. Thin feel. Some malt, some hops but generally bland.
No head, light golden body.  Refreshing, light malty flavor.  Not at all fantastic, but a decent beer.

This beer is really on the low end in Belgium and all the craze for trendy clubbers throughout the East.  That said - for a standard Pils, its not that bad.  Mine seemed really fresh with crisp malt flavors and a smart finish.  Tasty but not classic at all.
Belgians answer to our Budweiser.  Bland, mettalic, and pumpkin seed flavor.  Watery and plain finish.

Rerate Revising this after a few years - typical lager - a touch of honey sweetness - nice looking pour.  Neutral aroma. Decent saaz bite. Original 3.5 On tap at Taco Mac - Athens, Ga. - surprisingly not available in Tallahassee, Fl - one of the few most accessible beers that  I have not rated. Very decent Pils - clean light golden appearance - lots of bubbles. White soapy head.  Very crisp, clean flavor.  A bit of a slight hoppy aroma. Finishes strong.

When I lived in Belgium, we used to joke that this beer comes from the finest pee water. Really, it is a very average pils that's not complex. Color and aroma is standard with no outstanding  characteristics. A bit hoppy on the palate and a clean finish. I would call this this session beer of Belgium.

For a mass-produced pils, this isn't too bad. I had it on draft and it tasted fresh enough. Pale in color and in flavor. There is a slight hoppy finish which makes it better than most of the big beers. However, only drink as a last resort.
This is the Bud of Belgium.  A very standard lager with delusions of greatness. Wet cardboard nose, bound with cheap hop bitterness. I don't like this one at all.

This is actually getting worse down here. The beer is brewed under licence so the tap drop is not great. From the bottle it is not bad, with a mild hop finish and clean style. Still better than most of our swill.
Skunky garbage.  Trace hops in the nose.  Ungood flavor.  So much worse than Heineken.

Light golden in colour, with a short to medium head, which disappers rather quickly. Malt and herbal aroma. Mild bitterness, thin malt texture, short finish, but overall, not the worst macro lager around...
One of the most ordinary belgian beers. It's like Heineken, Carlsberg and so on. A little sweetness and a very little bitterness, that's all.

Decent white head with great lacing.  Plenty of carbonation also.  Light gold in color.  Slight malt/hop aroma.  Flavor is light and crisp and not offensive.  Finish is slightly dry and a little bitter.  A typical european pilsner but is actually better than a lot since it seems that they forgot to throw the skunk in the vat.

On draught: Looks like your average Pils clear light gold with snow white head. Tastes just like a German Pils in every way. Crisp clean light body with high effervescence. Subtle malt flavor and ever so slightly bitter.Very refreshing but not a great Pils. More recently I've had Pils from Ayinger and Pinkus which were both far better.
It is very crisp.  This reminds me of Czech lagers like Staropramen and Pilsner Urquell.  It's drinkable, but stronger than most American lagers.

Had on tap on May 7th, 2003 at Callahan's
The beer poured a golden color with slight carbonation.  The aroma wasn't anythign special - perhaps some hops and grain - but weak.  Taste is nothing to write home about - it was easy to drink, but the taste was a bit acidic with a weak aftertaste.

This beer poured a dark straw color and formed a nice bubbly white head that didn't leave much lace as it subsided. The aroma was of green apples and had a slight skunkiness to it, which couldn't have been from the store since Columbus just got this stuff in a few weeks ago. A medium amount of carbonation was present. The flavor was of hops and grain. For a lager, it had a surprising amount of taste to it and the finish actually had a bit of body to it. I can see where people would compare this more to something like a Heineken.

Had this a couple of times now and my feelings have changed quite a bit. For one, I don’t think it’s skunky at all on tap. For two, I’ve noticed some interesting clove and banana flavors lurking in there. Maybe it’s the Belgian influence but the smart money says they need to lager it longer. 

Original rating: Pours a pale golden. Decent head and lace. Somehat grainy aroma, a bit skunky even on tap. Pretty sweet, almost sticky. Strongly bitter. Some citrus notes. Well balanced. A good pilsner.
Poured a nice bright yellow with a good white head. Little aroma present. Flavor was very subtle. A decent tasting clean lager with a little complexity.
A fancy Budweiser with a harsher bite and higher alchohol content.  Typical lager clean & dry finish.  A good beer if you like mass-produced American lagers, but not stellar.
Golden yellow with a fine but quickly disappearing head.  Smells of hops and sharpness.  Some flora hops with a tangy bite.  Finishes sharply.  Smooth.  Decent beer.

Nice looking head, but it disappears almost instantly.
A citruslike aroma, with a sour flavor. Too much acid. An international standard lager.
International Standard Lager indeed! Not much aroma, not much flavor. Flat feel. No carbonation. Uh...
Not bad, probably the most available beer in Toronto - every place I walked by had a Stella Artois sign, or umbrellas, or something.

The most mis-used beer in the UK. Know affectionately as ‘the wife beater’ its drunk on mass by the masses. Light golden colour, it should have a strong head (often doesn’t though). When next in Belgium I rate it properly again.
belgian version, very skunky, watery, some corns, not very good ............
Heard good things about this brew. Very dissapointed. Light in color light in taste. Not very pleasing. Sorry folks
(Tap)Deep golden color with decent frothy head. Rotten egg smell, possibly from contaminated draught lines. Light bitterness becomes apparent on swallow.
" Stella recently began getting imported into Tampa, maybe even Florida all together. I had been reading about it for years, now I’m hooked. I call it the European Budweiser. "

Fronts some doughy biscuity flavors and chases that with decent, almost spicy bitterness, but the whole thing is obscured by a funky musk.  Drinking the brew is like trying to view a decent pastoral painting that has been vandalized with spray paint.
On tap: good mass-consumption beer but nothing else.  Not much to say about this one.

This beer is just a little dissapointing for a belgian Very famous beer. Otherwise my wifes favourite beer :)
Colour: Pale Golden Hue
Taste and Aroma: Hoppy aroma with a hint of fruitiness. A fine and clean bitterness due to the presence of several hop varieties in the recipie is well balanced with the malt flavour, a littlebit too much bitterness though in the aftertaste.
A decent Lager/pilsner.  Not much flavor,but more than your average. I never buy this beer, but I drink it on planes when I go to Europe because it's free.

I can't beleive i found this. I've never seen it anywhere and boom i find it on tap at some Irish bar where come english guy was schooling me the inconcsitencies of trans atlantic mcdonalds. It was served in a chalice and had a fruity clean aroma. The taste was like a cleaner, lighter version of heineken. Not bad, not good. finished with a low, low key amount of hops and bitterness. Not much else going for it though.

this one was disappointing. for whatever reason, i was under the impression that this was a great brew and had always meant to have one. now that i have i don't ever plan to again. not much aroma and an extremely thin body. the flavor was thin as well with no discernable hop and only the slightest bit of malt. one of my least favorite beers ever.

Not a bad brew. Nothing terribly special about the flavor due to its mild character although what flavor there is, is quite good. Clean and dry aftertaste. Great beer to drink while just kicking back and relaxing. Better than Beck's although somewhat similar.
Nice and clean standard lager, refreshing and quite good. Sometimes I have a feeling that it's brewed in every country in Europe.
Grainy aroma with a long finish.  A bit bitter.  I don't know why everyone on this website hates on lagers- they're not my favorite, but they're not deplorable.  For a lager, this is not a bad beer.
This pale yellow beer looks like a Budweiser. Pale yellow. Smells skunky but doesn't have much flavor.
A DECENT BEER THAT IS VERY DRINKABLE. IF YOU EXPECT A GREAT BEER YOU WILL BE DISSAPOINTED. I WOULD DRINK IT AGAIN.
Not really all that impressive, a glorified bud or mgd.  Had it off the tap, but it still tasted like a straight up pils. Nothing more do I have to say.
Not my favorite beer. The first time I had it (bottle) it was a bit shit. I think it's better off tap or out of a can.
Had it the other day at school on tap. fairly decent as far as lagers go. No evident hop flavour. Low bitterness. Unbalanced.

Regular golden pils with huge chunky white head. Skunky aroma (damned green bottles) Not much flavor. Thin and watery. Some hop bitterness. The worst beer brewed in Belgium I've had so far. With so many good ones, why bother with this?
A bit on the burnt side with the malt, but good otherwise... Not very impressed with the head or lack of complexity.

This one was about as middle of the frickin road as they get. Poured on tap at lucky baldwins, it came out a uriney colored yellow mass with a weenie little white head and very little carbonation apparent. It smelled super funky...just like a Eureka beer...with wheaty, grainy, breadym doughiness and a slight malt being apparent. It had a rather boring, clean and watery wheat/honey taste about it. It was putting me to sleep it was so boring. Clean ending, but nothing to the body at all....next!!!!!
Pissly transparentness..nice head though..smells like budweiser but tasted like budweiser with some peaches and nectarine puree'd and slopped on top...although in the end..its lagery poo.
Pale golden colour, decent head. Hoppy aroma. the taste is has some malty sweetness, with an hoppy, quite bitter aftertaste. A regular commercial pilsener: not bad, but nothing special.

Clear pale golden color with a bubbly and frothy head. A little wheaty aroma and some skunk. A taste of skunkiness and a nip of floral notes. I really am not a pilsner fan, but thought I would give it a try.
Even out of the bottle, this is one of the cleanest, freshest tasting brews I've had in a long time.  Pretty dry too.  Goes down real smoothly, and one of the few brews I can drink at least a six of.

Bright yellow color.  Mild hop aroma.  Lots of carbonation and a light, airy palate.  Pretty good flavor, much better than I remember.  Moderate hops and some malt, it is much like a Bohemian pilsner.  Score increased from original of 4/2/5/3/10.  Seems best on draught.

A dark yellow beer with a nice white head. The aroma is a strong hoppy one - really nice - it almost fills the room when you pour it and makes you think of a Czech pilsener. The flavor is very sweet (maybe too sweet) with a nice but not that prominent bitterness. A little more balance would help. A good beer for a pilsener.
Thick, bitter then sour and full of chemicals. Whoops, not 75 characters. There - that's better.

Had on tap.  It was pretty tasty.  Yellowish, a little on the bitter side.  Good if served cold and consumerd before it warms too much.  I'll have again while I'm out, but don't think that I'll ever buy a sixer for the fridge.

Pours very clear yellow with initial foamy white head. Head dissapears quickly leaving lacing. Old hops aroma. Thin clear mouthfeel with slight sweetness. Spicey bitter hop tastes. Alright beer if its served very cold and its a hot day.
I don't know why this beer is rated so low. I enjoyed this beer. I do think it's a little over-rated in my opinion.
(tap) Has a Heinekin-like stenchy aroma. Pours a light yellow, head is thin to non-existent. Palate is unenjoyable and finish weak. Overpriced and overrated.

(2Feb2003--draft)
Frothy, active, lacy head, mostly receding, medium/low effervescence.
Medium yellow color.  Mild hop aroma, somewhat fruity.  Flavor is fruity, with some malt notes, somewhat yeasty, some hop tanginess, low bitterness.  A bit flat.  Finishes sweet, with some acetaldehyde (green apples) creeping in.

Pale gold colour, ample but mostly diminishing frothy white head. Toasted malt and corn aroma. Starts dry and lightly toasted, picks up some corn and sourish notes, with a light and dry bitterness throughout that grows on the finish. Light and dry mouthfeel.
Skunky smell out of the bottle but not so bad out of the can.  One of my favourite tasting Macro Import Lager.  Can easily enjoy a couple of these because of the lightness.
maybe it's just the Australian version but this is pure crap.  Nice and clear crap, but crap.
blah.  Yucky, typical pilsener tasting yuck.  Yellow gold, thin head, blaaaaah.

Light color and body with nice white head.  I dont particularly like this stuff in bottles, however, on tap it it was pretty good.  aroma was mixed with some malt and a good amount of czech hops.  Flavor is sweet and crisp with nice hoppy flavors and a good hop finish.

Very light yellow. . .very thin.  Wheaty aroma that reminds me of the wort in a whiskey distillery.  Flavours are few and far between, but there are some grains and malts present. . .somewhere, I remember this having much more flavour 2 years ago, but it probably does in comparison to the XXXX and Touhey's I was drinking at the time.
A decent enough brew,a  good lager,but not good enough to justify the price they ask.
Thin, pale pour.  Not very smooth to drink, but mostly enjoyable.  It""s easy to find better, tho.

On draught at the Uva Cafe in Downtown Disney. This beer really did not impress me on any level. The first thing I noticed on the tap was that this was from Belgium so I guess I was expecting a Belgian Ale, but this is very obviously a Pils, and an uninspiring one at that. Pours an off-putting yellow with a thin white head. Light hops aroma. Bland flavor that did nothing for me. At least it wasn''t skunky.
Looks like pee, smells like skunk pee and popcorn, tastes like a cheap american beer.  This is the worst beer I have ever tasted from Belguim.
Blah.  It''s annoying watching people think they have good taste because they drink this stuff.
Hazy yellow with small white head.  Leaves nice lacing.  Slightly sweet aroma, bit of grassiness.  Taste is smooth and mostly indistinct, with a bit of a grassy bitter aftertaste.
very light, good flavor, mild and sweet.  good beer.........................
Slightly grassy aroma, little hint of hops.  Smooth body, slight grassiness and a nice length of hops in the finish.  An ok pils, fairly unimpressive.

Better than Becks, not as good as Jever.
Nice hop character-average Euro pilsener.
It is tasty but not exciting. Not as crisp as I like in a pils..............
One of the better mainstream pilseners. Head is huge, and nice and silky. Has a nice palalte. Still, nothing too special
Bottled(500ml). -nice pilsener, pale gold colored, little to sweet..........
Lots of head and definately a nice golden colour. Kind of bitter but not offensive.
Clear light gold with huge white head.  Sweet light malt and green apples, lightly bitter aftertaste.
Slightly hoppy.Balanced,Better than average, mass produced, European lager.
I didn't approve of this beer before but due to my retrained beer palate, I think this beer is quite good.  Nice clean maltiness, very bright, good clarity.  Good!
Light clear color.  Bitter taste, and pretty much a standard tasting large pilsner.  Some wheat-type flavors come through.
I tried even Ukrainian and Hungarian versions: nothing really special.......

A beautifull color and wonderfull presentation on tap at the O''Carrolls downtown Halifax they know how to serve beer at this establishment . But this beer was not the beer of choice in Belgium .A bit of hops and skunky sour smell .Not a try again .
hmmm... I don''t know but I was very dissapointed by this one. Very watery taste to it. Not much better than any of the Budmillercoors types. Totally overated in my opinion! Stay away!
Love this out of the tap, find the bottled version not as pleasent. ........
I was disapointed,I expected more from it,you can just taste that classic saaz hop under the slighty skunky smell.Fine in the mouth,alittle hard on the nose.
This isn''t a bad pilsener.  Drink while it is fairly fresh though..........
Middle-of-the-Road brew, which is where you''ll find yourself yacking if you drink too much of it. Slight sour aftertaste.

9-09-12 Re-Rate: Rating for the 2nd time, almost 10 years hence. Bottle. Smell is not offensive. Crystal clear yellow body with thin white head and sparse lace. Virtually no flavor. Has flavor approximating that of a light beer. No Belgian qualities. Rating went up slightly from a decade ago due to aroma. However, still has no redeeming value since the calories and ABV are too high for a beer this flavorless. 12-01-02: First heard of this beer over a year ago during a trip to Toronto. If I had it then, it was not memorable, as it was during this tasting. (BBC-Menlo Park) Moderately malty in aroma. Non-existent head. Good clear, amber color. Better flavor than I remember. Sweet, with some bitterness. Outside of the color, the lack of head, lace and sparkle makes Stella an unattractive beer. Without much to redeem itself in the taste, this ends up a below average brew. 2, 2, 5, 3, 7
Nothing really unique about this brew. Good chilled NOT WARM has odd sour taste and smell
Nice and Refreshing, Excellent when chilled and drank on a hot day..........
Mild, slightly sweet and slightly sour beer.  A hint of hops but pretty bland overall.  Smooth, drinkable, but not distinctive or bold in any way.

Oooooh: I had a bit too much at the Bank Hotel last night and woke up feeling a little discoloured. This is too sweet for me. If you spill it, you are gonna have a hard time wearing your thongs out to the loo without them sticking to the floor for a few days.
Nice hoppy aroma, with a taste that is nothing new but nothing bad either. Works about as well as any mass-marketed German pils.
Bottle.  Golden color with a laced foamy white head.  The only nice touch to this beer is the slightly sweet malt flavor in the middle.  Otherwise, it is rather bland.  Some flowers in the nose.

New Zealand Brewed under licence.

very hoppy/grassy aroma light clear gold colour, with fluffy head, mild bitter taste. Would love to compare against an orginal.
Re-rating.  I had this recently and I was generous with my rating.  Bland...
it was refreshing, but so is water. i read somewhere that this is belgium''s answer to bud.  it didn''t have the skanky horse-pee scent of bud, but i can see the resemblance.
Earthy aroma.  Nice moderate hop zip.  Medium gold. Good lager..............

This time i'm having one brewed by New Zealand breweries in Auckland, NZ, i think this is a bit blander than the Belgian version, sweet, with a slight bitter edge on the finish, better than most macro lagers, similiar to the Belgian brewed Stella, not too much difference.
Fresh.  A good drinkable beer.  Crisp and clean tasting.  Slightly bitter with a little aftertaste.  Good lacing with a very good appearance.  Clear yellow.
Goes great with any kind of fish. i usually dont like pilseners but this is a winner. good hoppiness and clean taste.
Golden yellow color. Citrusy aroma. Watery. What is that aftertaste. A Belgian disappointment.
A great standby - always worth having in the fridge. There are better lagers but there are far worse - Jupiler for a start!
Very nice. It has a distinctive taste and appearance. This beer has great character. Its a pleasure to drink
Not that bad, but not my type of beer.  Fairly bitter and odd aftertaste! Slightly refreshing though.
draft: nice to see in many bars as an aletrnative to other standard offerings. A slightly more spicy, citrusy, and generally lighter lager than many of the other large scale counterparts.
An average pilsener. Colour light yellow. Not much aroma and flavour. In the aftertaste there is a lot of water.
This smooth pale golden beer has a slightly sour, bitter aroma and flavor.  However, compared to some of the "Big" beers of the same style , this one beats them out.
It's for those who don't really like a good beer but still want to feel international. Very much an international lager.
Not really good. I didn,t a lot but the taste was not really good. Euro-Bud ?
Has a yellow color and a skunky smell.  Taste is typical Euro-skunk light colored beer from a green bottle.

Light gold color, medium head. Light bodied lager style beer. Light malts, somewhat hoppy. Taste is a little harsh. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is crisp. Aftertaste is slightly bitter. Some green bottle taste. I realize that this is supposed to be a ‘classic’ beer, but it really doesn’t show me much.
Too plain to leave a lasting impression.....................................

Well, it was advertised as the best selling Belgian beer, and if that’s the case, that’s a shame.  On the other hand, it’s pretty drinkable.  Not bad for a yellow beer, but it could definitely use some more... something.. On a positive note, the paper wrapper that goes all the way up to the cap is as classy as classy gets.

This beer has a gold/yellow body - hue apperance and a coarse white scum collar. I have drunk the beer from the bottle and it had no carbonic acid. The initial flavor taste is an weak extract and you get an headache of it.
Thin with very little flavor. Decent but nothing to look for................
Great for a hot day out in the sun.  It is very refreshing with decently crisp hops in the aroma and flavor.  Good balance in flavor of the bitter hops and the sweet malt.
Not exceptional except that it is a mass-produced beer.  I would be very happy if the avearge big brewer's beer tasted this good.  A lovely choice for a few on the patio.
Probably the safest lager to drink off tap in the UK.  Considering the alternatives.

Just what a pilsener should be.  Light, slightly hoppy but balanced.  Light golden in color, fluffy white head and good lace on the glass.  Aroma is a lot sweeter then other European pilseners that I have had.  Not bad overall.
I'm sure the original stella(if there was one) tasted exactly like this.  they must have had boring lagers in the 1300's.
good color and a nice head, light hop aroma, not all that good..............

I realize this beer isn't considered to be any great shakes in Belgium, and that it's marketed in the US as a "premium" beer when it's perhaps not, BUT I thought it was quite pleasant and drinkable.  Very smooth, and not overly fizzy like an american standard.  Not bitter at all.  Nice.
Crystal clear bright yellow.  Nice light malt flavor, but there’s almost a cucumber aftertaste?  Easy to drink and inoffensive European lager.
Not bad.  You can get better pilsners for cheaper, though.  Due to the cost, I probably wouldn't end up drinking these all night, but if they were free, I would strongly consider it.

On tap at Brussells airport.  Well I decided to try it one more time before I left Belgium especially when someone recommended trying it on tap. Visually its the same pale gold clear  but this time under a large medium lasting white head and faint lacing. Served too cold to discern anything other than s faint hop straw aroma. Same old thinnish watery body and faint bitter palate.  From what I can see there's no real difference between on tap and bottle versions of this beer.
First rating 6/17/2002 2.1
Bright gold clear colour with almost zero head. Faint malty corn syrup and hops aroma. Thin watery body and light bitter hops flavours. Faint bitter hops and soft sweet finish and wimpy aftertaste. Fortunately I only have to drink this once (for rating purposes only) while living in beer heaven - so for now it's back to the strong Belgians.
Rubbery, hoppy, adjuncty aroma. Almost no head, pale amber beer. Med.-light carb and body. Crisp with a bitter alcohol taste. Not very impressive for a Belgian beer.
Drunk at a Belgian musicfestival. Can't say that i really like this pilsener. Belgians can make great ales but they shouldn't brew pilseners.

O.k., now that I've had this on tap, I'll re-rate: previous bottles were not so hot.  Nice cookie dough malts - sure, not real thick, but it was refreshing with a nice mellow hop at the end.

(original:)light golden color.  There's a sweet maltiness from start to finish.  The hops dry out the finish, but are still dominated by sweetness.  average at best.
Primium?  I couldn't taste anything.  Sure it looks nice goes down easy, but a little too easy. Very timid....  Its a weak drink.
Looks and tastes good.The best lager around.................................
not much of a beer really, somewhat flat and uninspiring, give me a pale anyday over this slop!
On draught, this is a fairly typical macro pils. Fairly lively, light gold colour, reasonable given the usual alternatives on tap here.
It's tough to stand up to the excellence of most Belgian beers, but this is fine for a refreshing pint. Some batches seem to get a little skunky, though.
Very good beer, but not one of the better pilseners out there.  Some idiots in my study abroad group actually mistook this beer for Amstel - its definitely not that bad...

It's been some time since I had this one but it's all over England now. I remembered it being great and exclusive in my student days, and although not outstanding certainly one of the better choices for British lager drinkers. Smooth, lightly carbonated, malty lager with a nice crisp hoppiness around it. A little skunkiness in bottled version.
Definitely needed a rerate for this-one.  Sparkling yellow body.  White rocky head, excellent lace, fully lasting.  Yeasty aroma.  Lightly bitter flavour.
One of the better massproduced pilsners. Too expensive......................
Watery at first, but flavor picks up after a few drinks.  I found it to be a little sour but still easy to drink.  Very little aroma at all and very light looking for a European beer.
(re-rate) (draught) Not bad. Grassy aromas and easy drinking. However - it's nothing special for sure.
Not awful, but hardly worth getting excited over. The Belgians have their own styles, why are they messing around with this kind of thing?
Another typical belgian pils. Almost the same as Jupiler....................
I had this one on seat Beach rock, This is a typical Pils beer..............
Watery, no taste. I was not able to really to appreciate it. Need to re-rate.
A light pils that's not worth the high prices you find now in bars. It's a good cheap European pils and nothing more.

I liked it somewhat. a decent pils for all the crap it takes.  I thought the hops hit you right away. could use more i suppose, havent had tons of pilseners. the hops are very dry. I did not like the aftertaste, it was stale.
Deffinatly a beer to be seen with as the taste is nothing to write home about.  Have tasted much better pilseners in my time. Crisp taste but leaves a lot to be desired
a clean crisp beer. nothin special kinda ligh tfor my tastes but if this is wha tye rinto it might not be bad

Well, I can’t believe it, I actually had a great glass of Stella. Lovely bready malt, but light, with a fantastically fresh hop note. Brewed in Australia. If it was this good all the time I’d give it a better score. Unfortunately most other times I’ve tried it it’s been mediocre at best.
not very distinctive.  More style than substance here.  A beer for posers...

Is not a world class lager. 
Taste is slightly hopped but lacks a crisp bite.
Not stellar but an alright beer. Typical blond color. Not much head but quite a bit of lacing. Goes down smooth and easy. Would buy again.
Not a bad pilsener, but nothing exciting.  Appearance was weak and the flavor was decent with some bitterness.  Drinkable, but better out there.
Weak head, taste is a lil' bit bitter, but not enough. Very drinkable tho, so not much wrong with it, but not much great about it.

Bottled:
Pours a golden colour with a lacing head. Aroma is sweet malt, glue and grass. Grainy flavour with some citrus notes. Dry finish.

Can't say much for aroma or color, other than that the golden hue did seem to have a bit brighter look than other beers of its type.  It tasted crisp, and light, with a nice hoppy bite at the end.  Not bad.

The label's ironic claim to be "Belgium's Original Beer" explains why Belgium went on to create so many fine beers--people obviously turned off by this.  Your standard stuff.  At least it didn't have the bitterness or metallic finish common to other interpretations of the style.  Thoroughly unexceptional, if drinkable, stuff.
Reminded me of a budwiser, iwht a kind of rice taste too it.  It had a bit of a bite upon the first taste, but I adjusted after the second sip.  The aftertaste lasts, but it isn't a bad thing.
boo.. this is bad, tastes sweet, uninteresting... bland, watery.............
Had this at a tap room in and cost $6 for a pint.  Not really impressed with the taste at all.  Tasted alot like the Polish pils Lezajsk.
It's nothing really special, but nice for a change every now and then.......
